**PROHIBITION OF OFFERS TO EEA RETAIL INVESTORS**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, and should not be
offered, sold or otherwise made available to, any retail investor in the EEA or in the United Kingdom. For these
purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of
Article 4(1) of MiFID II; (ii) a customer within the meaning of the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that
customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II or (iii)
not a qualified investor as defined in Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”).
Consequently, no key information document required by the PRIIPs Regulation for offering, selling or
distributing the Notes the debt securities described in this Offering Memorandum or otherwise making them
available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering, selling or distributing such
debt securities or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the
PRIIPs Regulation.

This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in any member
state of the EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement
to publish a prospectus for offers of securities. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes
of the Prospectus Regulation.

**-------------**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered,
sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom. For these purposes, a retail
investor means a person who is one (or more) of (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of
Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA, (ii) a customer within
the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement
the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined
in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the
EUWA. Consequently no key information document required by the PRIIPs Regulation as it forms part of
domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering, selling or distributing the
Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the United Kingdom has been prepared and

prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in the United Kingdom will be made pursuant to an exemption
under the UK Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. This

**GLOSSARY OF SELECTED TERMS**

In this Offering Memorandum we use certain industry-specific terms and abbreviations when
discussing our business, the meanings of which are indicated below:

“2P bundles” .......................................... a combination of products marketed to our customers that
combine mobile and fixed broadband services, fixed broadband
and TV services or fixed broadband and voice services.

“3P bundles” .......................................... a combination of products marketed to our customers that
combine mobile, fixed broadband and either fixed line or
television services.

“4P bundles” .......................................... a combination of products marketed to customers that combine
mobile, fixed line, fixed broadband and television services.

“ACM” .................................................... the Authority for Consumers and Markets (Autoriteit
_Consument & Markt)._

“ADSL”................................................... asymmetrical digital subscriber lines.

“ARPU” .................................................. average revenue per user. See “Summary—Summary Financial
_Information and Other Data—Key Performance Indicators.”_

“BUs” ...................................................... building units, meaning any unit of real estate that is
differentiated by age, use or physical, administrative or legal
features from another such unit.

BUs are a reference unit commonly used to measure the FTTH
footprint of an operator. This unit can be a plot of land or a
dwelling in a building with a condominium regime. Likewise, a
single-family home may consist of more than one BU if distinct
areas are allocated between residential housing and other
purposes (e.g. commercial premises, warehouse, garage,
swimming pool, etc.).


“bundled **services”** or “bundled
**offerings” ............................................**


a combination of products marketed to our customers that
combines fixed line services (telephone, broadband and
television) and mobile services.


“DSL” ..................................................... digital subscriber line.

“DTA” ..................................................... the Dutch Telecommunications Act (Telecommunicatiewet)

“e-Privacy Regulation” ......................... the proposed Regulation on Privacy and Electronic
Communications concerning the Respect for Private Life and
the Protection of Personal Data in Electronic Communications
and repealing Directive 2002/58/EC.

“Fiber-to-the-home” or “FTTH” .......... the installation and use of optical fiber directly to individual
buildings, such as residences, apartment buildings and
businesses to provide high-speed internet access.

“fixed broadband” ................................. the broadband access provided via retail ADSL, VDSL,
satellite, fiber optic, COAX, HFC and other circuits over 2 Mb
per second, narrowband access (internet service through public
switch telephone network lines) and non-broadband final
customer circuits. Our fixed broadband services also include


-----

“Naked ADSL,” which allows customers to subscribe for a
broadband connection without a monthly fixed line fee.

“FMC” .................................................... fixed-mobile convergence.

“FTTx” ................................................... a generic term for any broadband network architecture that uses
optical fiber to replace all or part of the metal local loop.

“GHz” ..................................................... gigahertz.

“HFC” ..................................................... Hybrid fiber-coaxial.

“homes passed” ...................................... any of the residential or business addresses by which fiber
infrastructure, including an access network, city ring, area PoPs,
city PoP, and other elements deployed in connections with these
things, passes such that the address can be connected to the fiber
infrastructure by the installation of a segment of the access line
that connects a passive finishing unit at the address to the fiber
infrastructure.

“IoT” ....................................................... the “internet of things,” a system of interrelated computing
devices, mechanical and digital machines with unique
identifiers and the ability to transfer data over a network without
requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.

“LE/CE” ................................................. large enterprise or corporate enterprise.

“loop” ...................................................... the physical circuit connecting the network termination point at
the subscriber’s premises to the main distribution frame or
equivalent facility in the fixed public telephone network.

“Magenta FTTH footprint” .................. the footprint of that part of TMNL’s fixed internet network that
consists of FTTH, as sourced from the Open Dutch Fiber,
Primevest and KPN networks.

“Mb” ....................................................... megabits.

“MHz”..................................................... megahertz.

“MNO” ................................................... a mobile network operator.

“MVNO”................................................. a mobile virtual network operator, which is a mobile operator
that is not entitled to use spectrum for the provision of mobile
services. Consequently, an MVNO must subscribe to an access
agreement with a MNO in order to provide mobile access to
their customers. An MVNO pays a determined tariff to such
MNO for using the infrastructure to facilitate coverage to its
customers.

“NRAs” ................................................... national roaming agreements.

“OTT services”....................................... “over-the-top” telecommunications services provided via the
internet (such as voice and video calling, television and video
streaming) that are provided separately from the end user’s
internet service, typically by a service provider independent of
the end user’s internet service provider.


-----

“portability” ........................................... the regulated procedure which allows a customer to change to a
new mobile operator free of charge while maintaining the same
telephone number.

“RaaS” .................................................... radio-as-a-service.

“SMB” .................................................... small or medium-sized business.

“SOHO/VSE” ......................................... single office, home office and very small enterprise.

“unbundled local loop” or “ULL” ......... includes connections to both ends of the copper local loop
leased by one operator to other operators to provide voice and
DSL services (“fully unbundled loop” or “fully ULL”) or only
DSL services (“shared unbundled loop” or “shared ULL”).

“VDSL”................................................... very high bit-rate digital subscriber lines.

“VoIP” .................................................... voice over internet protocol.

“Wholesale services” ............................. network access that one operator provides to other operators,
who then sell services to their residential and corporate clients
via such network access.

“xDSL” ................................................... digital subscriber line technology.

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) effective from January 1, 2019. As a result, leases (as lessee) that would
have been classified in previous periods as operating leases are recognized in our consolidated statement of
financial position as of December 31, 2019. Under the new standard, except for short-term or low-value leases,
the right to use a leased asset is recognized as an asset with a corresponding financial liability for the present
value of outstanding lease payments. Assets with a finite useful life are subject to impairment testing. We have
adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment
obligations from existing operating leases were discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and
recognized as a lease liability and the right-to-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of
the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments.

As a result of the application of new accounting standards and the associated impact on our Historical
Consolidated Financial Statements, prospective investors should exercise particular caution when comparing
our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 to our financial
condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial_
_statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may_
_cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations.” For a discussion of the_
effects of the adoption of IFRS 16 on our financial condition and results of operations, see “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability_
_of Our Results of Operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and note 2.4 to the 2019 Financial Statements._

We have included in this Offering Memorandum for the convenience of the reader, certain metrics
excluding the impact of cash leases that have been impacted by IFRS 16 as the adoption of IFRS 16 has had a

Consolidated Financial Statements for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum and we believe it is
of interest to investors to present certain measures excluding such impact to facilitate like-for-like comparability

Underlying EBITDA AcL because we believe that these measures provide useful information to
our management and investors with respect to our overall operating performance by facilitating
comparisons of operating performance on a consistent basis by removing the impact of items not
directly resulting from core operations. We present these Non-IFRS Measures because we believe
that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other
interested parties as supplemental measures of performance.

- “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage.

- “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
AcL divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage.

- “Underlying EBITDA AcL Margin” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL divided by
Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage.

- “Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL
less Capital Expenditure.

- “Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL less
Capital Expenditure.

We present Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow and Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow
because we believe that similar free cash flow measures are frequently used by securities analysts,
investors and other interested parties in evaluating similar issuers. Pro Forma Operating Free Cash
Flow and Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow should not be considered as measures of cash
flow from operations under IFRS or as an indicator of liquidity.

- “Cash Conversion” which we define as Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow divided by
Underlying EBITDA AcL.

- “Capital Expenditure” which we calculate as the sum of mobile capital expenditure, fixed capital
expenditure, IT capital expenditure and other capital expenditure.

- “Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL adjusted
for (i) the full year effect of achieved synergies and (ii) the full year impact of planned unrealized
synergies.

We believe Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL provides useful information to our management

**Overview**

Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network
operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid)
and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our
customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile
service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for
the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The
_2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by_
_Umlaut)._

As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers, representing
an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For the twelve
months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our combined mobile
service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled €391 million, and
our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million. Mobile service
revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming, and our fixed
line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as fixed line
wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other
adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was €292
million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €637.4
million.

TMNL traces its origins back to 2002, when Deutsche Telekom entered the Dutch market through the
acquisition of Ben, which it subsequently rebranded as T-Mobile in 2003. In 2007, we acquired Orange
Netherlands, making us the third largest mobile operator in The Netherlands after Koninklijke KPN N.V.
(“KPN”) and VodafoneZiggo Group Holding B.V. (“VFZ”). In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s fixed business,
Vodafone Thuis, which was subsequently renamed to TMNL Thuis. This transaction marked our entry into the
fixed market, adding approximately 150,000 fixed line customers. Through the TMNL Thuis acquisition, we
also gained access to a dark fiber footprint on KPN’s fiber network (KPN ODF). In January 2019, we completed
the acquisition of Tele2, strengthening our position in the Dutch market, across all segments. In December
2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, an online-only SIM-only MVNO on our network, focusing in
particular on the low budget segment of the market. The Simpel acquisition further strengthened our position,
making us the leader both in terms of B2C mobile postpaid SIM cards and service revenues. We continue to
operate the Simpel brand after its acquisition in 2020. In April 2021, we announced a strategic partnership with
Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP that plans to roll-out fiber services to over one million
homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on this network which focuses on dense, urban areas in which we
currently have a large mobile market share. The Open Dutch Fiber partnership is an example of our asset-light
model and lean operational setup, which we believe enables us to streamline our business and optimize our
indirect cost base ratio.

We provide our B2C customers with a multi-brand portfolio of mobile services, including voice,
messaging and broadband aiming to cover all segments of the market from premium to low-budget and
operating on our own networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide
fixed broadband, TV and fixed voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. In addition, and in
line with market trends, we offer B2C customers packages that bundle mobile and fixed telecommunications
services at attractive prices, known as FMC packages. Our B2B business segment is dedicated to meeting the


-----

connectivity needs of companies of all types and sizes as we offer a broad range of telecommunications
solutions, cloud-based and unified communications solutions. The chart below sets forth key events in our
growth and transformation to the largest mobile telecommunications provider in The Netherlands’ B2C market

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Attractive telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands_**

We operate in The Netherlands, which has a sizeable and attractive telecommunications market which
consists of three main telecommunications providers. The Netherlands is the 6[th ]largest economy in Europe and
has a robust macroeconomic environment, with 2% real GDP growth expected for 2021, moderate population
and household growth, and a large demand for high-quality communication services (Source: Telecompaper).
We compete in both the mobile and the fixed markets with KPN and VFZ. We are the premier company in the
B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as


-----

compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the same market. The MVNO market is small
accounting for approximately 4% market share of postpaid SIMs, with the largest MVNO, Youfone, having an
approximately 3% market share based on number of SIM subscribers. In this context, we believe the risk of
irrational behaviors by existing competitors is low and that existing MNOs are likely to compete primarily on
the quality of their services. Following our acquisition of Tele2, the market players were further consolidated
from four to three and a process of revenue and ARPU stabilization started, similar to what has been seen in
other markets such as Austria, Germany or Ireland. The Netherlands has one of the lowest ARPU levels in
Europe.

We also believe that the risk of a new MNO entering the market is low. We believe that this is due to
the following factors: (i) the highly converged nature of the market, making it less attractive for new entrants,
as they must be able to offer both mobile and fixed offers to be competitive therein and (ii) the lack of any
viable spectrum auction that could allow the entrance of a new player, since the upcoming 5G spectrum auction
in The Netherlands is planned to offer only a specific band of spectrum and we do not need to renew our existing
spectrum licenses until 2030, making the auction more suitable for existing MNOs and unsuitable for new
entrants. The most recent possibility for a new entrant to obtain a marketable spectrum allocation would have
been the 2020 multi-band spectrum auction. However, only the three main players in the telecommunications
market, namely KPN, VFZ and us, participated in the auction. Additionally, we believe that the competitive
risk posed by MVNOs is low because MVNOs have limited ability to compete on unlimited subscriptions in
light of each MVNO’s lack of owned network and their limited ability to cover FMC packages, as well as such
unlimited plans’ impact on costs. Indeed, the number of MVNOs has decreased by half from approximately 60
to approximately 30 in The Netherlands over the last six years.

Furthermore, we anticipate that the B2C mobile market will continue to grow as data traffic continues
to increase. Indeed, our B2C mobile pro forma service revenues grew by 3.1% in 2020 (after a 4.1% decrease
in 2019) despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Key trends include:

(i) Growth in postpaid SIMs subscriptions, which is driven both by prepaid to postpaid subscription

migration and by population growth, as well as trends of increasing proportions of multi-SIM
subscriptions; and

(ii) Growth in mobile ARPU as driven by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services, value-added

services as well as overall inflation and the telecommunications market’s shift towards larger data
bundles. We believe that B2C ARPU will grow in the future due to these factors, even though
mobile ARPUs had decreased in The Netherlands in past years because of intense price
competition and mobile discounting as part of FMC offers, mainly triggered by KPN and VFZ.

The B2B market has seen similar developments. In particular, ARPU in the SOHO/VSE segment
follows consumer market trends, driven as in the B2C market by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services
and value-added services, and we believe those drivers will continue to push ARPU growth. In the B2B market
generally, we believe that growth in subscribers will be driven by growth in SOHO/VSE businesses, an
increased adoption of mobile services in the B2B market and an increasing adoption of converged
telecommunications solutions.

Additionally, the Dutch fixed telecommunications market has benefitted from infrastructure upgrades
in recent years that have contributed to a growing market, in spite of declining telephony and peaking TV,
primarily due to a higher demand for broadband services at higher speeds, which is our core product offering
within the fixed segment. Historically, the fixed internet market in The Netherlands was dominated by KPN
and VFZ, which have a combined market share of approximately 80%. We have positioned ourselves as a
challenger in this market, focusing on providing fast broadband services and offering competitive and
sustainable pricing. In the future, we believe that growth in the fixed market will be driven by (i) an increase in
subscribers associated with household growth and (ii) premium customers’ willingness to pay for ultrafast fiber
and better quality, which allows for more-for-more strategies and results in increasing demand for higher fiberbased data bundles.

FTTH coverage is expanding in The Netherlands and the B2C and B2B markets are expected to benefit
from such expansion. We expect to benefit from this trend through what we call our ‘Magenta’ footprint, which
includes several Optical Distribution Framework-type of agreements and partnerships with, among others, Open
Dutch Fiber, KPN’s affiliate Reggefiber Operator B.V. and Primevest Capital Partners, where we expect to


-----

eventually have access to over three million households at sustainable commercial terms. The remaining
households can be reached by Wholesale Broadband Access (“WBA”)-type of access on KPN copper (until its
planned phase-out over the next three years) and/or fiber network. Additional infrastructure players of
significant size include Delta Fiber, Glaspoort (a joint venture between KPN and APG Groep N.V.) and
Eurofiber.

**_World-class network and strong commercial execution_**

We lead our competitors across a number of key attributes, including our world-class mobile network
with the largest spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands, our leading brand portfolio and our strong commercial
execution.

In December 2020, Umlaut ranked us the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in
a row, and in February 2021, they recognized us as the top network in the world (Sources: PresseBox, Five in
_a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again; PresseBox, T-_
_Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut). According to the ACM, our mobile network carries_
approximately 50% of mobile data traffic in The Netherlands. We believe that our leading network position
results from our efficiently leveraging three key pillars: (i) technology, such as single radio access network
(“RAN”) with future-proof site configurations that are regularly upgraded in anticipation of customer demand;
(ii) sites, as we operate an optimal site grid with the highest site density in urban areas and 4,982 base stations
in total, providing coverage to more than 99% of the population of The Netherlands; (iii) the largest mobile
spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands with interference-free low bands, resulting in high cost efficiency and
an indoor capacity advantage. As of December 31, 2020, we held an aggregate of 250 MHz of spectrum, in
comparison with 215 MHz for VFZ and 195 MHz for KPN. None of the licenses in our portfolio need to be
renewed before 2030.

We have distinguished ourselves by our distinctive brand portfolio. In line with other MNOs in The
Netherlands, we have been following value-based and more-for-more strategies that target different market
segments with separate brands. Each of our four brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated profiles,

**_Well-positioned to benefit from market tailwinds for growth in market share, B2C revenue, customer_**
**_satisfaction and ARPU_**

Our status as a leading B2C mobile operator is confirmed by our market share as measured by our
volume of subscribers and by our revenue. As of December 31, 2020, we have 42% of the B2C mobile postpaid
market share by volume, which corresponds to 5.1 million SIMs. We have managed to reach our leading volume
market share of 42% over the past three years, supported in part by the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, while
the absolute number of subscribers grew at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2018 and 2020. At the same time, our
market share by revenue increased from 33% to 40% over the same period.

Our B2C mobile revenue growth in the past three years was mainly driven by stable ARPUs at brand
levels and a growing subscriber base, driven by marketing strategies for our brands, our strong positioning in
unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2, and an increase in demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel.

We have also maintained growth in customer satisfaction, which has helped us retain customers. In
the B2C mobile market, TMNL outpaced its competitors in The Netherlands by delivering the fastest-increasing
customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely
adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group which combines customer recommendation, customer likelihood
to continue services, competitive advantage and performance. Our TRI*M score increased by over 50% over
12 years. We believe that an increase in customer satisfaction was one of the key factors driving the reduction
in our B2C mobile churn to approximately 11% in 2020.

We believe that our position as a leading B2C mobile operator with growing customer satisfaction
metrics situates us well to take advantage of trends towards converged fixed and mobile offerings and more

-----

for-more strategies, as it allows us a larger base of customers to cross-sell into FMC packages and to upsell into
more premium offers. See “—World-class network and strong commercial execution” and “Industry—Dutch
_Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market—Focus on fixed broadband market.” Already in the first three quarters_
of 2021, our ARPU has grown across all four of our brands, corresponding to increases of between €0.8 and
€1.1 in the third quarter of 2021 in comparison with the first quarter of 2021. We expect to experience moderate
growth in the future by building on our success in growing subscriber base and potential further ARPU growth.

**_High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model_**

We have a successful track record of M&A, synergy realization and cost optimization. This track
record, combined with a lean, asset-light fixed business model has given us operating leverage and operational
efficiency.

In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s B2C fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which we shortly thereafter
rebranded T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone’s divestiture of Vodafone Thuis was ordered by the European
Commission as a remedy to provide competition clearance for VFZ, the joint venture between Vodafone and
Ziggo. This acquisition marked the beginning of our present fixed internet business and added about 150,000
fixed-line customers. In January 2019, we completed our acquisition of Tele2. This acquisition has strengthened
our position in the Dutch telecommunications market and allowed us to compete more effectively with KPN
and VFZ by giving us enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources and significant synergy potential. We are
executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have closed Tele2’s
standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings. Based on our
estimates, we anticipate realizing Tele2 cost-saving synergies with a total run-rate synergy potential of €130
million by 2024, of which we have already realized €115 million of synergies run-rate as of September 30,
2021. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, by then the largest MVNO in The
Netherlands. By means of this transaction, we acquired one million additional B2C mobile postpaid customers
who were already using our network under Simpel’s prior wholesale agreement with us. The acquisition of
Simpel provide further synergy and cost savings potential to be realized in the total amount of approximately
€9 million by 2024. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel entail for example related to reduced interconnect
costs, migration of Tele2’s business support system (“BSS”) to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad
debt collections (representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon
integration with TMNL), direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and
the cancellation of leased telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile
cross-selling, optimization of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related
costs as well as legal audit and tax fees. For risks related to our growth through acquisitions, see “Risk Factors—
_Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Acquisitions and other strategic transactions present many risks,_
_including the risk that we may not be able to integrate newly acquired operations into our business, which may_
_prevent us from realizing the strategic and financial goals contemplated at the time of any such transaction and_
_thus adversely affect our business.”_

We believe that these strategic acquisitions, coupled with our rapid and successful organic growth
initiatives, position us well to capture further market share and grow margins across the business segments in
which we operate.

Further, our lean and digital business model also allows us to benefit from strong operating leverage.
Aside from the lean operating cost base described above, we have also repositioned ourselves to become a
digital telecommunications company with an asset-light fixed model. On September 1, 2018, we demerged our
tower business into Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra). Subsequently, on January
1, 2019, one day prior to the closing of the Tele2 acquisition, we distributed Cignal Infrastructure as a dividend
in kind to Deutsche Telekom, with TMNL continuing to have full access to the contributed infrastructure
through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure
to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP, which is a joint venture of Cellnex and DTCP. Currently, we benefit
from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term
contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional
periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the
Consumer Price Index. Additionally, we continue to hold our own market-leading mobile spectrum portfolio.


-----

In our fixed segment we also have an asset-light model. Our partners, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest,
are conducting the roll-out of our FTTH network, and we do not have any direct fixed access network
ownership. We expect to have access to the over one million FTTH homes that Open Dutch Fiber is scheduled
to roll out to by 2025 in densely-populated areas with strong TMNL mobile customer presence. Under the
Primvest partnership, we expect that we will have FTTH access to approximately 130,000 homes passed. By
the terms of this partnership, we benefit from an initial period of exclusivity and line prices with base rates of
not more than €15 per month, indexed to inflation and subject to certain adjustments. In both of these
partnerships, we have agreed to certain utilization commitments. In addition, we have access to approximately
two million homes passed on KPN’s Open Distribution Framework footprint which is completed by WBA for
a nationwide fixed network footprint.

Such a lean business model has allowed us to achieve total capital expenditure savings of over €700
million, estimated as savings as a result of us not having to allocate and devote capital expenditure on building
a fiber network and mobile towers for five years.

**_Strong cash flow profile with demonstrated resilience and strong cash generation_**

We have historically demonstrated a track record of growth, profitability improvement and strong cash
flow generation. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have been able to maintain growth and increase
profitability, as evidenced by a 29.7% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin in 2020 in comparison to
26.7% in 2019. We believe this demonstrates the resilience of our business and of our company overall. In
addition, we generated a 56% Cash Conversion in 2020 in comparison with an average level of 30% for other
international telecommunication companies.

We delivered revenue growth in a challenging market environment between 2018 and 2020 at a 2%
CAGR. Such growth was mainly driven by a growing subscriber base and stabilizing ARPU levels in the mobile
B2C segment, as well as by strong growth in our B2C fixed business. Historically, our B2C mobile segment
has been the major contributor to revenue at a 4% CAGR between 2018 and 2020, having accounted for 47%
of total revenue in 2020. Our B2C mobile business delivered significant SIM net adds, particularly in the Simpel
and Ben brands, and relatively stable ARPUs among those of our brands that offered the increasingly-popular
unlimited data bundles. Positive developments offset a decrease in roaming revenue as a result of COVID-19–
induced travelling restrictions. Our B2C fixed segment was our fastest-growing segment, growing at a CAGR
of 11% over the past three years. We believe that this strong growth was driven by a successful FMC challenger
strategy which resulted in strong growth in subscriber base that amounted to an additional 133,000 customers
in the past three years.

We also delivered strong performance in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, both in terms of margin
expansion and growth. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin increased from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7%
in 2020 and to 31.1% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL
exhibited a strong CAGR of 16.1% between 2018 and 2020 due to an improved gross margin, declining indirect
costs in absolute terms from cost saving programs and headcount reduction, and realization of Tele2 synergies.

Because we delivered strong revenue and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL expansion through
challenging market conditions, we believe that we are in a position of strength and greater scale to deliver
incremental top line and profitability expansion as market conditions improve.

We also benefit from a strong cash generation profile driven by a solid top-line performance that is
combined with prudent cost management and moderate capital expenditure needs. Our Underlying Operating
Free Cash Flow increased by 53% in 2020 compared to 2019, and is expected to continue on a growth trajectory
going forward as we maintain our capital expenditure-light strategy. Our Cash Conversion was 56% in 2020
and it further increased to 58.9% during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, which is above the
average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies.

**_Committed and experienced management team_**

Our experienced management team is led by our CEO, Søren Abildgaard, and our CFO, Gero
Niemeyer, each of whom has over 22 years of industry experience. Our management team is seasoned in
running, acquiring and staffing telecommunications businesses and in navigating consumer markets both in The
Netherlands and abroad, and they leverage the expertise they acquired over decades of combined experience at
top-tier telecommunications and consultancy companies such as Telia, Orange, Magenta Telekom, KPN,
Deloitte and Booz Allen Hamilton. More importantly, the management team has a strong track record of
delivering growth from both organic initiatives and strategic acquisitions, and has won and maintained strong
stakeholder support while maintaining a strong debt capital structure. This industry-leading management team
is supported by a deep bench of divisional managers, who in turn are supported by a substantial workforce of
1,870 full-time equivalents as of September 30, 2021. Our employees, 48% of whom are customer-facing, are
highly diverse, being represented by 45 distinct nationalities.

Our management team has reached multiple milestones. Under our management’s leadership, revenue
between 2018 and 2020 increased by a CAGR of 2% due to increasing B2C revenues, and Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA AcL Margin expanded from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 as driven by an improved cost structure
and synergies from the Tele2 acquisition. Furthermore, the team has successfully repositioned our company as
a full FMC challenger in addition to having executed the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions.

**Our Strategy**

We have detailed commercial plans to support our further growth, both in terms of volume and of
value, for all brands and segments. In particular, we have identified a number of key drivers leading to growth
in our business which we believe will preserve our leadership position in the future, namely (i) leverage our
leading position in the B2C mobile market, (ii) capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus, (iii) exploitation
of untapped B2B value pools and expansion in fixed and (iv) optimization of our indirect cost base ratio, with
(v) a commitment to ESG initiatives.

**_Leverage our leading position in B2C mobile and benefit from market tailwinds on 5G monetization,_**
**_unlimited offerings, portfolio optimization and increased value-added services_**

We are a leading B2C mobile operator with a SIM market share of 42% in the B2C mobile postpaid
market, corresponding to 5.1 million SIMs as of December 31, 2020. B2C revenue growth resulted from
stabilizing ARPUs in 2019 and 2020 as well as a growing subscriber base, further supported by growth in


-----

unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2 as well as an increasing demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and
Simpel. We have also seen continued growth in our customer satisfaction. For B2C mobile, we have delivered
the fastest increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade, having outpaced our competitors
in The Netherlands.

Our leading market position provides a strong platform for growth both in terms of volume and value
across all brands and segments. In particular, we plan to grow ARPU through (i) 5G monetization, (ii) unlimited
growth, (iii) portfolio optimizations, (iv) value-added services and (v) FMC growth.

_Drive 5G monetization_

We were the first operator to reach nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band in 2020, and we
believe that we are well positioned to monetize our 5G investments. We offer 5G connectivity per default to
our premium offerings, such as T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan,’ or as an add-on to our value offerings, such as a
€2 p.c.m. add-on for our Tele2 customers. In the future, we plan to extend our 5G offering and continue our
more-for-more portfolio approach on the back of 5G.

_Grow unlimited offerings_

We believe that we hold a leading position in unlimited offerings based on our number of subscribers
and on our having been the first to have introduced an unlimited plan for mobile in The Netherlands. Our
premium offers in the mobile segment are unlimited plans, which we sell for €35 p.c.m. and €25 p.c.m.,
including value added tax (“VAT”), through the T-Mobile and Tele2 brands respectively. T-Mobile’s
‘Unlimited plan’ also includes 5G connectivity by default. Having introduced these offerings in 2017, our
unlimited subscriber base grew from 578,000 subscribers in December 2018 to more than a million subscribers
in June 2021. In May 2021, we also introduced an ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ plan including access to Netflix
and Videoland, a Dutch streaming service. We intend to continue to grow our unlimited offerings in the future
as we believe that unlimited plans are a key value driver in our premium portfolio by increasing customer
loyalty and customer satisfaction, and ultimately result in above-average monthly recurring charges (“MRC”).

_Portfolio optimizations_

Our multi-brand portfolio is a key value driver that allows us to effectively compete in all market
segments. All our brands have a distinctive positioning, minimizing the risk of intra-brand competition. With
approximately 100,000 intra-brand migrations in 2020, creating an average incremental MRC of €1, we have
proven the ability to upsell to customers within our portfolio, accruing value.

_Value-added services_

We believe that by offering value-added services (“VAS”), we distinguish ourselves from our
competitors while increasing ARPU, customer loyalty and customer satisfaction. Our new ‘Unlimited &
Entertainment’ package, described above, is one such example. In addition, T-Mobile offers security options
and add-ons from the music streaming service Deezer. On Tele2, we recently introduced ‘Unlimited for a day’
and ‘Unlimited weekend’ plans which add VAS to a Tele2 portfolio that already includes, among other things,
a 5G priced add-on.

_FMC growth_

Compared to KPN and VFZ, who have mobile FMC penetrations of 65% and 71% as of December
31, 2020, we believe that our FMC penetration of 8% as of December 31, 2020 provides us with ample
opportunity for growth. While KPN and VFZ leverage their large fixed bases, we intend to focus on crossselling our fixed offerings into our leading consumer mobile base. Since FMC customers are more loyal, more
satisfied and have higher monthly bill sizes compared to one-product customers, we expect FMC growth to be
attractive, both, in terms of volume and value.


-----

**_Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus_**

We are a successful challenger in the B2C fixed market with approximately 9% market share by
subscribers in 2020. In the past three years, as our business has grown its subscriber base and revenue at a
CAGR of approximately 11%, marking the fastest growth among our competitors, our market share has grown
from 7% in 2018 to 9% in 2020 and our share of total subscriber gross adds has grown from 17% in 2018 to
20% in 2020. We believe that we have been able to deliver this rapid, market-leading growth by leveraging our
challenger strategy and B2C fixed ARPUs below those of our competition, as our fixed ARPU was
approximately €33 for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, compared to the market average of
approximately €50. Our price leadership is evidenced by our FMC offer which combines 1 Gbit internet speeds
and a T-Mobile Unlimited subscription for a price of €50 p.m. (€25 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile
subscription), compared to €90 p.m. at KPN (€65 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile) and €93 p.m. at VFZ (€65.5
p.m. internet + €27.5 p.m. mobile). These consumer bundle prices are excluding promotions. We believe this
lower fixed-segment ARPU and challenger strategy represents a strong lever to continue attracting valueseeking customers. As illustrated in the chart below, we are able to offer fixed and mobile services at a
significantly lower price than our competitors.

We have an FTTH footprint that covers approximately 1.6 million homes passed on KPN’s and
Primevest’s networks. FTTH is also achieved through the Magenta footprint. We expect a further increase of
approximately 500,000 homes passed by the end of 2021 and the Magenta footprint is expected to significantly
increase homes passed by 2025. Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest partnerships are also key pillars of this
strategy. We have secured exclusive agreements with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in addition to benefitting
from non-exclusive ODF wholesale access to the KPN network, complemented by nationwide wholesale access
via KPN bitstream. For more about our partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, see “—Our
_Competitive Strengths—High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model.” We believe that our_
partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in particular will allow us to grow our fixed subscriber base
and drive margin expansion while maintaining healthy cash profile through our capital expenditure-light
strategy.

In the future, we plan to increase our revenue share through share gains at competitive ARPUs. First,
we plan to tap our mobile subscriber base, which is the largest in The Netherlands, to cross-sell our fixed
offerings to our mobile customers. In our T-Mobile brand, FMC penetration rose from 4% in 2018 to 20% in
2020, whereas overall for our company, FMC penetration increased from 2% in 2018 to 8% in 2020. However,
our FMC penetration remains well below the FMC penetration of our competitors. We believe our penetration
will grow in the future both as a result of a focused sales approach and because we expect more SIMs to become
FMC-eligible in 2021-2022. Planned quality improvements will also help grow and maintain our fixed base
through increased customer satisfaction and loyalty. Second, we will rely on highly-competitive ARPU levels
to further drive market share gains. Going forward, we are considering shifting towards a value-based
proposition by focusing on high-end fiber speeds and value-added services.


-----

**_Exploit untapped B2B value pools and expand in fixed_**

We have established a presence in the B2B market across all segments, namely SOHO/VSE, SMB and
LE/CE, both with our mobile and our fixed offerings which represent 71% and 29%, respectively, of our B2B
revenue in 2020. Our presence extends across all B2B customer segments with our largest exposure in the
SOHO/VSE and LE/CE segments at 36% of B2B mobile service revenues each, followed by the SMB segment
with a 25% revenue share (Source: Company information).

We have increased our revenue market share in the mobile B2B market from 17% in 2018 to 20% in
2020. For the past three years, we have the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator as measured by SIM net adds,
having earned a 43% SIM net adds share in 2020 in comparison with 31% for the closest competitor. We believe
this strategy highlights our success in attracting B2B mobile customers and managing churn well, and we
believe it will fuel our growth in the coming years. In the fixed B2B market, we had a modest revenue market
share of 4% in 2020, affording us an opportunity to grow our presence in the segment in 2021 and beyond.
Among our key priorities, we aim to transform the former Tele2 large enterprise legacy business and expand
into SOHO/VSE with fixed offerings.

Recognizing the above growth path in B2B mobile and the opportunity in B2B fixed, we have defined
a strategy to develop our potential in each of our SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE B2B segments. Our
entrepreneurial approach is built on four key growth drivers, namely (i) FMC offerings in the SOHO/VSE
segment, (ii) an SMB portfolio that combines FMC offerings (a “converged” portfolio) with cloud-based
service enhancements, (iii) a differentiating partner approach and (iv) fixed transformation in the LE/CE
segment.

_FMC offerings in the attractive SOHO/VSE segment_

The SOHO/VSE segment is a highly attractive market for our services, both because of its higher
margins and because we believe we are well-positioned to succeed in this space as a result of its similarities
with the B2C segment where we are a leader in mobile. This segment has rarely been tapped by either T-Mobile
or Tele2 before and it is growing in line with the B2C market. See “—Our Competitive Strengths—Attractive
_telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands.” Given our strength in mobile offerings in particular,_
we intend to target the SOHO/VSE segment by relying on FMC offerings. For example, in September 2021,
we launched a VSE internet offering and related FMC bundling proposition in order to provide the best value
for money, thus opening an additional market segment for us and a potential source of incremental revenue.

_FMC and cloud-enhanced SMB portfolio along with differentiating partnering approach_

We operate in the SMB segment under the T-Mobile and selectively under the Tele2 brand for larger
SMB customers. Our SMB offering comprises a product portfolio focused on FMC and cloud-enhanced
solutions. In the SOHO/VSE segment, we strive for an increase of our Unlimited attach rate as a key value
driver. In addition, we believe that our SMB FMC seats will increase, driven by, among other things, a Microsoft
Teams integration that forms a unified communications solution which we were the first to launch in the Dutch
market. We have a large mobile customer base and, as in the consumer market, we intend to upsell fixed and
unified communications services to our mobile base. In addition to our core connectivity services, we sell a
broad range of communications and cloud-based solutions tailored to the customers’ needs through our
extensive partner portfolio. See also “—Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus” above.

_Fixed transformation in LE/CE_

In the LE/CE segment, we are conducting a transformation of our fixed services in order to realize the
full potential of our extended portfolio. We are in the process of a transition from Tele2 legacy fixed
infrastructure to future-proof transactional stacks in order to accommodate changing customer demands that
request faster and more reliable connections and thus are switching to future-proof fiber-based technologies
which includes a shift from copper to fiber, from VPN to SDWAN and a phase-out of ISDN. We also intend to
supplement our stable fixed wholesale business with international carriers and Internet Service Providers by
wholeselling active services in ODF areas.


-----

**_Optimize our indirect cost base ratio_**

We have an asset-light fixed model and have been focused on creating a lean operational setup since
2016 when we completed a reorganization under the name ‘Lean Telco’ with a headcount reduction of certain
full-time equivalents and a savings target of €30 million. We further streamlined our business with a “3F – Fit
For Future” initiative in 2018-2019, having achieved our further cost savings target of €100 million during the
two year period 2018-2019. The focus in the coming years will be on optimization of our indirect cost base
(“IDC”) ratio through:

    - _Focusing on smart growth by transforming remaining legacy architecture, digitizing processes_
towards self-service, improving fixed product quality and transforming the OSS while focusing
on high-margin segments, thereby increasing our scale;

    - _Countering inflation with efficiencies by investing in marketing automation, robotic process_
automation and first-time right focus to deliver efficiency gains as they increase productivity; and

    - _Continuing to optimize costs by investing in systems and process improvements._

**_Build on our ESG commitments_**

We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several initiatives in order
to improve our impact on the environment and society. We intend to build on our past ESG successes with a
four-pillar ESG program. Our first pillar is sustainability. In 2020, we already used 100% green electricity and
produced 60,000 kWh of renewable energy by using our own solar panels. In 2021, we introduced eco-plastic,
E-SIMs and lighter packaging. Additionally, we have targeted a reduction to carbon neutral emission level by
2026. Furthermore, we will reduce new plastic packaging to zero by 2026. We continue to be involved in our
community in other ways, such as our establishment of two partnerships to accelerate “Innovation for Society”
projects in 2020.

For 2021 and 2022, we aim to set up three impactful “Innovation for Society” partnerships to invest in
e-health, education and smart cities. Going forward, we intend to continue setting up three partnerships a year.
We also focus on digital inclusion, as our goal is to enable more people to be part of the digital society. In 2020,
more than 2,500 people gained access to the digital society with our social SIM program and we reached more
than 15,000 people through our debt prevention program. Our target is to reach more than 25,000 disadvantaged
individuals every year.

Lastly, our management aims to foster an environment in which everyone feels included. We have set
up a dedicated work stream in the diversity and inclusion program focused on activities and awareness within
the company, sharpened our policy on social return and set up a “Back to work” fund. For 2021 and 2022, our
focus is on diversity and inclusion, such as through setting up gender-neutral communication and starting the
dialogue on safety and belonging. Our goal is to be a 100% inclusive organization by 2025.

**_The Acquisition_**

On September 6, 2021, funds advised by Apax and Warburg Pincus, which together control the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer, announced their intention to acquire the Target from its current shareholders, Deutsche
Telekom, the holder of 75.0% of the share capital of TMNL and Tele2 Sweden (together with Deutsche
Telekom, the “Existing Shareholders”), the holder of 25.0% of the share capital of TMNL. In this regard, the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into a sale and purchase agreement dated September 6, 2021 with the
Existing Shareholders and the Target (the “Acquisition Agreement”), pursuant to which, the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer agreed to acquire the entire issued share capital of the Target.

Under the Acquisition Agreement, the aggregate consideration payable by the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer at Completion Date, consists of €3,713.5 million plus €700,000 per calendar day from November 1, 2021
until the earlier of (i) the Completion Date or (ii) the date falling 15 business days after the date on which the
last completion condition under the Acquisition Agreement has been satisfied or waived, to compensate the
Existing Shareholders for additional cash generation in the Target Group during this time period. The purchase
price will be adjusted for a leakage amount, which consists of €24.0 million as re-branding costs plus the sum
of any specified item resulting in leakage of value, for example, any distribution by the Target Group to any of
the Existing Shareholders or certain affiliates parties and any payments made or amounts payable under the
SAR schemes instituted by the Target, in each case, during the period from July 1, 2021 until the date of transfer
of the shares of the Target to Senior Secured Issuer (together, the “Leakage”). In addition, the Acquisition
Agreement also specifies the manner in which the acquisition consideration payable by the Senior Secured
Issuer is to be split between the Existing Shareholders.

Under the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions,
including appropriate clearance from the antitrust and other regulatory authorities and the satisfaction of
relevant procedures with the Target’s works council. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, a number
of these closing conditions have been satisfied, and among key conditions, clearance from the Dutch Ministry
of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy under the Dutch Telecommunication Act. Depending on the timing of
the satisfaction of the remaining closing conditions, we currently expect to complete the Acquisition by January
2022. Under the Acquisition Agreement, (i) in the event that the Completion Date does not take place by March
6, 2022, each of Deutsche Telekom and Tele2 Sweden (as Existing Shareholders and sellers under the
Acquisition Agreement) will have the right to terminate the Acquisition Agreement and (ii) in the event that the
Completion Date does not take place by July 6, 2022, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (as the purchaser) will
have the right to terminate the Acquisition Agreement.

The total consideration for the Acquisition due on the Completion Date, is expected to be financed on
such date using a portion of:

    - the Shareholder Contribution of an estimated amount of €1,090.0 million;

    - the TLB drawn under the Senior Facilities Agreement; and

    - the offering of the Notes.


-----

Prior to the Completion Date, the Issuers will not have any control over the Target Group. In addition,
prior to the completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group will not be subject to the covenants described in
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and the “Description of the Senior Notes.”

**The Sponsors**

**_Apax_**

Apax is a leading global private equity advisory firm. Over its 50-year history, Apax has raised and
advised funds with aggregate commitments of over $60 billion. Apax invests in companies across four global
sectors of Healthcare, Technology, Services and Internet/Consumer. These funds provide long-term equity
financing to build and strengthen world-class companies through leveraging its deep sector and sub-sector
experience, operating capabilities, and global platform. Some of Apax’s investments in the telecommunications
and allied sectors include, Inmarsat, Orange Switzerland, TDC, Wind Telecom, Mobifon, TIM Hellas, Kabel
Deutschland, Bezeq, Versatel.

**_Warburg Pincus_**

Warburg Pincus is a leading global growth investor and is an experienced partner to management
teams seeking to build durable companies with sustainable value. Founded in 1966, it has invested more than
$97 billion in over 960 companies across 40 countries, as of September 30, 2021. In particular, Warburg Pincus
has, over the years, invested over $3.3 billion of equity in the communication and media sector as of September
30, 2021 and possesses direct knowledge of the telecommunications industry’s end markets and customers
through its investments in other telecommunications companies. Some of Warburg Pincus’ investments in the
telecommunications and allied sectors include Inmarsat, Community Fibre, Ziggo, Airtel, United Internet,
IONOS by 1&1, Converge, INEA, inexio, Bharti and Amercia Net.

**_Financial Information of the Issuers_**

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer are newly formed entities incorporated
on July 20, 2021, in each case for purposes of facilitating the Transactions and performing certain activities
related thereto. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer
and, following the completion of the Acquisition, the Target will be a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuers have no revenuegenerating activities of their own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those
acquired or incurred in connection with their incorporation and the Transactions. As a result, no historical
financial information of the Issuers is included in this summary, except for certain limited “adjusted” financial
data presented on a consolidated basis, adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions and the use of
proceeds therefrom, including the impact on the cash position, the amount of debt and the interest expense of
the Group. The effects of purchase price accounting from the Acquisition have not yet been reflected in the
information presented, however, the Acquisition may have certain effects on our financial statements and may
impact our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows, which we are unable to determine
with certainty until after the Completion Date. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and
_Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and_
_assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and_
_affect our reported results of operations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Acquisition—We have made_
_certain assumptions relating to the Acquisition in forecasts that may prove to be materially inaccurate.”_

consolidated statement of cash flows of the Target Group presented herein are derived from (i) the audited
consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2019
and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as
adopted by the European Union and which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V.
(the “Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated interim
financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, including
the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial
Reporting (the “Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited
Consolidated Financial Statements, the “Historical Consolidated Financial Statements”).

The financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 in this Offering
Memorandum is derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Financial Statements”). The audited consolidated financial statements of the
Target Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 were originally approved by us on December 31,
2019. Thereafter, we have restated certain financial information as of and for the year ended December 31,
2018, included in the 2019 Financial Statements, by restating the classification of “other receivables” to “trade
receivables” for an amount of €619 thousand, “other payables” to “current other liabilities” for an amount of
€68,947 thousand, “non-current other liabilities” to “other liabilities” for an amount of €2,004 thousand, “other
receivables” to “other assets” for an amount of €32,629 thousand and “tax liabilities” to “liabilities held for
sale” for an amount of €1,792 thousand. These restatements do not have any impact on the reported profit for
the year 2018 or reported equity and an immaterial impact on the cash flow statement for 2018. As a result, we


-----

have not separately restated the financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018. See note
2.3 to the 2019 Financial Statements.

In addition, we also present certain financial information of the Target Group for the twelve months
ended September 30, 2021 (the “LTM Financial Information”). Except as otherwise stated, the LTM
Financial Information is derived by adding the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit
or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to the

Except as stated otherwise, the LTM Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our
financial reporting or in accordance with IFRS.

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) effective from January 1, 2019. As a result, leases (as lessee) that would
have been classified in previous periods as operating leases are recognized in our consolidated statement of
financial position as of December 31, 2019. Under the new standard, except for short-term or low-value leases,
the right to use a leased asset is recognized as an asset with a corresponding financial liability for the present
value of outstanding lease payments. Assets with a finite useful life are subject to impairment testing. We have
adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment
obligations from existing operating leases were discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and
recognized as a lease liability and the right-to-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of
the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments.

As a result of the application of new accounting standards and the associated impact on our Historical
Consolidated Financial Statements, prospective investors should exercise particular caution when comparing
our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 to our financial
condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial_
_statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may_
_cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations.” For a discussion of the_
effects of the adoption of IFRS 16 on our financial condition and results of operations, see “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability_
_of Our Results of Operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and note 2.4 to the 2019 Financial Statements._

After the completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group will not prepare separate consolidated
financial statements and we instead intend to report our consolidated financial results at the level of the Parent.
Due to this, our future financial statements may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial
statements included in this Offering Memorandum. Our future financial statements could be materially different
once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial
statements included in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Impacting Comparability—Reporting.”_

**Pro Forma Adjustments Related to the Tele2 and Simpel Acquisitions and T-Infra Demerger**

We completed the acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019 and the acquisition of Simpel on December
1, 2020. On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our
rented sites to a separate legal entity, T-Infra. T-Infra was transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019,
and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date. In this Offering Memorandum, we
present Pro Forma Net Revenue which is based on Tele2 and Simpel’s revenues for their respective preacquisition periods (adjusted for the estimated impact of IFRS 15 and IFRS 16) which are added to our revenue
and adjusted for certain management reclassifications. We also present in this Offering Memorandum, Pro
Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying RunRate EBITDA AcL which make certain adjustments to our EBITDA for the periods presented to take into
account the reported EBITDA contributions of Tele2 and Simpel for their respective pre-acquisition periods,
and eliminating the reported (negative) EBITDA of T-Infra (demerged business) for the relevant periods after

making certain intercompany adjustments based on management reclassifications and to exclude special factors
such as pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions,
as detailed in this Offering Memorandum.

IFRS 16, thereby including operating lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with
cash EBITDA.

believes are one-off and/or non-recurring items and (ii) removal costs related to the stock appreciation right (“SAR”) scheme
introduced by TMNL in 2017.
