secure debt ranking senior or equal in right of payment to the Senior Notes will be available to pay obligations
on the Senior Notes only after the aforementioned secured debt has been repaid in full from these assets. The
Senior Notes have limited security and there may not be sufficient assets remaining to pay amounts due on any
or all of the Senior Notes then outstanding. The Senior Notes Indenture will not prohibit us from incurring
additional secured debt, nor will it prohibit any of our subsidiaries from incurring additional liabilities. While
the Senior Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Guarantees will be

second lien indebtedness that is secured by the Shared Collateral.

**_The right of the holders of Senior Notes to receive payment under the Senior Notes Guarantees is_**
**_contractually subordinated to the senior debt of the Senior Notes Guarantors._**

The obligations of the Senior Notes Guarantors under their respective Senior Notes Guarantees (as

-----

will contain restrictions on the ability of the Senior Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Guarantors to incur

**_Pursuant to the distribution waterfall provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Shared Collateral will_**
**_secure the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and the obligations under the Senior_**

    - the Guarantor did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value or corporate

**_Dutch insolvency laws may provide you with less protection than bankruptcy laws of other jurisdictions you_**
**_are familiar with._**

The Issuers and the Guarantors are incorporated under the laws of The Netherlands. Accordingly,
insolvency proceedings with respect to such Issuers and the Guarantors would be likely to proceed under, and
be governed by, the laws of The Netherlands. Dutch insolvency laws are not identical to, and insolvency
outcomes may vary from, the laws of the United States or other jurisdictions with which investors are familiar.
In the event that any one or more of the Issuers or the Guarantors experiences financial difficulty, it is not
possible to predict with certainty the outcome of insolvency or similar proceedings or whether Dutch insolvency
laws would be favorable to your interests.

In the event that any one or more of the Issuers, the Guarantors or any future guarantors, if any, were
to experience financial difficulty, it is not possible to predict with certainty in which jurisdiction’s or
jurisdictions’ insolvency or similar proceedings would be commenced, or the outcome of such proceedings.
Any Guarantees and Collateral provided by entities organized in jurisdictions not discussed in this Offering
Memorandum are also subject to material limitations pursuant to their terms, by statute or otherwise. Any
enforcement of the Guarantees or security interests after bankruptcy or an insolvency event in such other
jurisdictions will be subject to the insolvency laws of the relevant entity’s jurisdiction of organization or other
jurisdictions. The insolvency and other laws of each of these jurisdictions may be materially different from, or
in conflict with, each other, including in the areas of rights of secured and other creditors, the ability to void
preferential transfer, priority of governmental and other creditors, ability to obtain post-petition interest and
duration of the proceeding. The application of these laws, or any conflict among them, could call into question
whether any particular jurisdiction’s laws should apply, adversely affect your ability to enforce your rights
under the Guarantees or the Collateral in these jurisdictions and limit any amounts that you may receive. See
“Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on Notes Guarantees and Security.”

**_We may not be able to obtain the funds required to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control._**

The Indentures contain provisions relating to certain events constituting a Change of Control (as
defined under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior
_Notes—Change of Control,” as applicable). Upon the occurrence of a change of control, we will be required to_
offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and
unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. If a change of control were to occur,
we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds available at such time, or that we would have
sufficient funds to provide to the Issuers to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Notes or that the
restrictions in the Indentures, the Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Facilities Agreement or our other thenexisting contractual obligations would allow us to make such required repurchases. A change of control may
result in a mandatory prepayment under the Senior Facilities Agreement. The exercise of the right of holders of
the Notes to require the repurchase of the Notes upon a change of control could cause a default under our debt
documents, even if the change of control itself does not. The ability of the Issuers to receive cash from entities
of our Group to allow them to pay cash to the holders of the Notes, following the occurrence of a change of
control, may be limited by our then-existing financial resources. Sufficient funds may not be available when
necessary to make any required repurchases. If an event constituting a change of control occurs at a time when
we are prohibited from providing funds to the Issuers for the purpose of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek
the consent of the lenders under such indebtedness to the purchase of the Notes or may attempt to refinance the
borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such borrowings is not obtained, the Issuers
will remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we cannot assure you that we would be able
to obtain third-party financing to refinance the borrowings that contain such prohibition or make an offer to
repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. Any failure by the Issuers to offer to purchase the Notes would
constitute a default under the Indentures, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the Senior Facilities
Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior
_Notes—Change of Control.”_

Further, if pursuant to a Change of Control Offer, holders of not less than 90% of the aggregate
principal amount of the then-outstanding Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes (as the case may be) validly
tender and do not withdraw such Notes, the Indentures will permit the relevant Issuer, at its option, to redeem
the remaining outstanding Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes (as the case may be) at a price of 101% of the
principal amount of such Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest. As a consequence, holders of the Notes may
be required to surrender the Notes against their will at a price equivalent to that paid to tendering holders and
may not receive the return expected.

The change of control provisions contained in the Indentures may not necessarily afford you protection
in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring, merger or other
similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve
a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a Change of Control (as
defined under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior
_Notes—Change of Control,” as the case may be). Except as described under “Description of the Senior Secured_
_Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Change of Control,” the Indentures do not_
contain provisions that would require the Issuers to offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a
reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or similar transaction. Additionally, there are certain
exceptions to the definition of “Change of Control” which allow changes in the ownership of the relevant Issuer
if certain conditions are satisfied, including if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded
in connection with such Change of Control on one occasion.

In the event the Parent is sold to a new investor, whether or not such sale constitutes a change of control
under the Indentures, no assurance can be given that any such investor will continue to implement our current
business and financial strategy.

The definition of “Change of Control” in the Indentures include a disposition of all or substantially all
of the assets of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries, taken as a whole, to any person. Although there is a
limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no precise established
definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of
uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of all or substantially all of the


-----

Parent’s and its restricted subsidiaries’ assets, taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a
change of control has occurred and whether the Issuers are required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes.

**_Dutch withholding tax may be due on (deemed) payments of interest under the Notes._**

Dutch withholding tax (at a rate equal to the highest Dutch corporate income tax rate) may be due on
(actual or deemed) payments of interest (including guarantee payments) under the Notes due by (verschuldigd
_door) any Issuer, Guarantor or future issuer or guarantor incorporated or organized under the laws of the_
Netherlands or otherwise tax resident, or with a taxable presence, in the Netherlands (the “Dutch
**Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021**
(Wet bronbelasting 2021) in case the relevant Dutch Issuer/Guarantor is related (gelieerd) (within the meaning
set out below) to the entity entitled to such (Deemed) Payments (voordeelgerechtigde) and:

    - such related recipient entity (i) is (deemed) resident in a low tax jurisdiction (laagbelastende
_jurisdictie) or (ii) has a permanent establishment in such low tax jurisdiction to which the interest_
(or guarantee payment) is allocated (worden toegerekend);

    - the related recipient entity is not (deemed) resident in a low tax jurisdiction, in case (a) such entity
is entitled to the (Deemed) Payments with the main purpose or one of the main purposes of
avoiding withholding tax in the hands of another person or entity, and (b) there is an artificial
arrangement or transaction, or a series of artificial arrangements or transactions. An arrangement
or transaction, or series of arrangements or transactions, shall be regarded as artificial to the extent
that it is not put into place for valid commercial reasons, which reflect economic reality; and/or

    - the related entity is from a Dutch tax perspective regarded the recipient of the (Deemed)
Payments, whereas such related recipient entity is not regarded as the recipient (gerechtigde)
thereof pursuant to the laws of the country in which such entity is (deemed) resident or pursuant
to the laws of which such entity is established (opgericht).

No additional amounts shall be payable with respect to any Note in relation to the withholding or
deduction for or on account of any tax imposed or to be withheld in the Netherlands pursuant to The Netherlands
Withholding Tax Act 2021. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes” and
“Description of the Senior Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

_Related entities_

Generally, a holder of notes is considered to be related to a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor for these purposes
if (i) it has a qualifying interest in a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor, (ii) a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor has a qualifying
interest in such party, or (iii) a third party has a qualifying interest in both a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor and such
party. For these purposes, a party is equated with any collaborating group of parties of which it forms part. A
qualifying interest is an interest that allows the holder to have a decisive influence over the other party’s
decisions, in such a way that it is able to determine the activities of the other party. A party is in any case
considered to have a qualifying interest in another party if it (directly or indirectly) owns more than 50% of the
voting rights in such other party.

_Low tax jurisdictions_

A jurisdiction qualifies as a low tax jurisdiction for purposes of The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act
2021 if it is listed in an annually updated ministerial decree published by the Dutch government which includes
jurisdictions (i) with a profit tax applying a statutory rate of less than 9% (updated annually based on an
assessment as of October 1 of the preceding year) or (ii) included on the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions
in the preceding year.

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the_**
**_relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

The Notes will initially only be issued in global certificated form and held through Euroclear and
Clearstream. Interests in the global Notes will trade in book-entry form only, and Notes in definitive registered
form, or definitive registered Notes, will be issued in exchange for book entry interests only in very limited
circumstances. Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes unless and
until definitive notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, the common depositary (or its
nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes in global form.

Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form
will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, such
payments will be credited to participants’ accounts of Euroclear and Clearstream that hold book-entry interests
in the Notes in global form and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the
common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, none of the Issuers, the Guarantors, the Trustees, the Paying
Agent, any other paying agent or any registrar will have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the
records relating to or payments of interest, principal or other amounts to Euroclear and Clearstream, as
applicable, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a book-entry interest in the Notes,
you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream, and, if you are not a participant in Euroclear
and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any
rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indentures.

Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents
or requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes, including enforcement of security for the
Notes and the Guarantees. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be reliant on the common
depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream (as registered holder of the applicable Notes) to act on your
instructions and/or will be permitted to act directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to
do so from Euroclear and Clearstream, or, if applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that
procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any
requested actions or to take any other action on a timely basis.

**_There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes may be_**
**_limited._**

We cannot assure you as to:

    - the liquidity of any market in the Notes;

    - your ability to sell your Notes; or

    - the prices at which you would be able to sell your Notes.

Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among others, prevailing
interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for noninvestment grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices
of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by
a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in
prices. The trading market for the Notes may attract different investors and this may affect the extent to which
the Notes may trade. It is possible that the market for the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such
disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial
performance. As a result, there is no assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Notes. If no
active trading market develops, you may not be able to resell your holding of the Notes at a fair value, if at all.

Although an application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the
Notes on the Official List of the Exchange, we cannot assure you that the Notes will be or remain listed.
Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of the permission to deal in the Notes
on the Official List of the Exchange being granted, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting (whether
or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Notes, as applicable, from the
Official List of the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Notes, as applicable,
in the secondary market.

In addition, the Indentures allow us to issue additional notes in the future, which could adversely
impact the liquidity of the Notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Additional Notes” and
“Description of the Senior Notes—Additional Notes.”

**_The interests of the holders of the Notes and additional notes issued under the Indentures from time to time_**
**_may be inconsistent._**

The Senior Secured Notes will be issued pursuant to the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, and the
Senior Notes will be issued pursuant to the Senior Notes Indenture. Subject to certain restrictions, further series
of additional notes may be issued under the Indentures which may have different terms in respect of currency,
interest rate and certain other matters. Accordingly, holders of such additional notes may have interests that
differ from the holders of other series of notes issued under the Indentures, including the Notes. However,
holders of such additional notes will generally vote as a single class with holders of other series of notes issued
under the relevant Indenture, including the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes (as the case may be), with
respect to amendments, waivers or other modifications of the relevant Indenture. Accordingly, to the extent any
amendment, waiver or modification is approved by the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of
the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes (as the case may be) then outstanding under the relevant Indenture
(subject to the limited exceptions), all holders of Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes (as the case may be)
under the relevant Indenture will be bound by such amendment, waiver or modification.

**_The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws._**

The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or
the securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in
the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration
requirements of the Securities Act and the applicable securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction. See


-----

“Transfer Restrictions.” It is the obligation of holders of the Notes to ensure that their offers and sales of the
Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws.

**_Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations._**

The Issuers and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are organized outside the United
States, and the business of such entities organized outside the United States is conducted outside the United
States. The majority of the directors and executive officers of the Issuers and the Guarantors organized outside
the United States are non-residents of the United States. Although the Issuers and the Guarantors will submit to
the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws or under
the Indentures, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on those directors and
executive officers of the Issuers and the Guarantors outside the United States. In addition, because the majority
of the assets of the Issuers and Guarantors and the assets of their directors and executive officers are located
outside of the United States, your ability to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S. courts will be
limited. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuers and the
Guarantors may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States.
See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

**_The Indentures will not be qualified under the TIA._**

The Indentures with respect to the Notes offered hereby are not required to be, nor will they be,
qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or
include or be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of the Notes will not be
entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified
indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the Trustees or conflicting interests of the
Trustees. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes.”

**_Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. An investment in the Notes denominated in a
currency other than the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments will entail
foreign exchange related risks due to, among others, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative
to other relevant currencies because of economic, political or other factors over which we have no control.
Depreciation of the euro against other relevant currencies could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the
Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated
into the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments. In addition, an investment
in the Notes by U.S. investors may have significant tax consequences. See “Certain Tax Considerations—
_Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_

**_Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be_**
**_fungible with existing Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for United States federal income_**
**_tax purposes._**

Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time
may be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the
applicable series of Notes previously issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes
Indenture, as applicable, without being fungible with such series of Notes for United States federal income tax
purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined in “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal
_Income Tax Considerations.”) considering the purchase of Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes sold pursuant_
to Regulation S as part of this offering of Senior Secured Notes and Senior Notes or in the secondary market,
you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular United States federal income tax consequences
to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such series of Notes, including with respect to the potential
issuance of Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes that are not fungible with the applicable
series of initial Notes issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes Indenture, as
applicable, for United States federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being

**Overview**

Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network
operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid)
and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our
customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile
service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for
the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The
_2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by_
_Umlaut)._

As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers,
representing an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For
the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our
combined mobile service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled
€391 million, and our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million.
Mobile service revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming,
and our fixed line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as
fixed line wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions
and other adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was
€292 million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was
€637.4 million.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

Our operations and the operating metrics discussed below have been, and may continue to be, affected
by certain key factors as well as certain historical events and actions. The key factors affecting the ordinary
course of our business and our results of operations are discussed below.

**_Mobile and Fixed Subscriber Base_**

Mobile subscribers consist of subscribers for voice services (including incoming and outgoing calls),
SMS and MMS services, and mobile broadband services (smartphones, wireless internet access through a
laptop, tablet, wireless router or dongle). Fixed subscribers consist of subscribers for FTTH or xDSL broadband
services through one of our fixed line services, TV or telephony packages, as well as other business and
Wholesale Services such as “fiber to the office” services. The evolution of our mobile and fixed subscriber
bases is, and in the periods under review was, driven by market dynamics (including regulatory environment,
competition-driven price evolution, demographics, technological innovation and changing customer behavior),
our ability to capture new subscribers and retain existing subscribers, our acquisitions, and macroeconomic
conditions. See “—Macroeconomic Developments and the Impact of COVID-19 in The Netherlands” and “Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our business is concentrated in The Netherlands, and_
_may be adversely affected by negative economic, legal or political developments in The Netherlands.” A larger_
subscriber base generally results in higher revenue, as the number of our revenue-generating customers
increases. In addition, as a substantial portion of our costs are fixed, a larger subscriber base produces certain
relative cost savings, as efficiencies of scale in our network reduce the costs per customer of delivering our
services and providing customer support. With the acquisition of Tele2 in January 2019 and Simpel in
December 2020, we have substantially increased our subscriber base by covering all consumer segments of the
B2C postpaid market, particularly by offering the full range of premium to low budget products, which we
believe strengthened our position as the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer
market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs.

We divide our mobile subscriber base primarily into postpaid and prepaid B2C mobile and postpaid
B2B mobile. In particular, we expect the Dutch B2C mobile postpaid market, which is a key segment of growth
for us, to expand due to growth in postpaid SIMs, driven by prepaid to postpaid migration, increasing use of
second SIMs, population growth and an increased prevalence of younger generations using mobiles phones at
an early age. Similarly, we expect our B2B mobile market to grow across the three main segments: SOHO/VSE,
SMB and LE/CE. Postpaid SIMs are counted in our subscriber base as long as they have an active contract and
prepaid SIMs are counted in our subscriber base as long as a SIM card is connected to our network which has
had at least one chargeable event or incoming traffic event (excluding any traffic initiated by us) within the last
six months. The calculation includes subscribers through wholesale resellers, as we enter into direct contractual
arrangements with customers of resellers, but excludes subscribers through MVNOs, as MVNOs own their
respective subscriber bases. Each connection by a subscriber represents at least one line; however, this may
vary depending on circumstances, and one subscriber may have several lines (for instance, a broadband line,
together with two postpaid lines). We expect our fixed subscriber base to grow due to a household growth,
further FTTH penetration in The Netherlands and better quality. In this regard, in April 2021, we announced a
strategic partnership with Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP, to roll-out fiber services
to over one million homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on the network, which focuses on dense, urban
areas in which we currently have a large mobile market share.

**_Multi-brand Strategy to Address Different Customer Segments with Tailored Value Propositions_**

Our multi-brand strategy has allowed us to grow across all customer segments in The Netherlands by
offering different value propositions across key consumer distribution channels. We operate under the TMobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands and each of our brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated
profiles. We position our T-Mobile brand as a premium brand, our Tele2 brand as a value brand and Ben and
Simpel as budget brands. We are the market leader across the entire spectrum with a 42% market share in the
B2C mobile based on our number of postpaid SIM subscribers. We combine strong remote direct sales through
our branded websites and mobile platforms with both our own and third-party call centers, complemented by a
large physical retail network of exclusive stores and distributors. In 2020, our direct and indirect online channels
accounted for more than 60% of our B2C sales. We leverage these channels to offer our customers a range of
service options tailored to their needs through both bundled and flexible unbundled packages, offering
predictable pricing, a strong portfolio of digital channels and customer experience. Our customer services for
Ben and T-Mobile have been voted number one and number two, respectively, in the Dutch telecommunications
industry (Source: MarketResponse). In 2020, Umlaut ranked us as the best mobile network in The Netherlands
for the fifth year in a row, and in 2021, they also ranked us first in their global ranking of all network providers.

From 2018 to 2020, we have increased our market share in the mobile services market from 23.8% to
42.0%, respectively, consistently capturing a large majority of market net adds supported by our acquisitions
of Tele2 and Simpel. Our success in the mobile services market has been driven by our focused commercial
strategy and customer led-approach, allowing us to significantly outperform the Dutch mobile market generally.
Similarly, our market share in the B2C fixed broadband market by subscriber grew from 4.7% in 2018 to 5.7%
in 2020, facilitated by our expanding and improving network footprint. This substantial increase in net adds,
combined with the attractive underlying fundamentals of the Dutch telecommunications market, has resulted in
an overall increase of our mobile subscriber base at a CAGR of 4.5% from 2018 to 2020 and an increase in our
fixed residential broadband subscriber base at a CAGR of 11.5% over the same period.

**_Bundled Offerings, Cross-selling and Migration of Postpaid Subscribers to FMC and Multiple Lines_**

The competitive landscape in The Netherlands is generally characterized by tiered offerings that
include lower priced entry-level products and a focus on bundled offerings, including special promotions and
discounts for customers who subscribe for bundled services and, more recently and as a future trend to take into
consideration, offerings for access to services under 5G networks. Our main competitors offer integrated
products over their fixed line and/or cable networks, including fixed-mobile services bundles comprising
mobile, fixed voice and broadband internet products, as well as 4P bundles that combine these three products
with television services. Bundled services are expected to remain important and customers that have such
services are less likely to switch to a different operator for all or part of the bundled services. We have used and
will continue to use bundled offerings and value added services to attract new customers, and to migrate existing
customers to additional services, by cross-selling broadband to our existing mobile subscriber base and
upselling higher value packages. During the periods under review we have focused our efforts on cross-selling
FMC services and second and third lines to postpaid subscribers, providing discounts to postpaid mobile and
fixed subscribers if they sign up for a bundled offering including FMC services and multiple mobile lines.

**_Material New Subsidiaries, Joint Ventures, Acquisitions and Other Arrangements_**

_Demerger of T-Infra_

On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our
rented sites into a separate legal entity, namely Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021 known
as T-Mobile Infra B.V.). Cignal Infrastructure was thereafter transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1,
2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date, with TMNL continuing to
have full access to the contributed infrastructure through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June
2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP a joint venture of
Cellnex and DTCP, and subsequently it was transferred to Cellnex Netherlands B.V. Currently, we benefit from
access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for
an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10
years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price
Index.

_Acquisition of Tele2 and Simpel_

In January 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2. The acquisition has strengthened our position
in the Dutch telecommunications market, particularly in the premium mobile segment, allowing us to compete
more effectively with our competitors in the Dutch market, due to enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources
and significant synergy potential. Pursuant to this acquisition, we acquired approximately 1.2 million
subscribers, as of January 2, 2019.

On December 1, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, the largest MVNO in The Netherlands.
This has helped to further consolidate our leading position in the mobile market and expand into a low budget
segment of the Dutch mobile market. Pursuant to this acquisition, we acquired approximately 1.0 million
subscribers, who at the time of the acquisition already used our network pursuant to a network access
arrangement that Simpel had previously entered into with us.

We are executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have
closed Tele2’s standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings.
Based on our estimates, we anticipate realizing total cost-saving synergies in connection with Tele2 and Simpel
with a total run-rate synergy potential of €139 million by 2024, having already realized €116 million of
synergies run-rate as of September 30, 2021. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel include reduced
interconnect costs, migration of Tele2’s BSS to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad debt collections
(representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon integration with TMNL),
direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and the cancellation of leased
telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile cross-selling, optimization
of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related costs as well as legal audit
and tax fees.

**_Capital Expenditure and Network Upgrades_**

Our historical capital expenditure is mainly driven by the acquisition of licenses of frequency spectra,
which occur every eight to ten years and are a necessary capital expenditure for our mobile network. These
frequencies are auctioned by the Dutch government and are generally valid for 15 to 20 years, after which the
licenses are put up for auction again. The first 5G frequencies were auctioned in mid-2020 and we were able to
acquire bands on the 700 MHz and 1,400 MHz frequencies for the first time as well as re-acquire our previouslyowned 2,100 MHz spectrum. As of December 31, 2020, we had the largest mobile spectrum portfolio in The
Netherlands, ranging from low frequency (700 MHz) to high frequency (2,600 MHz), with no reinvestment
required until 2030. We intend to participate in the new 3.5 GHz spectrum auction, which is currently expected
in the second half of 2022.

Our business capital expenditure primarily consists of Mobile Capital Expenditure (which represents
capital expenditure relating to expansion and/or improvement of our mobile network infrastructure and is
calculated as the sum of capital expenditure relating to (i) modernization of RAN to ensure full 5G capabilities


-----

and the roll-out of low frequency 5G-ready bands and (ii) other expansion or improvement of our mobile
network, such as in relation to quality improvement and network evolution projects and capital expenditure to
increase capacity), Fixed Capital Expenditure (which represents capital expenditure necessary to maintain and
expand our fixed infrastructure, and is primarily related to (i) capacity extension and upgrades of our fixed
infrastructure, (ii) investments in active equipment in new roll-out areas, (iii) customer-premise equipment for
new customers and (iv) quality improvements and phase out of legacy networks). IT Capital Expenditure (which
represents capital expenditure relating to the ongoing IT transformation and our cloud-first strategy) and Other
Capital Expenditure (which represents certain other heads of capital expenditures incurred by us, such as in
relation to the acquisition and post-acquisition integration related capital expenditure as well as certain other
miscellaneous heads of capital expenditure such as in relation building facilities and retail outlets). During the
last three financial years, we have spent in the aggregate €337.4 million as Mobile Capital Expenditure (€79.7
million in 2018, €143.0 million in 2019, €114.7 million in 2020). We spent in the aggregate €166.4 million as
Fixed Capital Expenditure (€22.3 million in 2018, €64.5 million in 2019, €79.6 million in 2020). In addition,
we spent in the aggregate €124.9 million as IT Capital Expenditure (€41.6 million in 2018, €44.6 million in

**_Macroeconomic Developments and the Impact of COVID-19 in The Netherlands_**

As we operate entirely in The Netherlands, our business and results of operations are influenced by
macroeconomic developments in the Dutch economy. To the extent they relate to and influence rates of
consumer confidence and spending in The Netherlands, rates of Dutch unemployment, GDP growth and other
macroeconomic metrics can impact the amount of money that Dutch consumers spend on our products and
services and thus impact our sales and results of operations. GDP growth and other economic metrics may also
correlate with rates of business investment in The Netherlands, and can thus impact our sales to business
customers. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Dutch GDP increased by 1.96% in 2019, continuing its
process of gradual deceleration from the average GDP growth rate of 2.4% from 2016-2018, but still
significantly higher than the average GDP growth rate of 1.1% during the period from 2013-2015. Additionally,
the inflation rate was on average 2.6% in 2019, well above from 1.1% in 2016-2018 and from 1.4% in 20132015.

Since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, governments of many countries, including The
Netherlands, have taken preventative measures to try to contain its spread. These measures have included
mandatory closure of businesses, social distancing requirements and travel restrictions, which have severely
diminished the level of economic activity around the world and in The Netherlands, caused significant volatility


-----

in financial markets and triggered a period of global economic slowdown, the extent and duration of which
remain uncertain. The COVID-19 pandemic and the multiple waves of infections that have been recorded have
severely impacted the economies of the European Union, including The Netherlands. In particular, the World
Bank registered a contraction for the European Union’s real GDP of 5.9% in 2020 and forecasts deeper
continuing impacts on those economies dependent on international tourism as well as those dependent on
international trade, as supply bottlenecks persist (Source: World Bank, Global Economic Prospects January
_2021; June 2021). In The Netherlands, employment and working hours were negatively impacted, with the_
unemployment rate increasing by 1.9% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2020 and total working hours
bottoming out at an aggregate loss of 7.7 average weekly hours in May of 2020 (Source: Institute of Labor
_Economics, Drivers of Working Hours and Household Income Dynamics during the COVID-19 Pandemic: The_
_Case of The Netherlands). COVID-19 caseload waves and concomitant containment measures were associated_
with exceptional declines in consumer spending in two waves in 2020, reaching 17% and 12% declines in
consumer spending year-over-year in April and December of 2020, respectively (Source: Statistics
_Netherlands). Eurostat has registered a contraction of the Dutch economy of 3.7% in 2020 (source: Eurostat)._
However, due to a steady vaccination drive and the resulting stimulation in economic activity, consumption and
public confidence, the OECD has projected a steady rebound of the Dutch economy in 2021, with a projected
GDP growth of 3.5% in 2021. For 2022, the OECD has currently forecast a growth of 3.0%. The annual average
unemployment rate is expected to be 4.12% in 2021 and 4.66% in 2022. (Source: OECD).

In response to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, on March 16, 2020 we temporarily closed all of
our retail shops, and thereafter, beginning March 21, 2020 and in compliance with regulations and guidance
issued by the Dutch government, we gradually reopened some of our retail shops in a ‘box-in shop’ format,
whereby our retail shops were installed with Plexiglas walls enabling our employees and consumers to safely
interact with each other. In June 2020, we reopened the entirety of our retail shops while implementing social
distancing measures. On December 15, 2020, the Dutch government ordered the closure of all non-essential
commercial and retail businesses in The Netherlands and, in compliance with this directive, we closed all of
our retail shops for sale while remaining open for service as it qualified as essential services. In April 2021, we
progressively reopened our retail stores while requiring certain social distancing and other safety measures to
be observed.

In addition, the self-isolation measures imposed by the Dutch government in order to combat COVID19 have resulted in a considerable increase in internet traffic, as customers increasingly relied on VoIP and OTT
services while gatherings are prohibited and residents are advised to stay at home. The COVID-19 pandemic
positively impacted our B2B segment, as people worked remotely, leading to an increase in calls, data usage,
video-conferencing and other services requested by business customers. However, COVID-19 pandemic had a
negative impact on our roaming revenues due to travel restrictions imposed on our customers by many countries
and territories around the world meant that mobile roaming remained limited during this period. Our networks
continue to be stable and we believe are able to cope well with the additional volume caused by increased
numbers of people working from home.

**Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations**

**_Acquisitions and Demerger and other Arrangements_**

We have made two material acquisitions during the periods under review. The assets and operations
acquired in such transactions are not fully reflected across all periods that are included in our Historical
Consolidated Financial Statements. We also undertook a material demerger of infrastructure assets during this
period. The impact of these acquisitions as well as the demerger should be taken into account when comparing
the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements across the periods included therein.

These acquisitions and the demerger consist of the following, in chronological order:

    - on September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of
our rented sites to a separate legal entity, Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021,
T-Infra). Subsequently, Cignal Infrastructure was transferred to Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V.
on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date;


-----

    - on January, 2, 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2’s Dutch operations, and it has been
consolidated into our financial results from that date;

    - on December 1, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, and it has been consolidated into
our financial results from that date.

Following the Acquisition, our business operations will be separated from Deutsche Telekom and run
as a stand-alone business. In this regard, and at the time of completion of the Acquisition, we expect to enter
into certain transitional services agreements, including with Tele2. As a result of the separation, we do not
expect our cost base to change materially. In addition, going forward our business would not avail of financing
from the Deutsche Telekom, and we expect to fulfil our liquidity requirements mainly from net cash generated
from operating activities, the Notes, drawings under the Senior Facilities Agreement (including the RCF) and
the factoring arrangements entered into by us from time to time. Pursuant to our separation from Deutsche
Telekom, we expect to be able to streamline our reporting and management information systems and expect to
achieve certain related efficiencies. See also “Business— Separation from Deutsche Telekom” and “Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Separation from Deutsche Telekom.”_

**_Seasonality_**

We regularly experience a slight seasonality in postpaid mobile revenue during two quarters, as
described below, while seasonality is fairly low for our other services:

    - _First Quarter. Revenue in the first quarter is generally less compared to the following quarters in_
the financial year due to the fact that this quarter has one to two less days than the second and the
fourth quarter. This only affects customers in pay-per-use voice tariffs.

    - _Third Quarter. Some revenue uplift is linked to the growth of out of bundle usage by postpaid_
mobile lines, due to customers leaving their regular residence and place of work where they have
access to broadband and Wi-Fi, whereas they tend to have more limited access to Wi-Fi on
vacation, increasing their data usage. This mostly affects customers having tariffs with a low data
allowance and prepaid mobile lines.

**_Adoption of IFRS 16_**

The mandatory first-time application of the new the IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective
from January 1, 2019, had a material impact on our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Since expenses
and cash outflows for leases are substantial elements of our earnings performance and solvency, we have taken
into account the effects of IFRS 16 (Leases) when determining our financial performance indicators. On
September 1, 2018, we demerged Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra), consisting
primarily of passive infrastructure and site lease agreements, and subsequently transferred the entity as a
dividend in kind to Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. on January 1, 2019. After the demerger, we entered into a
lease agreement with Cignal Infrastructure regarding the demerged passive infrastructure and sites. As of
January 1, 2019, the passive equipment previously carried at cost and the right of use assets related to the
greenfield and rooftop spaces, each of which were previously accounted as indirect costs, are now accounted
as leases under IFRS 16. In order to ensure maximum comparability with our previous performance indicators,
we measure our operational performance on the basis of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, which is calculated
as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude the impact of IFRS 16, thereby including operating
lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with cash EBITDA.

**_Reporting_**

We present the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements in this Offering Memorandum. After
completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group may not prepare separate consolidated financial statements
and we instead may report our consolidated financial results at the level of the Parent. Due to this, our future
financial statements may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included
in this Offering Memorandum. Our future financial statements could be materially different once the


-----

adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements
included in this Offering Memorandum.

**Key Income Statement Items**

**_Net revenue_**

Net revenue relates to all revenues from the ordinary business activities of the Target Group, including
revenue from rendering of mobile telecommunication services, revenue from the sales of goods and
merchandise and revenue from the rendering of fixed line services. Revenues are recorded net of value-added
tax and other taxes collected from customers. Value-added tax and other taxes collected are remitted to
governmental authorities.

**_Other operating income_**

Other operating income relates to income from intercompany charges and miscellaneous other
operating income such as charge back to shareholders for employees on the Target Group’s payroll and gain in
fair value of assets.

**_Own capitalized costs_**

Own capitalized costs represents capitalization of workforce cost relating to roll out and capacity
expansions in our mobile and fixed network and the development of platforms for cellular sites.

**_Goods and services purchased_**

Goods and services purchased relates to expenses for raw materials and supplies, merchandise and for
services purchased, such as cost of handset devices, fixed access services, roaming costs for mobile subscribers,
marketing and sales costs and commission, and costs relating to energy and logistics.

**_Personnel costs_**

Personnel costs relate to salaries and wages, social security contributions, pensions and other employee
benefits.

**_Net impairment gains/losses on financial assets_**

Net impairment gains/losses on financial assets includes impairment gains/losses relating to trade
receivables and contract assets and provisions relating to bad debt.

**_Other operating expenses_**

Other operating expenses include legal, consulting and audit fees, claims, expenses recorded due to
recognition of provisions, proceeds from sale of receivables to debt collection agencies and miscellaneous other
operating expenses.

**_EBITDA_**

EBITDA corresponds to EBIT (earnings before interest and tax) before depreciation, amortization and
impairment losses.

**_Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses_**

Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses include amortization and impairment of intangible
assets, depreciation and impairment of property, plant and equipment and depreciation right of use assets.

**_Profit from operations (EBIT)_**

Profit from operations (EBIT) includes earnings before interest and tax.


-----

**_Net finance income/costs_**

Net finance income/costs are calculated as interest income less interest expense.

**_Other financial income/expense_**

Other financial income/expense includes gain/losses from foreign currency. The gain/losses consist of
gain on foreign currencies and losses due to measurement of provisions.

**_Gain/(Loss) from other financial activities_**

Gains/(Loss) from other financial activities includes gains and losses from foreign currency and
measurement of provisions.

**_Net finance (expense)/income_**

Net finance (expense)/income is our net finance cost adjusted for loss from other financial activities.

**_Profit/(Loss) before income tax_**

Profit/(Loss) before income tax is calculated as operating profit less financial results and results from
equity-consolidated investments.

**_Income taxes_**

Income taxes include both our current and deferred income tax. Current tax assets or liabilities are
measured at the amount expected to be paid to or recovered from the taxation authorities, using the tax rates
and tax laws that have been enacted or substantially enacted at the reporting date. Current or deferred corporate
income tax is recognized in our condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive
income unless it arises from a transaction or economic event that has been recognized in the same year or in a
different year against equity or from a business combination.

_Net revenue_

Net revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €1,536.5 million, an increase of €89.7
million, or 6.2%, compared to €1,446.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due
to the acquisition of Simpel, which was completed on December 1, 2020. Accordingly, revenue from Simpel
was consolidated with our results for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 (contributing €88.0 million),
whereas our results for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 did not consolidate any revenue from Simpel.
In addition, the increase in net revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 as compared to the nine
months ended September 30, 2020, was, among other things, due to the increase in the subscriber base of our
T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile operations and our B2C fixed operations.

Net revenue for our B2C segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €1,213.2 million,
an increase of €136.3 million, or 12.7%, compared to €1,076.9 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Simpel resulting in a larger customer base, an increase in ARPU
for the B2C segment during the nine months ended September 30, 2021, and the increase in subscriber base in
relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile operations and our B2C fixed operations.

Net revenue for our B2B segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €268.1 million,
a decrease of €4.2 million, or 1.6%, compared to €263.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020,
primarily due to growth in subscriber base in our B2B segment during these periods, partially offset by a
decrease in the ARPU for the B2B segment during the nine months ended September 30, 2021 (€13.0 per month,
calculated on an historical basis) as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020 (€13.7 per month,
calculated on an historical basis), driven by an increase in the mix of LE/CE customer segment, which has
historically generated a relatively lower ARPU.

Net revenue for our other segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €55.1 million,
a decrease of €50.8 million, or 48.0%, compared to €106.0 million for the nine months ended September 30,
2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Simpel. Prior to completion of this acquisition and during the nine
months ended September 30, 2020, Simpel was the largest MVNO in The Netherlands and we shared our
network with Simpel against payment of network access fees, which were recorded as other income. Upon
completion of the acquisition of Simpel, such network access arrangements were terminated and no network
access fees from Simpel were recorded during the nine months ended September 30, 2021.

_Other operating income_

Other operating income for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €0.4 million, a decrease
of €2.6 million, or 86.7% compared to €3.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily
due to the fact that indemnification assets relating to “all-in subscriptions” contract claims was recognized
during the nine months September 30, 2020 (€1.7 million).

These claims relate to our prior and discontinued offer of ‘free handsets’ to consumers along with
mobile subscriptions, referred to as ‘all-in subscriptions.’ In 2014 and 2016, the Supreme Court of The
Netherlands ruled that such offerings were not compliant with statutory provisions on installment purchases,
credit transactions and credit agreements. In this regard, multiple claims vehicles and foundations have solicited
individuals to initiate mass claims against telecommunications providers who offered such all-in subscriptions,
and as a result, we have recognized provisions in our financial statements for potential payout of these claims.
Individual consumers were able to file their potential claim until September 1, 2019, and pursuant to an
agreement reached by us in October 2020 with a joint venture organization, we have finalized processing claims
from this organization as of date while others are still pending. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to


-----

_Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We face risks arising from the outcome of various criminal, civil,_
_administrative and regulatory proceedings.”_

_Own capitalized costs_

Own capitalized costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €15.7 million, an increase
of €2.2 million, or 16.3%, compared to €13.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily
due to capitalization of increased workforce costs relating to internalization of certain technology management
functions, which were previous carried out by an external vendor.

_Goods and services purchased_

Goods and services purchased for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €851.1 million, an

_Personnel costs_

_Net impairment losses on financial assets_

Net impairment losses on financial assets for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €16.2

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €16.2 million, a

2021

_Net revenue_

Net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €1,914.9 million, an increase of €594.3 million,
or 45.0%, compared to €1,320.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the acquisition
of Tele2, which was completed on January 2, 2019. Accordingly, revenue from Tele2 was consolidated with
our results for the year ended December 31, 2019 (contributing €597.0 million), whereas our results for the year
ended December 31, 2018 did not consolidate revenue from Tele2. In addition, the increase in net revenue for
year ended December 31, 2019, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2018, was, among other things,
due to the increase in our subscriber base in relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile
operations and T-Mobile Thuis brand in our B2C fixed operations, partially offset by a slight decrease in our
B2C Mobile postpaid ARPU during the same period (from €17.6 per month during the year ended December
31, 2018 to €17.2 per month during the year ended December 31, 2019, in each case calculated on an historical
basis and excluding the impact of the Tele2 B2C Mobile postpaid ARPU).

Net revenue for our B2C segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €1,426.0 million, an
increase of €477.9 million, or 50.4%, compared to €948.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This
increase was primarily due to our acquisition of Tele2 resulting in a larger customer base (an addition of
approximately 1.2 million subscribers, as of January 2, 2019 and a revenue of €336.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019) and the increase in subscriber base in relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C


-----

mobile operations and T-Mobile Thuis brand in our B2C fixed operations, partially offset by a slight decrease
in our B2C mobile postpaid ARPU during the same period, as described above.

Net revenue for our B2B segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €404.7 million, an
increase of €151.1 million, or 59.6%, compared to €253.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018
primarily due to our acquisition of Tele2 resulting in a larger customer base, partially offset by a decrease in
our B2B mobile ARPU during the same period (from €18.4 per month during the year ended December 31,
2018 to €15.1 per month during the year ended December 31, 2019, in each case calculated on an historical
basis and excluding the impact of the Tele2 B2B mobile ARPU for the relevant period).

Net revenue for our other segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €84.3 million, a decrease
of €34.7 million, or 29.1%, compared to €118.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 primarily due to
the elimination of certain revenue streams from Tele2, such as in relation to handset revenue and interconnection
charges, which we gradually eliminated pursuant to the acquisition of Tele2 in January 2, 2019.

_Other operating income_

Other operating income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €2.0 million, a decrease of €8.4
million, or 80.7%, compared to €10.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a decrease
in miscellaneous other operating income, driven by the demerger of T-Infra, which became effective on January
1, 2019 and resulted in elimination of site income from the other MNOs who previously used the demerged
assets, partially offset by our acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019, which resulted in a release of certain
provisions relating to network sharing with Tele2.

_Own capitalized costs_

Own capitalized costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €16.9 million, an increase of €7.7
million, or 83.7%, compared to €9.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily driven by the
Tele2 acquisition and the resulting increase in capitalization of increased workforce costs.

_Goods and services purchased_

Goods and services purchased for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €1,109.4 million, an
increase of €328.1 million, or 42.0%, compared to €781.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to the acquisition of Tele2 and the consequent increase in our subscriber base which increased
our goods and services purchased and an increase in our rental and leasing costs pursuant to the demerger of TInfra.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €173.2 million, an increase of €69.5
million, or 67.0%, compared to €103.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an
increase in salaries and wages (€59.3 million) and an increase in social security contributions (€7.6 million)
driven by an increase in our employee base due to the acquisition of Tele2.

_Net impairment losses on financial assets_

Net impairment losses on financial assets for the year ended December 31, 2019 remained relatively
flat at €23.3 million compared to €23.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €42.7 million, an increase of
€30.3 million, compared to €12.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to increase in
legal, consulting and audit fees miscellaneous other expenses driven by the Tele2 acquisition.


-----

_EBITDA_

EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €585.3 million, an increase of €165.7 million, or
39.5%, as compared to €419.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the increase in
net revenues, driven by the acquisition of Tele2 and increase in our subscriber base, which was offset by an
increase in goods and services purchased and personnel costs, in each case driven by the acquisition of Tele2.

_Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses_

Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €518.1
million, an increase of €307.1 million compared to €211.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to an increase in amortization and impairment of intangible assets (€77.2 million) and
depreciation and impairment of PPE (€118.3 million), in each case during the year ended December 31, 2019
and driven by the Tele2 acquisition.

_Profit from operations (EBIT)_

As a result of the factors described above, profit from operations (EBIT) for the year ended December
31, 2019 was €67.1 million, a decrease of €141.5 million, or 67.8%, compared to €208.6 million for the year
ended December 31, 2018.

_Net finance costs_

Interest income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €3.8 million, an increase of €3.7 million
compared to €0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the Tele2 merger and the
resulting increase in interest income relating to site sharing receivables.

Interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €97.6 million, an increase of €95.6 million
compared to €2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the increase in shareholder
loan borrowed by us from Deutsche Telekom and the impact of adoption of IFRS 16, beginning from January
1, 2019.

As a result of the movement in the interest income and interest expense as described above, net finance
costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €93.8 million, an increase of €91.9 million compared to €1.9
million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

_Other financial expense_

Other financial expense for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €0.3 million, as compared to €0.2
million for the year ended December 31, 2018, due to losses from transactions in foreign currency.

_Gain/(loss) from other financial activities_

Loss from other financial activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €0.3 million, as
compared to €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of €0.1 million due to losses from
transactions in foreign currency, which also resulted in an increase in other financial expenses as described
above.

_Results from financial activities_

Results from financial activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 was a loss of €94.1 million,
compared to a loss of €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of €92.0 million, primarily
due to an increase in net finance cost, as described above.


-----

_Profit/(loss) before income taxes_

As a result of the factors described above, profit/loss before income taxes, for the year ended December
31, 2019, was a loss of €27.0 million, as compared to a profit of €206.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2018, representing an increase of €233.6 million.

_Income taxes_

Income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2019 were a benefit of €22.3 million, compared to an
expense of €113.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, a variation of €136.2 million, due to a loss
before tax and a positive tax effect of changes in tax rate, partially offset by certain non-deductible expenses,
during the year ended December 31, 2019, as compared to a profit before tax and impairment due to the
adjustment of future tax rate during the year ended December 31, 2018.

_Result for the year_

As a result of the factors described above, result for the year ended December 31, 2019 was a loss of
€4.7 million, compared to a profit of €92.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, a decrease of €97.3
million.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our liquidity requirements consist mainly of debt servicing requirements, investments in bolt-on
acquisitions, Mobile Capital Expenditure and Fixed Infrastructure Capital Expenditure. Historically, our
principal sources of liquidity have been our net cash generated from operating activities, share capital increases,
factoring arrangements entered into by us and borrowings under our financing arrangements, including
financing facilities from Deutsche Telekom. Going forward, in addition to net cash generated from operating
activities, we expect our principal sources of liquidity to include the Notes, drawings under the Senior Facilities
Agreement (including the RCF) and the factoring arrangements entered into by us from time to time.

RCF1 under the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for an aggregate principal amount of up to
€500.0 million in revolving credit, and RCF2 under the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for an aggregate
principal amount of up to €200.0 million in revolving credit, both of which were undrawn as of September 30,
2021. Subject to certain exceptions and conditions, each of RCF1 and RCF2 may be borrowed, repaid and
reborrowed thereunder at any time in accordance with the Senior Facilities Agreement. For further information,
see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”

After the completion of the Transactions, we will have €800.0 million in aggregate principal amount
of Senior Secured Notes outstanding, €550.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes
outstanding and €2,400.0 million in aggregate principal amount of outstanding loans under the Senior Facilities
Agreement (excluding amounts drawn by us from time to time under RCF1 and RCF2), in addition to certain
other financial indebtedness as described under “Capitalization.”

The Issuers are holding companies with no material operations or assets of their own. As a result, the
Issuers will primarily depend on the cash flow generated by the operating subsidiaries of the Group and paid to
the Issuers by way of interest payments under, or repayments of, the relevant intercompany loans or otherwise


-----

to meet their obligations, including their respective obligations under the Notes and the Senior Facilities
Agreement. The relevant Issuer’s ability to pay cash interest on the Notes offered hereby will be determined by
its cash available for debt service.

As of September 30, 2021, after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, the Issuers and the
Guarantors would have had €4,528.4 million in aggregate principal amount of third-party debt, including €760.7
million of lease liabilities under IFRS 16 and €17.7 million in respect of our factoring facilities.

While we believe we have sufficient liquidity and capital resources to meet our current operating
requirements, our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn
dependent on a variety of factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in
the section titled “Risk Factors.” For further information, see the section titled “Capitalization.”

**_Capital Expenditure_**

Our business capital expenditure consists of:

    - Mobile Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure relating to expansion and/or
improvement of our mobile network infrastructure and is calculated as the sum of capital
expenditure relating to (i) modernization of RAN to ensure full 5G capabilities and the roll-out of
low frequency 5G-ready bands and (ii) other expansion or improvement of our mobile network,
such as in relation to quality improvement and network evolution projects and capital expenditure
to increase capacity. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we incurred
Mobile Capital Expenditure of €79.7 million, €143.0 million and €114.7 million, respectively. For
the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur Mobile Capital Expenditure of
approximately €103 million. Since the year ended December 21, 2018, we have continued with
our initiatives to upgrade our mobile network, primarily through the installation of active antennas
on the 1800MHz and 2600MHZ time division duplex bands. In particular, during the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, we significantly increased our Mobile Capital Expenditure,
primarily in relation to the preparation of the 5G rollout on the low band and adding extra capacity
and coverage by preparing for introducing the 800MHz band into use. During the current period,
the main focus of our Mobile Capital Expenditure has been in relation to the continuing rollout of
the low bands 700/800/900Mhz networks and ramping up the 1800/2100Mhz hardware
replacement.

    - Fixed Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure necessary to maintain and expand
our fixed infrastructure, and is primarily related to (i) capacity extension and upgrades of our fixed
infrastructure, (ii) investments in active equipment in new roll-out areas, (iii) customer-premise
equipment for new customers and (iv) quality improvements and phase out of legacy networks.
During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we incurred Fixed Capital
Expenditure of €22.3 million, €64.5 million and €79.6 million, respectively. For the year ended
December 31, 2021, we expect to incur Fixed Capital Expenditure of approximately €106 million,
Prior to the year ended December 31, 2019, we had a relatively small fixed network. With the
acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019, we expanded our owned base of fixed network
infrastructure. Since then, along with the growth of our fixed subscriber base, we have sought to
expand our fixed network, and one of the key drivers of increase in our Fixed Capital Expenditure
during the periods under discussion, has been in relation to customer-premise equipment for new
customers. In addition, our Fixed Capital Expenditure initiatives have also been focused on
addition of capacity in respect of our T-Mobile Thuis network so as to accommodate the continued
growth of our fixed network subscribers, as well as improving the quality, and where appropriate,
phasing-out of legacy fixed networks.

    - IT Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure relating to the ongoing IT
transformation and our cloud-first strategy. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and
2020, we incurred IT Capital Expenditure of €41.6 million, €44.6 million and €38.7 million,
respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur IT Capital Expenditure
of approximately €44 million. Since the year ended December 31, 2018, our IT Capital
Expenditure initiatives have been focused on the implementation of customer relationship
management or “CRM”-related upgrades to our IT systems and infrastructure, including
digitization initiatives to supports our B2C and B2B segments. In addition, since the year ended
December 31, 2019, we have implemented a new vertical sourcing model, so as to move our IT
systems to a cloud-based network.

    - Other Capital Expenditure, which represents certain other heads of capital expenditures incurred
by us, such as in relation to the acquisition and post-acquisition integration related capital


-----

expenditure as well as certain other miscellaneous heads of capital expenditure such as in relation
building facilities and retail outlets. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2019,
we incurred Other Capital Expenditure of €2.7 million, €38.8 million and €35.9 million,
respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021 we expect to incur Other Capital Expenditure
of approximately €36 million. The higher Capital Expenditure from 2019 onwards is primarily in
relation to the integration of our Tele2 acquisition. In relation to the Tele2 acquisition, which we
completed on January 2, 2019, the key focus of capital expenditure was in relation to postacquisition integration initiatives, particularly in relation to increasing our mobile network to
accommodate all Tele2 traffic and subscribers and to phase-out the Tele2 mobile network. In
relation to the Simpel acquisition, which we completed on December 1, 2020, our capital
expenditure was relatively limited. In connection with the Acquisition, we expect to incur capital
expenditure under the Transition Services Agreement, particularly in relation to the separation of
our management functions from Deutsche Telekom, ring-fencing of our systems and operations,
obtaining of new licenses and entering into new contracts, and the migration of some of our
operation systems to an independent network. See also “Summary—Summary Financial
_Information and Other Data—Capital Expenditure Data.”_
