**Off Balance Sheet Arrangements**

As of September 30, 2021, we have provided certain bank guarantees to secure the performance of our
obligations, among others, under our licenses and supplier contracts. As of September 30, 2021, we have issued
bank guarantees in the amount of €3.0 million (December 31, 2020: €3.6 million). Further, as of September 30,
2021, we have also entered into certain purchase commitment contracts, including in relation to inventories
(including handsets) and property, plant and equipment resulting in commitments of €182.7 million (December
31, 2020: €214.2 million.

Further, we have entered into partnership agreements with Primevest and Open Dutch Fiber to roll-out
Fiber-to-the-Home (“FTTH”) throughout The Netherlands. Pursuant to the partnership agreement with
Primevest, the first cluster, Segbroek in The Hague, was delivered in November 2019. Under the partnership
agreement with Primevest, we have a minimum commitment of 10 years to pay a fixed percentage of the homes
passed (amounting to €5.4 million) for the period beyond the exclusivity period (after year three) and until year
10 for this sub-cluster. We entered into a partnership agreement with Open Dutch Fiber on April 1, 2021. This
partnership agreement is over an initial 20-year period with a minimum commitment to pay for a fixed
percentage of the homes passed for the period beyond the exclusivity (after year one per cluster).

For risks associated with our off-balance sheet arrangements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to
_Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We are and may in the future, become a party to certain performance_
_bonds, guarantees or other off-balance sheet arrangements that may have a current or future effect on our_
_financial condition, revenue or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital_
_resources.”_

**_Factoring Arrangements_**

From time to time, we also enter into factoring arrangements in respect of receivables owed to us.
These receivables include both telecom charges already due and receivables from sales of handsets to customers
payable over a period of up to two years. The terms of our existing factoring agreements between 2022 and
2023. The factoring arrangements entered into by us typically involve (a) the transfer of substantially all risks
and rewards with the involvement of structured entities, (b) the splitting of significant risks and rewards with
control remaining with us without the involvement of structured entities or (c) the splitting of significant risks
and rewards with control remaining with us and with the involvement of structured entities. As of September
30, 2021, our factoring facilities were of an amount of €240.0 million. See also “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangement—Factoring and Receivables Financing Facilities” and “Capitalization.”_

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

We are exposed to the following risks related to the use of financial instruments:

    - market risk;

    - credit risk;

    - liquidity risk;

    - foreign currency risk; and


-----

    - interest rate risk.

Our supervisory and management boards of directors have overall responsibility for the establishment
and oversight of our risk management framework. Our risk management policies are designed to identify and
analyze the risks undertaken by us, define appropriate risk limits and controls, and monitor risks and the
adherence to limits. Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market
conditions and in our activities. We, through our management standards and procedures, aim to develop a
disciplined and constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and obligations.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest rates or
indexation, could affect our income or the value of financial instruments held. The objective of market risk
management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable parameters. We face a low
market risk regarding our financial instruments. Our overall risk management program focuses on minimizing
uncertainty in financial markets and the potential adverse effects on our financial performance.

For further details on our market risk management, refer to note 32 in our Audited Financial
Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 and note 9 in our Condensed
Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to which we are exposed if a customer or counterparty to a
financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. This risk arises principally from receivables from
customers.

held and other loan collateral at the relevant reporting dates can be depicted as follows:

We have no significant concentrations of credit risk and maintain policies to ensure that sales are made
to customers with an adequate credit history. Our clients primarily consist of consumers and businesses with
low average balances which are regularly reviewed. When necessary, these consumers are disconnected from
service when no payment is received. Credit risk is taken into account through a combination of specific and
general valuation allowances.

We have policies to limit exposure to risks assumed in respect to customers and financial institutions,
exposure to risk of recovering receivables and loans is managed as part of our ordinary activities. We have
policies to ensure that sales of products on a wholesale basis are made to customers, including both B2B and
B2C customers, with an adequate credit history. Several debt collection agencies are commissioned to collect


-----

outstanding receivables and inform us about the status of doubtful debts. This valuation is done by the agencies
based on complex models taking various indications into account.

To measure the expected credit losses, trade receivables and contract assets have been grouped based
on shared credit risk characteristics and the days past due. The contract assets relate to unbilled work in progress
and have substantially the same risk characteristics as the trade receivables for the same types of contracts. We
have therefore concluded that the expected loss rates for trade receivables are a reasonable approximation of
the loss rates for the contract assets.

The expected loss rates are based on the payment profiles of sales over a period of 12 to 45 months,
depending on the segment, and the corresponding historical credit losses experienced within this period. The
historical loss rates are adjusted to reflect current and forward-looking information on macroeconomic factors
affecting the ability of the customers to settle the receivables. Our maximum exposure to credit risk from fair
value at profit or loss at December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and September 30, 2021 is equal to the carrying
amounts. With respect to the COVID-19 pandemic, we consider that there was no significant impact on our
credit risk and financial assets as of September 30, 2021.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet financial obligations as they fall due. Our
approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that we will always have sufficient liquidity to
meet our liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses
or risking damage to our reputation.

We apply a prudent policy to cover our liquidity risks, based on maintaining sufficient cash and
marketable securities as well as the availability of sufficient financing through credit facilities to settle market
positions.

Our available cash and equivalents as of September 30, 2021, were €153.9 million, compared to €169.2
million as of December 31, 2020, €143.9 million as of December 31, 2019 and €293.0 million as of December
31, 2018. Net cash generated from operating activities during the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was
positive in the amount of €293.7 million, compared to a positive amount of €581.6 million in the year ended
December 31, 2020, a positive amount of €429.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 and a positive
amount of €394.0 million during the year ended December 31, 2018.

With respect to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is foreseeable that the general situation of
the markets where we operate could lead to a general increase in liquidity tensions in the Dutch economy, as
well as a potential contraction in the credit market.

**INDUSTRY, COMPETITION AND MARKET OVERVIEW**


**Overview**

Within the Dutch telecommunications industry, we operate across two markets, providing both mobile
and fixed connectivity services to consumers and businesses. While we began as a mobile-only business, we
have now established ourselves as a challenger in the fixed connectivity services market, with fixed broadband
internet as our core fixed product, in addition to fixed telephony and television services. We are one of three
mobile network operators in The Netherlands, each of which holds a strong presence in the mobile and fixed
connectivity services markets. Other players in our industry include mobile virtual network operators
(“MVNO”) and infrastructure providers, such as independent tower companies. We operate in a dynamic
regulatory environment to which we must be continually responsive and innovative. Driven by organic and
inorganic growth, we are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by
mobile service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The
Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source:
_PresseBox, Five in a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again;_
_PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut )._


**Dutch Economy**

The Netherlands is the sixth largest economy in the European Union, with a gross domestic product
(“GDP”) of €800 billion in 2020 (source: Eurostat, October 2021), and the 10[th] most populated country in the
region, with an estimated population of 17.5 million inhabitants in 2020 (source: Eurostat, October 2021). In
2020, Dutch GDP declined by 3.8%, less than the European Union average of 6.0% (source: Eurostat) as a
result of the COVID-19-related lockdowns imposed by Dutch authorities. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic,
the Dutch economy consistently grew faster than the European Union average for the past four years. Dutch
GDP growth has been driven by a combination of factors, led by private consumption, investment and
international trade.

The Netherlands has been moderately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, timely fiscal
support and existing digital infrastructure reduced the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Eighty percent of
the decrease in output caused by the COVID-19 pandemic in the first half of 2020 was recouped towards the
end of 2020. This was mainly attributed to the resilience of manufacturing. Export of services in 2020 was 17%
lower than in 2019 (source: Bureau for Economic Policy Analysis (“CPB”) (Centraal Planbureau)). Despite a
contraction of 3.7% of the Dutch economy during 2020, current economic analyses project a strong recovery.
The OECD estimates an annual growth rate of 3.5% in 2021, 3.0% in 2022 and 1.8% in 2023.

Price growth in The Netherlands has remained low and relatively stable, with an annual inflation rate
of 1.1% in 2020, compared to 2.6% in 2019 (source: De Nederlandsche Bank (“DNB”), March 2021). The
decrease is mainly attributed to reduced consumption in 2020 caused by the containment measures that were
taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic (source: OECD). The inflation rate is projected to increase to
1.5% over the course of 2021. This relatively stable increase is a result of higher oil prices on the one hand and
substantial adjustments to household expenditures on the other hand, with the impacts effectively cancelling
one another. Inflation is expected to rise to 2.2% in 2022 and 1.5% in 2023, in line with developments that
would be expected in economic recovery _(source: European Commission, November 2021)._ Dutch
unemployment rates have improved, declining from a peak of 7.4% in 2014 to a low of 3.4% in 2019 before
increasing to 3.8% in 2020, due to the fast implementation of policy support such as wage subsidies, deferred
tax expenses and loan guarantees for firms, but these rates remain low overall compared to other jurisdictions
(sources: OECD, World Bank).

The Netherlands has recovered from challenging macroeconomic conditions in the past, most recently
from the 2008 global financial crisis. Following a four-year period of economic growth from 2003 to 2007
_(source: World Bank), in 2008 The Netherlands entered a recession following the global economic slowdown_
at the time. Consequently, The Netherlands’ real GDP declined by 3.7% in 2009, with the unemployment rate
not peaking until 2014 at 7.4%. This decline was partially mitigated by a series of stimulus measures taken by
the Dutch government in 2008 and 2009 to stabilize the economy. The two stimulus plans, amounting to €6
billion and €13.754 billion respectively, aimed to bolster domestic sectors and improve social and
unemployment policies. The efforts translated into positive economic growth over the subsequent years,
however growth stagnated with a further recession in 2012, caused by low export growth and a decrease in
domestic spending (source: Statistics Netherlands (Central Bureau voor de Statistiek)).

**Dutch Telecommunications Market**

**_History and regulatory changes_**

As a result of liberalization initiatives of the telecommunications sector mandated by various European
Commission Directives and WTO commitments, the Dutch telecommunications market officially has moved
from a closed, restricted, and virtually monopolized sector to an open market structure in 1997.


-----

Prior to 1990, the Royal Dutch PTT (now known as KPN) held a monopoly position on the installation
of telecommunication networks and the provision of telecommunication services. Liberalization was gradually
imposed over the following seven years and after its privatization in 1989 and listing in 1994. In 1995, an
additional Global System for Mobile communication (“GSM”) license in the mobile segment was awarded to
Libertel (now known as VFZ). In 1996/1997, the liberalization of the fixed segment was initiated by opening
up fixed infrastructure. Two national licenses were awarded to Telfort and Enertel along with KPN as the
incumbent and about 1,400 regional infrastructure licenses were awarded to approximately 160 other
companies. In 1998, digital cellular system licenses at 1,800 MHz were awarded to Telfort,
Teledanmark/Proximus, which was launched as Ben and is now part of TMNL, and France
Telecommunications, which was launched as Federa and was bought by TMNL in 2007. These market
participants all expanded their product offerings, introduced new technologies and enhanced the
telecommunications market.

The Dutch telecommunications sector has experienced multiple instances of consolidation. In 2008,
three of the largest cable operators – Home, Casema and Multikabel – formed Ziggo, which eventually was
acquired by Liberty Global. Subsequently, Liberty Global formed in The Netherlands a joint venture with
Vodafone, creating the large national converged cable operator VFZ. A condition of the European
Commission’s regulatory approval of this joint venture was that Vodafone had to divest its Dutch fixed line
broadband business, Thuis, which was acquired by TMNL in December 2016. Deutsche Telekom Group
originally entered the Dutch telecommunications market through its acquisition of operator Ben Nederland
Holding B.V. in 2002 and Orange Nederland N.V., Orange Nederland Breedband B.V. in 2007, and later
acquired the Dutch operations of Swedish MNO Tele2 Sverige AB in January 2019. Today, TMNL, KPN and
VFZ are the major operators in the country.

Following the global financial crisis of 2009 and the takeover attempt by América Móvil of KPN in
2012, the Dutch government’s view on a fully open market changed slightly. The government made various
regulatory commitments to protect Dutch consumers and foster healthy competition. In 2011, The Netherlands
became the first European country to pass net neutrality legislation, preventing leading market operators from
charging consumers extra for certain data traffic. In 2019, the Dutch industry regulator, Netherlands Authority
for Consumers and Markets (“ACM”), through guidance detailed a framework to prevent bottlenecks in FTTHrollout, therein highlighting options such as joint investment and temporary protection at municipal level for
first movers. The objectives of consumer and technology protection for the vital telecommunications sector also
has resulted in a revised Telecommunication Sector Act, passed on May 19, 2020, with the purpose of further
protecting Dutch national security and public order. Under this reform, the Minister of Economic Affairs and
Climate must be notified if a party intention to acquire ‘a controlling interest’ in a ‘telecom party’ if such interest
results in ‘relevant influence’ in the Dutch telecommunications sector. If an acquisition leads to disproportionate
influence over Dutch national security and public order, the Minister can prohibit the transaction. Although
wholesale regulation which required operators to sign commercial agreements to gain access to KPN’s fixed
network was repealed in 2020, the Dutch telecommunications supervisory board (ACM) is considering whether
to reinforce the legislation after reviewing it this year.

**_Dutch Telecommunications Infrastructure_**

**_Mobile infrastructure market_**

The Dutch mobile telecommunications infrastructure ecosystem comprises three mobile network
operators (“MNO”) that own their networks, approximately 30 active mobile virtual network operators
(“MVNO”) as well as infrastructure companies. Many telecommunications operators and smaller tower
companies across The Netherlands are executing, or considering, tower network sales to other operators and
independent telecommunications infrastructure tower companies. The major independent tower company in
The Netherlands is Cellnex, which offers network as a service, allowing customers to operate their own
networks, without maintaining own passive network infrastructure, by paying a flat fee per site or a variable
cost per gigabyte (“GB”) consumed. Cellnex builds and maintains the distributed antenna system (“DAS”), to
which the MNOs connect. Cellnex entered the Dutch market in 2016 with its acquisition of Protelindo and
Shere Group in 2016, as well as Alticom in 2017. On September 1, 2018, TMNL carved out its tower business
by way of a legal demerger (juridische splitsing) to Cignal Infrastructure. As part of a later transaction, Cignal
Infrastructure was transferred to Cellnex Netherlands B.V. T-Mobile Netherlands maintains access to Cellnex’s


-----

passive infrastructure elements through a master services agreement. Cellnex now operates a total of 4,314 sites,
with 180 new sites to be rolled out in the next seven years. VFZ owns its portfolio of towers of approximately
3,000 sites.

The three MNOs – TMNL, KPN and VFZ – have been rolling out 4G technology since mid-2012 or
early 2013 and are collectively offering 4G coverage in 99% of the country in terms of both geography and
population. All three MNOs provide 5G services, following an early launch by VFZ in April 2020 with the help
of Ericsson’s dynamic spectrum sharing technology which enables 5G activation with existing frequency bands
on the 1,800 MHz band, KPN and TMNL launched their respective 5G services in July 2020, following the
first auction of 5G on the 700 MHz band. The auction covered 700 MHz, 1,400 MHz and 2,100 MHz bands
and raised a total of €1.23 billion. In terms of allocation of frequency rights between the dominant market
players, TMNL secured 70 MHz and KPN and VFZ 75 MHz each. All MNOs have since expanded their 5G
networks, with VFZ reporting in July 2020 that it had reached a population coverage of more than 80% on its
5G network. In October 2020, TMNL reported that its 5G mobile network reached 90% of the Dutch population,
making it the first MNO to provide nationwide 5G coverage. Finally, in April 2021, KPN estimated that their
5G network reached approximately 72% of the Dutch population. Further 5G services may be offered after the
auction in the latter half of 2022 of the 3.5 GHz band, which is currently used by the Dutch government for
intelligence communications and by a satellite telecommunications company for safety communications at sea.

**_Fixed infrastructure market_**

The Netherlands has one of the highest fixed broadband penetrations in Europe, with 97% of all
households having internet in 2020 (source: Eurostat). DSL, hybrid fiber coaxial (“HFC”) and fiber networks
compete on a cross-platform basis. Fixed broadband connections have increased by 13.3% between 2013 and
2020 and fiber connections have increased by more than a factor of three over the same period. HFC connections
increased by 12.9% and DSL decreased by 19.7% (source: ACM Monitor; Publicly available sources). DSL
connections are falling as consumers move to next-generation networks (“NGN”), namely fiber to the home
(“FTTH”) or HFC, which are able to deliver higher speed and quality. In 2020, about 49% of the fixed


-----

broadband connections provided households with data above 100 Mb/s (source: ACM). This number has
continuously increased over the years due to new technologies and infrastructure as well as increased consumer
demand, not least during the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns. FTTH and HFC have become the main focus
for Dutch operators in recent years, as demonstrated by the extensive rollout of fiber optic network. The
Netherlands has taken a collaborative approach with municipalities when building out fiber networks. As a
result of operators partaking in the rollout of NGN networks and phasing out copper networks, the number of
FTTH networks installed grew from 517,000 to almost 1,600,000 in 2020, representing an increase of 206%
(source: ACM Monitor).

As of 2020, the number of households passed with FTTH amounted to approximately 3.67 million,
representing approximately 46% of all households in The Netherlands (source: ACM Monitor). Approximately
3.33 million of the houses passed are on the KPN and DELTA Fiber Nederland B.V. (“DELTA Fiber”)
network.

The fixed infrastructure market has followed a similar monetization path as the mobile infrastructure
market, and several commercial wholesale agreements over fiber networks have been reached in recent years.
Operators have been either divesting their FTTH networks or creating strategic partnerships with companies
such as Open Dutch Fiber (“ODF”) or DELTA Fiber Nederland B.V., backed by financial sponsors KKR &
Co. Inc. (“KKR”) with Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners Management GmbH (“DTCP”) and EQT Partners
(“EQT”), respectively. In April 2021, KKR and DTCP launched a fiber venture with TMNL as the anchor
tenant, in which capital expenditure commitments will amount to approximately €700 million (source: publicly
_announced by KKR and DTCP). Similarly, one of EQT’s infrastructure funds and Stonepeak recently_
announced their joint acquisition of DELTA Fiber. Another example is KPN and pension fund APG’s joint
venture, Glaspoort, a partnership that is aimed to rollout fiber to approximately 750,000 homes and 225,000
businesses in the upcoming five years. The investment is expected to amount to over €1 billion.

The fixed broadband sector also has been backed by significant investment in fiber infrastructure, as
seen in the FTTH household penetration of approximately 20% in 2020, compared to 7% in 2013. There is,
however room for growth, as fiber connections in The Netherlands represented only 21% of total broadband
connections in 2020, compared to the OECD average of 31%. The Netherlands ranks 26[th] among all 38 OECD
countries in terms of percentage of fiber connections amongst total broadband connections.

**_Dutch telecommunications market_**

The Dutch telecommunications market is one of the largest in Europe, supported by The Netherlands
being the sixth largest economy in the European Union (source: Eurostat, October 2021) and a population of
more than 17.5 million (source: Eurostat, January 2021). The market landscape is led by the three MNO
players: KPN, TMNL and VFZ. Mobile penetration is 128% as of the fourth quarter of 2020 (source: ACM
_Monitor), which is above the European Union average of 122% (source: World Bank). Consistent with global_
consumption trends, demand for data has increased significantly in The Netherlands, translating to a
compounded annual growth of approximately 61% since 2013 and until the end of 2020. TMNL currently
carries more than 50% of this data (source: ACM Monitor) and a vast majority of this data is based on 4G
(LTE), the network for which currently reaches over 99% of the country by both geography and population.
Consequently, the Dutch operators are increasingly focusing on services based on 5G.

There are positive trends that impact the mobile B2C segment. The continued increase of the
population, with younger generations having phones at a younger age and the pre-to-post migration impact the
number of SIM subscriptions. The current trend towards multi-SIM, meaning the ability for consumers to
connect multiple devices to the same mobile number, allows for more flexible voice services and increased
customer loyalty. KPN and TMNL offer multi-SIM solutions today. Average revenue per user (“ARPUs”) of
the market are according to management’s estimates expected to grow, mainly through the increased access of
5G, “more for more” services and low-end portfolio optimization.

Within the fixed market, consumer demand for data at a higher speed is increasing and the willingness
to pay more for ultrafast fiber and better quality is becoming increasingly important to consumers. We believe
that this growing demand for broadband services is likely to offset the decline of segments such as traditional
TV and fixed voice, which are increasingly being replaced by more digital solutions such as over the top
(“OTT”) communication services that operate over the internet.

**_Dutch Mobile Market_**

**_Focus on the Dutch mobile telephony market_**

The Dutch mobile telephony market is led by the three MNOs – KPN, TMNL and VFZ – which
directly provide services to consumers mainly through their group brands, with KPN offering sub-brands such
as Simyo, and TMNL offering Tele2, Simpel or Ben as an alternative to the premium brand T-Mobile. MVNOs
hosted on MNO’s networks also provide consumers with mobile telephony services. As of December 31, 2020,
TMNL was the premier company in the B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our
number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the
same market.

KPN phased out its Telfort brand between 2019 and 2020 in order to focus on value-over-volume
strategy in which the company wants to leverage a simplified product portfolio. TMNL’s growth has been
driven partly by the completion of the merger with the Dutch operations of Swedish Tele2 Sverige AB in 2019
and the acquisition of Simpel, a Dutch SIM-only MVNO, in 2020. Despite increased competition in the last
decade, the market has stabilized and prices have shown moderate growth across the MNOs.

The mobile telecommunications market in The Netherlands is relatively sizeable and attractive with
three MNOs and the risk of new MNOs and MVNOs entering the market is limited. For MNOs, low prices act
as a deterrent as ARPUs are at the low end of European benchmarks and significantly below the level at which
Tele2 unsuccessfully entered the market in 2015. Furthermore, there is no upcoming spectrum auction that


-----

could facilitate a new entrant – the upcoming auction for the 3.5 GHz spectrum is inappropriate for new entrants
due to propagation characteristics – and the market is highly converged, resulting in more lasting customers
and limiting the pool of available subscribers. The number of MVNOs has halved in the last six years from
approximately 60 to approximately 30 and the remaining MVNOs are small and focused on niche customer
groups.

The three players in the market have seen relatively stable ARPUs in recent quarters. KPN has
delivered stable ARPUs for the B2C mobile postpaid category, with ARPUs ranging between €17.3-18.3 since
the first quarter of 2019 (source: Public filings). KPN is devoting resources to its value-over-volume strategy
by refocusing on the KPN brand and phasing out its Telfort brand, in 2019, aiming to leverage its market
position as a trusted and conventional MNO and offer a simplified product portfolio. Historically, VFZ’s
ARPUs declined in a push to grow FMC penetration as a competitive response to TMNL’s lower prices. ARPUs
have recently started to stabilize, given the high FMC share reached and the changed competitive environment.
In recent reporting periods, all brands have experienced ARPU increases and reduced aggressive promotions.
Further growth within the Dutch mobile telephony market is supported by structural drivers such as the increase
in number of SIMs due to population growth. The continued pre- to post-migration trend, the growth of
Unlimited, 5G, value-added services and overall inflation are other drivers that are expected to support ARPUs.

**_Focus on the Dutch mobile broadband market_**

Mobile broadband is wireless internet access that is delivered through cellular towers. Although
representing a relatively small fraction of mobile connections in The Netherlands, the mobile broadband market
has gained traction through mobile network operator investments in high-speed package (“HSPA”) and LTE
technologies. An increase in the number of subscribers of mobile broadband is expected with the upcoming
auction of 3.5 GHz band in 2022, as 5G will enhance the range and capacity of networks.

**Dutch Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market**

**_Focus on fixed broadband market_**

Active fixed network broadband lines reached 7.5 million households in 2020, a modest increase of
0.9% compared to 2019 (source: ACM Monitor). Expansion of fixed broadband is mainly driven by growth of
installed fiber networks, which grew by 16.1% between 2019 and 2020 and resulted in a penetration of 42%.
This number has been increasing by the month, and as of June 2021 fiber penetrated 51% of Dutch households.


-----

_Broadband by technology (in millions of lines)_

_Source: ACM Monitor_

The growing number of broadband lines is partially driven by bundled offerings, the prevalence of
which has increased and most notably for 4P bundles (fixed-mobile). In 2020, 4P bundles took up 26% of total
broadband connections – compared to 7% in 2014. Bundled offerings accounted for 92% of all retail
connections with broadband in 2020 (source: ACM Monitor).

Over the course of 2020, average fixed broadband speed increased because of higher network access
and greater sales of bundles with higher fixed line connection speeds and larger mobile connection traffic
volumes. As of 2020, 99% of broadband lines had a connection speed higher than 10 Mbps. In 2019, lines with
a connection speed greater than 30 Mbps but less than 100 Mbps amounted to 46% and decreased to 44% in
2020. However, this decrease was offset by an increase of lines with a connection speed of 100 Mbps or higher,
which increased from 46% of retail connections in 2019 to 49% in 2020 (source: ACM Monitor). Collectively,
lines with a speed of 30 Mbps or more amounted to 91.7%. While lines with connection speeds greater than
100 Mbps increased in 2020, this was mainly reflected in high-speed data processed via fiber-optic connections,
representing a 30.1% increase, whereas DSL and cable connections increased by 0.9% and 1.3% respectively.
This demonstrates the proportionate relationship between the number of high data subscribers and upgrades of
network infrastructure and technology.

Two of the three largest MNOs, VFZ and KPN, hold key positions in the market for fixed broadband
retail connections, with a revenue market share of 45% and 41% respectively, with TMNL currently holding a
6% share.

**_Focus on fixed telephony_**

Fixed telephony revenue continued to decline during 2020 and so did both public switched telephone
networks (“PSTN”) and voice over broadband (“VOB”) single connections. Although fixed telephony is
considered a mature, declining market, the operators benefit from the service by bundling it with other
telecommunications services. In 2020, only 17% of fixed telephony retail connections were contracted
individually. The remaining 37% was in 4P bundles, 40% in 3P bundles and 6% in 2P bundles.

In 2020, the network traffic per fixed line decreased by 30.9% whereas broadband network traffic
increased by 14.7%. The majority of consumers have replaced their fixed telephones with mobiles and most
digital interactions now take place either online or via mobile networks. As a result of the shift from fixed to
mobile telephony, fixed telephony revenues have decreased by 71% since 2013.

_Revenue fixed network (in € million)_

_Source: ACM Monitor_

**_Bundling/fixed-mobile convergence_**

By bundling services together, such as high speed data packages and phone services, rather than
offering discounted prices separately, both consumers and operators can potentially achieve better value. FMC
can be driven by consumer demand and by operators seizing opportunities and locking in customers, leveraging
either a fixed or a mobile asset that competitors may not have.

_Product bundles penetration (% of total subscribers)_


-----

_Source: ACM Monitor_

The Dutch telecommunications market has shifted over recent years. The number of fixed-mobile
product bundles (4P, 3P and 2P bundles) has increased every year from an aggregate of 5.6 million in 2013 to
7.0 million in 2020, with penetration of fixed-mobile product bundles increasing from 4.9% to 36.6% over this
period. There has been a steady increase in the popularity of 4P bundles, growing each year from approximately
0.4 million in 2013 to 2.9 million in 2020. Meanwhile, 3P bundle subscriptions increased from 3.5 million in
2013 to 3.9 million in 2016, before falling back to 2 million in 2020 as 4P bundles grew in popularity.
Consumers with 2P bundle subscriptions have increased from 1.7 million in 2013 to 2.1 million in 2020 (source:
_ACM Monitor). In 2020, TMNL held a 5-10% retail market share of bundled services. VFZ held a 45-50%_
market share, while KPN and DELTA Fiber held 35-40% and 5-10% market share, respectively. DELTA Fiber
does not offer retail bundles containing mobile (source: ACM Monitor).

FMC will be further enabled by cross-selling a large mobile base and through the upselling of fixed
services to mobile customers, which will spur growth in the consumer market. In 2021, TMNL’s brand Tele2
launched various FMC multi-brand offerings that are aimed to improve loyalty, both by serving the existing
customer base and by establishing brands that cater to new customers within the whole household.

**Pay-TV**

Although demand for traditional television is gradually reducing as consumers move to alternative
media services, such as OTT services, television via fiber is gaining prominence. Between 2013 and 2020, fiber
connections for television in The Netherlands increased by a factor of 1.7x _(source: ACM Monitor). Fiber_
provides customers with good quality picture while simultaneously allowing operators to reduce operating costs
in the long run.

_Television subscriptions per connection type (in millions of lines)_

_Source: ACM Monitor_

The rapid growth of OTT streaming services, both advertisement-based video on demand (“AVOD”)
and subscription-based video on demand (“SVOD”), has impacted traditional pay-TV operators that use
satellite and cable to offer subscription television services. As KPN launched its IPTV package as part of its
convergence strategy and eventually launched 4P bundles, competitors had to act accordingly and improve their
own convergence service offerings. Despite VFZ’s leading position in the market, the company now offers
Netflix on all of its set-top boxes. In 2015, KPN launched KPN Play, which eventually was discontinued in
2018 due to a lack of demand. TMNL subsequently closed its own OTT offering, Knippr, the same year.
Nevertheless, in 2020 The Netherlands had the third highest percentage of its national population streaming
internet TV or videos compared to 37 other European countries, due to significant growth of companies offering
streaming media as a core service. In 2020, 95% of the Dutch population who used the internet within the last
three months used it to watch internet-streamed TV or videos, compared to 90% and 84% in 2018 and 2016,
respectively (source: Eurostat).

that capacity for broadband could be increased.

**Business & wholesale market**

The B2B mobile market has declined in the last three years, mainly due to changes in what type of
telecommunications services businesses require for their operations. One factor contributing to the negative
trend in voice is the transition from traditional telephony to integrated solutions (e.g., Cloud PBX solutions that
provide telephone server access over a cloud-based internet network).

Wholesale business fiber connections in The Netherlands amounted to approximately 107,000
connections, growing from 100,000 in 2019 (source: ACM Monitor). The fixed connectivity segment is mainly
driven by demand for internet and data networks, which in turn is fueled by the shift from cable to fiber.

Pursuant to regulatory refinements, KPN and VFZ are no longer required to maintain a wholesale offer
for virtual access to their networks. Since 1997, KPN was obligated to provide wholesale access to its copper
and fiber network, and since October 2018 VFZ was obligated to provide wholesale access to its cable network.
In a landmark decision in March 2020, the regulator (ACM) found that KPN and VFZ together held significant
market power. However, after a national appeal, this decision was annulled by the CBb in March 2020. The
court held that there was not sufficient evidence to establish joint dominance on the retail market by KPN and
VFZ. As a result, these companies are no longer obligated to provide wholesale access to their networks,
although KPN has chosen to continue to offer wholesale access of both copper and fiber to other operators.

**Regulatory outlook**

The main regulatory bodies in the Dutch telecommunications market include ACM and supervisory
authorities: the Radiocommunications Agency Netherlands (Agentschap Telecom) (“AT”), which is part of the
Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy; the Dutch Authority for the Financial Markets (Autoriteit
_Financiële Markten) (“AFM”); and the Dutch Data Protection Authority (Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens) (“AP”)._

There are differing views on how deregulation will impact competition and pricing for fixed wholesale
access. TMNL relies on access to KPN’s networks but recently submitted two requests to ACM to have KPN
regulated again and enforce wholesale access against regulated wholesale tariffs (source: Company
_information). Despite wholesale access no longer being regulated at this time, ACM has been granted a new_
regulatory tool (symmetric access) to impose access obligations, in addition to the market analysis route it has
had for decades. A draft market analysis decision of the ACM is expected to be published towards the end of
2021, following its press release in July 2021, that it will conduct research and take a decision on the need (and


-----

if so, the way) to regulate fixed access. According to this press release, the ACM sees a risk that KPN may
restrict its access conditions.

In February 2021, the Dutch Minister of Finance sent a letter to the Dutch Parliament reflecting an
intention to revise consumer credit regulation in The Netherlands by lowering the threshold for document
verification required to obtain a loan for a mobile device. So far, no legislative proposal has been submitted to
Parliament to execute this intention and a decision has not been made whether to submit such a proposal. With
regards to data roaming, there will potentially be stricter quality of service provisions as EU bodies are in a
process of reviewing roaming regulations including a potential reduction of the wholesale and/or retail tariffs
in the future. In April 2021, Dutch mobile operators received a decision from the Dutch government on the
basis of which Chinese vendors are restricted from supplying specific components to the core mobile network
and service platforms of Dutch telecom providers. The Dutch MNOs are granted a transition period to replace
the current equipment and the transition period is in line with TMNL’s usual replacement and rotation cycle.

The auction of the 3.5 GHz is expected to take place in the latter half of 2022, but this could be delayed
to 2023 due to a court case initiated by Inmarsat, a British satellite telecommunications company, which
currently uses the spectrum for safety communications at sea. There are not expected to be significant regulatory
challenges in connection with spectrum coverage.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network
operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid)
and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our
customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile
service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for
the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The
_2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by_
_Umlaut)._

As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers, representing
an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For the twelve
months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our combined mobile
service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled €391 million, and
our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million. Mobile service
revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming, and our fixed
line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as fixed line
wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other
adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was €292
million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €637.4
million.

TMNL traces its origins back to 2002, when Deutsche Telekom entered the Dutch market through the
acquisition of Ben, which it subsequently rebranded as T-Mobile in 2003. In 2007, we acquired Orange
Netherlands, making us the third largest mobile operator in The Netherlands after Koninklijke KPN N.V.
(“KPN”) and VodafoneZiggo Group Holding B.V. (“VFZ”). In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s fixed business,
Vodafone Thuis, which was subsequently renamed to TMNL Thuis. This transaction marked our entry into the
fixed market, adding approximately 150,000 fixed line customers. Through the TMNL Thuis acquisition, we
also gained access to a dark fiber footprint on KPN’s fiber network (KPN ODF). In January 2019, we completed
the acquisition of Tele2, strengthening our position in the Dutch market, across all segments. In December
2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, an online-only SIM-only MVNO on our network, focusing in
particular on the low budget segment of the market. The Simpel acquisition further strengthened our position,
making us the leader both in terms of B2C mobile postpaid SIM cards and service revenues. We continue to
operate the Simpel brand after its acquisition in 2020. In April 2021, we announced a strategic partnership with
Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP that plans to roll-out fiber services to over one million
homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on this network which focuses on dense, urban areas in which we
currently have a large mobile market share. The Open Dutch Fiber partnership is an example of our asset-light
model and lean operational setup, which we believe enables us to streamline our business and optimize our
indirect cost base ratio.

We provide our B2C customers with a multi-brand portfolio of mobile services, including voice,
messaging and broadband aiming to cover all segments of the market from premium to low-budget and
operating on our own networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide
fixed broadband, TV and fixed voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. In addition, and in
line with market trends, we offer B2C customers packages that bundle mobile and fixed telecommunications
services at attractive prices, known as FMC packages. Our B2B business segment is dedicated to meeting the
connectivity needs of companies of all types and sizes as we offer a broad range of telecommunications
solutions, cloud-based and unified communications solutions. The chart below sets forth key events in our
growth and transformation to the largest mobile telecommunications provider in The Netherlands’ B2C market
and an established mobile-led FMC challenger.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Attractive telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands_**

We operate in The Netherlands, which has a sizeable and attractive telecommunications market which
consists of three main telecommunications providers. The Netherlands is the 6[th ]largest economy in Europe and
has a robust macroeconomic environment, with 2% real GDP growth expected for 2021, moderate population
and household growth, and a large demand for high-quality communication services (Source: Telecompaper).
We compete in both the mobile and the fixed markets with KPN and VFZ. We are the premier company in the
B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as
compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the same market. The MVNO market is small
accounting for approximately 4% market share of postpaid SIMs, with the largest MVNO, Youfone, having an
approximately 3% market share based on number of SIM subscribers. In this context, we believe the risk of
irrational behaviors by existing competitors is low and that existing MNOs are likely to compete primarily on
the quality of their services. Following our acquisition of Tele2, the market players were further consolidated


-----

from four to three and a process of revenue and ARPU stabilization started, similar to what has been seen in
other markets such as Austria, Germany or Ireland. The Netherlands has one of the lowest ARPU levels in
Europe.

We also believe that the risk of a new MNO entering the market is low. We believe that this is due to
the following factors: (i) the highly converged nature of the market, making it less attractive for new entrants,
as they must be able to offer both mobile and fixed offers to be competitive therein and (ii) the lack of any
viable spectrum auction that could allow the entrance of a new player, since the upcoming 5G spectrum auction
in The Netherlands is planned to offer only a specific band of spectrum and we do not need to renew our existing
spectrum licenses until 2030, making the auction more suitable for existing MNOs and unsuitable for new
entrants. The most recent possibility for a new entrant to obtain a marketable spectrum allocation would have
been the 2020 multi-band spectrum auction. However, only the three main players in the telecommunications
market, namely KPN, VFZ and us, participated in the auction. Additionally, we believe that the competitive
risk posed by MVNOs is low because MVNOs have limited ability to compete on unlimited subscriptions in
light of each MVNO’s lack of owned network and their limited ability to cover FMC packages, as well as such
unlimited plans’ impact on costs. Indeed, the number of MVNOs has decreased by half from approximately 60
to approximately 30 in The Netherlands over the last six years.

Furthermore, we anticipate that the B2C mobile market will continue to grow as data traffic continues
to increase. Indeed, our B2C mobile pro forma service revenues grew by 3.1% in 2020 (after a 4.1% decrease
in 2019) despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Key trends include:

(i) Growth in postpaid SIMs subscriptions, which is driven both by prepaid to postpaid subscription

migration and by population growth, as well as trends of increasing proportions of multi-SIM
subscriptions; and

(ii) Growth in mobile ARPU as driven by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services, value-added

services as well as overall inflation and the telecommunications market’s shift towards larger data
bundles. We believe that B2C ARPU will grow in the future due to these factors, even though
mobile ARPUs had decreased in The Netherlands in past years because of intense price
competition and mobile discounting as part of FMC offers, mainly triggered by KPN and VFZ.

The B2B market has seen similar developments. In particular, ARPU in the SOHO/VSE segment
follows consumer market trends, driven as in the B2C market by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services
and value-added services, and we believe those drivers will continue to push ARPU growth. In the B2B market
generally, we believe that growth in subscribers will be driven by growth in SOHO/VSE businesses, an
increased adoption of mobile services in the B2B market and an increasing adoption of converged
telecommunications solutions.

Additionally, the Dutch fixed telecommunications market has benefitted from infrastructure upgrades
in recent years that have contributed to a growing market, in spite of declining telephony and peaking TV,
primarily due to a higher demand for broadband services at higher speeds, which is our core product offering
within the fixed segment. Historically, the fixed internet market in The Netherlands was dominated by KPN
and VFZ, which have a combined market share of approximately 80%. We have positioned ourselves as a
challenger in this market, focusing on providing fast broadband services and offering competitive and
sustainable pricing. In the future, we believe that growth in the fixed market will be driven by (i) an increase in
subscribers associated with household growth and (ii) premium customers’ willingness to pay for ultrafast fiber
and better quality, which allows for more-for-more strategies and results in increasing demand for higher fiberbased data bundles.

FTTH coverage is expanding in The Netherlands and the B2C and B2B markets are expected to benefit
from such expansion. We expect to benefit from this trend through what we call our ‘Magenta’ footprint, which
includes several Optical Distribution Framework-type of agreements and partnerships with, among others, Open
Dutch Fiber, KPN’s affiliate Reggefiber Operator B.V. and Primevest Capital Partners, where we expect to
eventually have access to over three million households at sustainable commercial terms. The remaining
households can be reached by Wholesale Broadband Access (“WBA”)-type of access on KPN copper (until its
planned phase-out over the next three years) and/or fiber network. Additional infrastructure players of


-----

significant size include Delta Fiber, Glaspoort (a joint venture between KPN and APG Groep N.V.) and
Eurofiber.

**_World-class network and strong commercial execution_**

We lead our competitors across a number of key attributes, including our world-class mobile network
with the largest spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands, our leading brand portfolio and our strong commercial
execution.

In December 2020, Umlaut ranked us the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in
a row, and in February 2021, they recognized us as the top network in the world (Sources: PresseBox, Five in
_a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again; PresseBox, T-_
_Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut). According to the ACM, our mobile network carries_
approximately 50% of mobile data traffic in The Netherlands. We believe that our leading network position
results from our efficiently leveraging three key pillars: (i) technology, such as single radio access network
(“RAN”) with future-proof site configurations that are regularly upgraded in anticipation of customer demand;
(ii) sites, as we operate an optimal site grid with the highest site density in urban areas and 4,982 base stations
in total, providing coverage to more than 99% of the population of The Netherlands; (iii) the largest mobile
spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands with interference-free low bands, resulting in high cost efficiency and
an indoor capacity advantage. As of December 31, 2020, we held an aggregate of 250 MHz of spectrum, in
comparison with 215 MHz for VFZ and 195 MHz for KPN. None of the licenses in our portfolio need to be
renewed before 2030.

We have distinguished ourselves by our distinctive brand portfolio. In line with other MNOs in The
Netherlands, we have been following value-based and more-for-more strategies that target different market
segments with separate brands. Each of our four brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated profiles,

market share of 42% over the past three years, supported in part by the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, while
the absolute number of subscribers grew at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2018 and 2020. At the same time, our
market share by revenue increased from 33% to 40% over the same period.

Our B2C mobile revenue growth in the past three years was mainly driven by stable ARPUs at brand
levels and a growing subscriber base, driven by marketing strategies for our brands, our strong positioning in
unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2, and an increase in demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel.

We have also maintained growth in customer satisfaction, which has helped us retain customers. In
the B2C mobile market, TMNL outpaced its competitors in The Netherlands by delivering the fastest-increasing
customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely
adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group which combines customer recommendation, customer likelihood
to continue services, competitive advantage and performance. Our TRI*M score increased by over 50% over
12 years. We believe that an increase in customer satisfaction was one of the key factors driving the reduction
in our B2C mobile churn to approximately 11% in 2020.

We believe that our position as a leading B2C mobile operator with growing customer satisfaction
metrics situates us well to take advantage of trends towards converged fixed and mobile offerings and morefor-more strategies, as it allows us a larger base of customers to cross-sell into FMC packages and to upsell into
more premium offers. See “—World-class network and strong commercial execution” and “Industry—Dutch
_Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market—Focus on fixed broadband market.” Already in the first three quarters_
of 2021, our ARPU has grown across all four of our brands, corresponding to increases of between €0.8 and


-----

€1.1 in the third quarter of 2021 in comparison with the first quarter of 2021. We expect to experience moderate
growth in the future by building on our success in growing subscriber base and potential further ARPU growth.

**_High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model_**

We have a successful track record of M&A, synergy realization and cost optimization. This track
record, combined with a lean, asset-light fixed business model has given us operating leverage and operational
efficiency.

In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s B2C fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which we shortly thereafter
rebranded T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone’s divestiture of Vodafone Thuis was ordered by the European
Commission as a remedy to provide competition clearance for VFZ, the joint venture between Vodafone and
Ziggo. This acquisition marked the beginning of our present fixed internet business and added about 150,000
fixed-line customers. In January 2019, we completed our acquisition of Tele2. This acquisition has strengthened
our position in the Dutch telecommunications market and allowed us to compete more effectively with KPN
and VFZ by giving us enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources and significant synergy potential. We are
executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have closed Tele2’s
standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings. Based on our
estimates, we anticipate realizing Tele2 cost-saving synergies with a total run-rate synergy potential of €130
million by 2024, of which we have already realized €115 million of synergies run-rate as of September 30,
2021. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, by then the largest MVNO in The
Netherlands. By means of this transaction, we acquired one million additional B2C mobile postpaid customers
who were already using our network under Simpel’s prior wholesale agreement with us. The acquisition of
Simpel provide further synergy and cost savings potential to be realized in the total amount of approximately
€9 million by 2024. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel entail for example related to reduced interconnect
costs, migration of Tele2’s business support system (“BSS”) to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad
debt collections (representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon
integration with TMNL), direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and
the cancellation of leased telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile
cross-selling, optimization of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related
costs as well as legal audit and tax fees. For risks related to our growth through acquisitions, see “Risk Factors—
_Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Acquisitions and other strategic transactions present many risks,_
_including the risk that we may not be able to integrate newly acquired operations into our business, which may_
_prevent us from realizing the strategic and financial goals contemplated at the time of any such transaction and_
_thus adversely affect our business.”_

We believe that these strategic acquisitions, coupled with our rapid and successful organic growth
initiatives, position us well to capture further market share and grow margins across the business segments in
which we operate.

Further, our lean and digital business model also allows us to benefit from strong operating leverage.
Aside from the lean operating cost base described above, we have also repositioned ourselves to become a
digital telecommunications company with an asset-light fixed model. On September 1, 2018, we demerged our
tower business into Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra). Subsequently, on January
1, 2019, one day prior to the closing of the Tele2 acquisition, we distributed Cignal Infrastructure as a dividend
in kind to Deutsche Telekom, with TMNL continuing to have full access to the contributed infrastructure
through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure
to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP, which is a joint venture of Cellnex and DTCP. Currently, we benefit
from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term
contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional
periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the
Consumer Price Index. Additionally, we continue to hold our own market-leading mobile spectrum portfolio.

In our fixed segment we also have an asset-light model. Our partners, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest,
are conducting the roll-out of our FTTH network, and we do not have any direct fixed access network
ownership. We expect to have access to the over one million FTTH homes that Open Dutch Fiber is scheduled
to roll out to by 2025 in densely-populated areas with strong TMNL mobile customer presence. Under the


-----

Primvest partnership, we expect that we will have FTTH access to approximately 130,000 homes passed. By
the terms of this partnership, we benefit from an initial period of exclusivity and line prices with base rates of
not more than €15 per month, indexed to inflation and subject to certain adjustments. In both of these
partnerships, we have agreed to certain utilization commitments. In addition, we have access to approximately
two million homes passed on KPN’s Open Distribution Framework footprint which is completed by WBA for
a nationwide fixed network footprint.

Such a lean business model has allowed us to achieve total capital expenditure savings of over €700
million, estimated as savings as a result of us not having to allocate and devote capital expenditure on building
a fiber network and mobile towers for five years.

**_Strong cash flow profile with demonstrated resilience and strong cash generation_**

We have historically demonstrated a track record of growth, profitability improvement and strong cash
flow generation. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have been able to maintain growth and increase
profitability, as evidenced by a 29.7% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin in 2020 in comparison to
26.7% in 2019. We believe this demonstrates the resilience of our business and of our company overall. In
addition, we generated a 56% Cash Conversion in 2020 in comparison with an average level of 30% for other
international telecommunication companies.

We delivered revenue growth in a challenging market environment between 2018 and 2020 at a 2%
CAGR. Such growth was mainly driven by a growing subscriber base and stabilizing ARPU levels in the mobile
B2C segment, as well as by strong growth in our B2C fixed business. Historically, our B2C mobile segment
has been the major contributor to revenue at a 4% CAGR between 2018 and 2020, having accounted for 47%
of total revenue in 2020. Our B2C mobile business delivered significant SIM net adds, particularly in the Simpel
and Ben brands, and relatively stable ARPUs among those of our brands that offered the increasingly-popular
unlimited data bundles. Positive developments offset a decrease in roaming revenue as a result of COVID-19–
induced travelling restrictions. Our B2C fixed segment was our fastest-growing segment, growing at a CAGR
of 11% over the past three years. We believe that this strong growth was driven by a successful FMC challenger
strategy which resulted in strong growth in subscriber base that amounted to an additional 133,000 customers
in the past three years.

We also delivered strong performance in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, both in terms of margin
expansion and growth. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin increased from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7%
in 2020 and to 31.1% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL
exhibited a strong CAGR of 16.1% between 2018 and 2020 due to an improved gross margin, declining indirect
costs in absolute terms from cost saving programs and headcount reduction, and realization of Tele2 synergies.

Because we delivered strong revenue and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL expansion through
challenging market conditions, we believe that we are in a position of strength and greater scale to deliver
incremental top line and profitability expansion as market conditions improve.

We also benefit from a strong cash generation profile driven by a solid top-line performance that is
combined with prudent cost management and moderate capital expenditure needs. Our Underlying Operating
Free Cash Flow increased by 53% in 2020 compared to 2019, and is expected to continue on a growth trajectory
going forward as we maintain our capital expenditure-light strategy. Our Cash Conversion was 56% in 2020
and it further increased to 58.9% during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, which is above the
average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies.
