**_Committed and experienced management team_**

Our experienced management team is led by our CEO, Søren Abildgaard, and our CFO, Gero
Niemeyer, each of whom has over 22 years of industry experience. Our management team is seasoned in
running, acquiring and staffing telecommunications businesses and in navigating consumer markets both in The
Netherlands and abroad, and they leverage the expertise they acquired over decades of combined experience at
top-tier telecommunications and consultancy companies such as Telia, Orange, Magenta Telekom, KPN,
Deloitte and Booz Allen Hamilton. More importantly, the management team has a strong track record of
delivering growth from both organic initiatives and strategic acquisitions, and has won and maintained strong
stakeholder support while maintaining a strong debt capital structure. This industry-leading management team
is supported by a deep bench of divisional managers, who in turn are supported by a substantial workforce of
1,870 full-time equivalents as of September 30, 2021. Our employees, 48% of whom are customer-facing, are
highly diverse, being represented by 45 distinct nationalities.

Our management team has reached multiple milestones. Under our management’s leadership, revenue
between 2018 and 2020 increased by a CAGR of 2% due to increasing B2C revenues, and Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA AcL Margin expanded from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 as driven by an improved cost structure
and synergies from the Tele2 acquisition. Furthermore, the team has successfully repositioned our company as
a full FMC challenger in addition to having executed the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions.

**Our Strategy**

We have detailed commercial plans to support our further growth, both in terms of volume and of
value, for all brands and segments. In particular, we have identified a number of key drivers leading to growth
in our business which we believe will preserve our leadership position in the future, namely (i) leverage our
leading position in the B2C mobile market, (ii) capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus, (iii) exploitation
of untapped B2B value pools and expansion in fixed and (iv) optimization of our indirect cost base ratio, with
(v) a commitment to ESG initiatives.

**_Leverage our leading position in B2C mobile and benefit from market tailwinds on 5G monetization,_**
**_unlimited offerings, portfolio optimization and increased value-added services_**

We are a leading B2C mobile operator with a SIM market share of 42% in the B2C mobile postpaid
market, corresponding to 5.1 million SIMs as of December 31, 2020. B2C revenue growth resulted from


-----

stabilizing ARPUs in 2019 and 2020 as well as a growing subscriber base, further supported by growth in
unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2 as well as an increasing demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and
Simpel. We have also seen continued growth in our customer satisfaction. For B2C mobile, we have delivered
the fastest increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade, having outpaced our competitors
in The Netherlands.

Our leading market position provides a strong platform for growth both in terms of volume and value
across all brands and segments. In particular, we plan to grow ARPU through (i) 5G monetization, (ii) unlimited
growth, (iii) portfolio optimizations, (iv) value-added services and (v) FMC growth.

_Drive 5G monetization_

We were the first operator to reach nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band in 2020, and we
believe that we are well positioned to monetize our 5G investments. We offer 5G connectivity per default to
our premium offerings, such as T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan,’ or as an add-on to our value offerings, such as a
€2 p.c.m. add-on for our Tele2 customers. In the future, we plan to extend our 5G offering and continue our
more-for-more portfolio approach on the back of 5G.

_Grow unlimited offerings_

We believe that we hold a leading position in unlimited offerings based on our number of subscribers
and on our having been the first to have introduced an unlimited plan for mobile in The Netherlands. Our
premium offers in the mobile segment are unlimited plans, which we sell for €35 p.c.m. and €25 p.c.m.,
including value added tax (“VAT”), through the T-Mobile and Tele2 brands respectively. T-Mobile’s
‘Unlimited plan’ also includes 5G connectivity by default. Having introduced these offerings in 2017, our
unlimited subscriber base grew from 578,000 subscribers in December 2018 to more than a million subscribers
in June 2021. In May 2021, we also introduced an ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ plan including access to Netflix
and Videoland, a Dutch streaming service. We intend to continue to grow our unlimited offerings in the future
as we believe that unlimited plans are a key value driver in our premium portfolio by increasing customer
loyalty and customer satisfaction, and ultimately result in above-average monthly recurring charges (“MRC”).

_Portfolio optimizations_

Our multi-brand portfolio is a key value driver that allows us to effectively compete in all market
segments. All our brands have a distinctive positioning, minimizing the risk of intra-brand competition. With
approximately 100,000 intra-brand migrations in 2020, creating an average incremental MRC of €1, we have
proven the ability to upsell to customers within our portfolio, accruing value.

_Value-added services_

We believe that by offering value-added services (“VAS”), we distinguish ourselves from our
competitors while increasing ARPU, customer loyalty and customer satisfaction. Our new ‘Unlimited &
Entertainment’ package, described above, is one such example. In addition, T-Mobile offers security options
and add-ons from the music streaming service Deezer. On Tele2, we recently introduced ‘Unlimited for a day’
and ‘Unlimited weekend’ plans which add VAS to a Tele2 portfolio that already includes, among other things,
a 5G priced add-on.

_FMC growth_

Compared to KPN and VFZ, who have mobile FMC penetrations of 65% and 71% as of December
31, 2020, we believe that our FMC penetration of 8% as of December 31, 2020 provides us with ample
opportunity for growth. While KPN and VFZ leverage their large fixed bases, we intend to focus on crossselling our fixed offerings into our leading consumer mobile base. Since FMC customers are more loyal, more
satisfied and have higher monthly bill sizes compared to one-product customers, we expect FMC growth to be
attractive, both, in terms of volume and value.


-----

**_Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus_**

We are a successful challenger in the B2C fixed market with approximately 9% market share by
subscribers in 2020. In the past three years, as our business has grown its subscriber base and revenue at a
CAGR of approximately 11%, marking the fastest growth among our competitors, our market share has grown
from 7% in 2018 to 9% in 2020 and our share of total subscriber gross adds has grown from 17% in 2018 to
20% in 2020. We believe that we have been able to deliver this rapid, market-leading growth by leveraging our
challenger strategy and B2C fixed ARPUs below those of our competition, as our fixed ARPU was
approximately €33 for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, compared to the market average of
approximately €50. Our price leadership is evidenced by our FMC offer which combines 1 Gbit internet speeds
and a T-Mobile Unlimited subscription for a price of €50 p.m. (€25 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile
subscription), compared to €90 p.m. at KPN (€65 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile) and €93 p.m. at VFZ (€65.5
p.m. internet + €27.5 p.m. mobile). These consumer bundle prices are excluding promotions. We believe this
lower fixed-segment ARPU and challenger strategy represents a strong lever to continue attracting valueseeking customers. As illustrated in the chart below, we are able to offer fixed and mobile services at a
significantly lower price than our competitors.

We have an FTTH footprint that covers approximately 1.6 million homes passed on KPN’s and
Primevest’s networks. FTTH is also achieved through the Magenta footprint. We expect a further increase of
approximately 500,000 homes passed by the end of 2021 and the Magenta footprint is expected to significantly
increase homes passed by 2025. Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest partnerships are also key pillars of this
strategy. We have secured exclusive agreements with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in addition to benefitting
from non-exclusive ODF wholesale access to the KPN network, complemented by nationwide wholesale access
via KPN bitstream. For more about our partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, see “—Our
_Competitive Strengths—High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model.” We believe that our_
partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in particular will allow us to grow our fixed subscriber base
and drive margin expansion while maintaining healthy cash profile through our capital expenditure-light
strategy.

In the future, we plan to increase our revenue share through share gains at competitive ARPUs. First,
we plan to tap our mobile subscriber base, which is the largest in The Netherlands, to cross-sell our fixed
offerings to our mobile customers. In our T-Mobile brand, FMC penetration rose from 4% in 2018 to 20% in
2020, whereas overall for our company, FMC penetration increased from 2% in 2018 to 8% in 2020. However,
our FMC penetration remains well below the FMC penetration of our competitors. We believe our penetration
will grow in the future both as a result of a focused sales approach and because we expect more SIMs to become
FMC-eligible in 2021-2022. Planned quality improvements will also help grow and maintain our fixed base
through increased customer satisfaction and loyalty. Second, we will rely on highly-competitive ARPU levels
to further drive market share gains. Going forward, we are considering shifting towards a value-based
proposition by focusing on high-end fiber speeds and value-added services.


-----

**_Exploit untapped B2B value pools and expand in fixed_**

We have established a presence in the B2B market across all segments, namely SOHO/VSE, SMB and
LE/CE, both with our mobile and our fixed offerings which represent 71% and 29%, respectively, of our B2B
revenue in 2020. Our presence extends across all B2B customer segments with our largest exposure in the
SOHO/VSE and LE/CE segments at 36% of B2B mobile service revenues each, followed by the SMB segment
with a 25% revenue share (Source: Company information).

We have increased our revenue market share in the mobile B2B market from 17% in 2018 to 20% in
2020. For the past three years, we have the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator as measured by SIM net adds,
having earned a 43% SIM net adds share in 2020 in comparison with 31% for the closest competitor. We believe
this strategy highlights our success in attracting B2B mobile customers and managing churn well, and we
believe it will fuel our growth in the coming years. In the fixed B2B market, we had a modest revenue market
share of 4% in 2020, affording us an opportunity to grow our presence in the segment in 2021 and beyond.
Among our key priorities, we aim to transform the former Tele2 large enterprise legacy business and expand
into SOHO/VSE with fixed offerings.

Recognizing the above growth path in B2B mobile and the opportunity in B2B fixed, we have defined
a strategy to develop our potential in each of our SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE B2B segments. Our
entrepreneurial approach is built on four key growth drivers, namely (i) FMC offerings in the SOHO/VSE
segment, (ii) an SMB portfolio that combines FMC offerings (a “converged” portfolio) with cloud-based
service enhancements, (iii) a differentiating partner approach and (iv) fixed transformation in the LE/CE
segment.

_FMC offerings in the attractive SOHO/VSE segment_

The SOHO/VSE segment is a highly attractive market for our services, both because of its higher
margins and because we believe we are well-positioned to succeed in this space as a result of its similarities
with the B2C segment where we are a leader in mobile. This segment has rarely been tapped by either T-Mobile
or Tele2 before and it is growing in line with the B2C market. See “—Our Competitive Strengths—Attractive
_telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands.” Given our strength in mobile offerings in particular,_
we intend to target the SOHO/VSE segment by relying on FMC offerings. For example, in September 2021,
we launched a VSE internet offering and related FMC bundling proposition in order to provide the best value
for money, thus opening an additional market segment for us and a potential source of incremental revenue.

_FMC and cloud-enhanced SMB portfolio along with differentiating partnering approach_

We operate in the SMB segment under the T-Mobile and selectively under the Tele2 brand for larger
SMB customers. Our SMB offering comprises a product portfolio focused on FMC and cloud-enhanced
solutions. In the SOHO/VSE segment, we strive for an increase of our Unlimited attach rate as a key value
driver. In addition, we believe that our SMB FMC seats will increase, driven by, among other things, a Microsoft
Teams integration that forms a unified communications solution which we were the first to launch in the Dutch
market. We have a large mobile customer base and, as in the consumer market, we intend to upsell fixed and
unified communications services to our mobile base. In addition to our core connectivity services, we sell a
broad range of communications and cloud-based solutions tailored to the customers’ needs through our
extensive partner portfolio. See also “—Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus” above.

_Fixed transformation in LE/CE_

In the LE/CE segment, we are conducting a transformation of our fixed services in order to realize the
full potential of our extended portfolio. We are in the process of a transition from Tele2 legacy fixed
infrastructure to future-proof transactional stacks in order to accommodate changing customer demands that
request faster and more reliable connections and thus are switching to future-proof fiber-based technologies
which includes a shift from copper to fiber, from VPN to SDWAN and a phase-out of ISDN. We also intend to
supplement our stable fixed wholesale business with international carriers and Internet Service Providers by
wholeselling active services in ODF areas.


-----

**_Optimize our indirect cost base ratio_**

We have an asset-light fixed model and have been focused on creating a lean operational setup since
2016 when we completed a reorganization under the name ‘Lean Telco’ with a headcount reduction of certain
full-time equivalents and a savings target of €30 million. We further streamlined our business with a “3F – Fit
For Future” initiative in 2018-2019, having achieved our further cost savings target of €100 million during the
two year period 2018-2019. The focus in the coming years will be on optimization of our indirect cost base
(“IDC”) ratio through:

    - _Focusing on smart growth by transforming remaining legacy architecture, digitizing processes_
towards self-service, improving fixed product quality and transforming the OSS while focusing
on high-margin segments, thereby increasing our scale;

    - _Countering inflation with efficiencies by investing in marketing automation, robotic process_
automation and first-time right focus to deliver efficiency gains as they increase productivity; and

    - _Continuing to optimize costs by investing in systems and process improvements._

**_Build on our ESG commitments_**

We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several initiatives in order
to improve our impact on the environment and society. We intend to build on our past ESG successes with a
four-pillar ESG program. Our first pillar is sustainability. In 2020, we already used 100% green electricity and
produced 60,000 kWh of renewable energy by using our own solar panels. In 2021, we introduced eco-plastic,
E-SIMs and lighter packaging. Additionally, we have targeted a reduction to carbon neutral emission level by
2026. Furthermore, we will reduce new plastic packaging to zero by 2026. We continue to be involved in our
community in other ways, such as our establishment of two partnerships to accelerate “Innovation for Society”
projects in 2020.

For 2021 and 2022, we aim to set up three impactful “Innovation for Society” partnerships to invest in
e-health, education and smart cities. Going forward, we intend to continue setting up three partnerships a year.
We also focus on digital inclusion, as our goal is to enable more people to be part of the digital society. In 2020,
more than 2,500 people gained access to the digital society with our social SIM program and we reached more
than 15,000 people through our debt prevention program. Our target is to reach more than 25,000 disadvantaged
individuals every year.

Lastly, our management aims to foster an environment in which everyone feels included. We have set
up a dedicated work stream in the diversity and inclusion program focused on activities and awareness within
the company, sharpened our policy on social return and set up a “Back to work” fund. For 2021 and 2022, our
focus is on diversity and inclusion, such as through setting up gender-neutral communication and starting the
dialogue on safety and belonging. Our goal is to be a 100% inclusive organization by 2025.

**History of the Target Group**

TMNL’s primary subsidiaries consist of (i) T-Mobile Netherlands and its subsidiaries, including TMobile Netherlands Retail B.V. (“T-Mobile Netherlands Retail”) and, indirectly through Complex Bidco
B.V., Simpel.nl B.V. (“Simpel”), (ii) T-Mobile Thuis B.V. (“T-Mobile Thuis”) and (iii) T-Mobile Netherlands
Finance B.V. (“T-Mobile Netherlands Finance”). T-Mobile Netherlands Finance holds the financial markets
license for consumer credit issued by AFM and is the contracting party for consumers obtaining credit for
products provided by us.

Our origins can be traced back to two acquisitions in The Netherlands by the group headed by Deutsche
Telekom AG (the “Deutsche Telekom Group”). In September 2002, the Deutsche Telekom Group acquired
the Dutch mobile operator Ben Nederland Holding B.V., whose name was then changed to T-Mobile
Netherlands Holding B.V. in February 2003. The Deutsche Telekom Group also rebranded Ben to T-Mobile in
February 2003, marking the introduction of the T-Mobile brand in The Netherlands. In September 2007, we
acquired Orange Nederland N.V. and Orange Nederland Breedband B.V. from the France Télécom S.A. group.
The fixed line component of this business, acquired under Orange Nederland Breedband B.V., was eventually
rebranded and sold in January 2014 under the Online.nl brand. In 2008, we relaunched Ben as a budget brand.

In April 2010, we acquired the customer base and the ‘Simpel’ brand of the mobile service provider
Simpel Consumenten B.V from its founder Jasper de Rooij. We transferred the customer base and brand back
to de Rooij and investors in August 2014 by concluding an asset purchase agreement, and we also then signed
an MVNO agreement with Simpel, the successor company of the business, under which Simpel continued to
use our network.

In December 2016, we acquired from Vodafone Libertel B.V. the B2C fixed line internet business of
Vodafone Thuis in The Netherlands, which we renamed T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone divested this business as
the result of an antitrust remedy ordered by the European Commission to provide clearance for the VFZ joint
venture. This acquisition added approximately 160,000 customers.

On September 1, 2018, we carved out our tower business by way of a legal demerger (juridische
_splitsing) from TMNL to Cignal Infrastructure (until June 2021, named T-Mobile Infra B.V.). As part of the_
demerger, Cignal Infrastructure was incorporated as a 100% subsidiary of T-Mobile Netherlands. On December
17, 2018, T-Mobile Netherlands and Cignal Infrastructure entered into a master services agreement governing
the relationship between us and Cignal Infrastructure and the terms and conditions of our access to these passive
infrastructure elements. Ultimately, Cignal Infrastructure was distributed as a dividend in kind to Deutsche
Telekom on January 1, 2019. As part of a later transfer of Cignal Infrastructure to Cellnex Netherlands B.V.,
on May 27, 2021 T-Mobile Netherlands and Cignal Infrastructure entered into an amended and restated master
lease agreement which replaced the master services agreement dated December 17, 2018.


-----

On January 2, 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2. The seller, Tele2 Sweden, received
approximately €190 million in cash and 25% of the issued and outstanding shares of TMNL. This transaction
was subject to the approval of European antitrust authorities, and final and unconditional approval was obtained
from the European Commission on November 27, 2018. This acquisition better enabled us to become an
integrated telecommunications provider by deepening our capacity to offer fixed and mobile subscriptions.

On December 1, 2020, we acquired Simpel pursuant to the exercise of a call option we had signed in
July 2019 for the acquisition of 100% of Complex Bidco B.V. and its 100% subsidiary, Simpel. This transaction
gained the unconditional approval of the ACM on November 16, 2020. Simpel had previously exclusively
marketed SIM-only subscriptions through its own website, using SIM cards that operated on the T‑Mobile
Netherlands network. This acquisition was effectuated in order to secure mobile market shares, create synergies,
and make us more competitive in the SIM-only consumer market.

**Geography**

Our business operates entirely in The Netherlands and all of our revenue is generated from The
Netherlands.

_B2C segment_

The B2C segment represents our largest customer segment, constituting 74.9% and 79.0% of our net
revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021, respectively.
Customers in this segment are offered landline, mobile phone, broadband and bundled services mainly marketed
under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands. Specifically, we provide our B2C customers with the
following multi-brand portfolio of services, aiming to cover all segments of the market:

    - Mobile services: we provide voice services, SMS/MMS and mobile broadband through our own
networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra, with 2G scheduled to be phased out shortly. We offer
consumers mobile flexible bundled and unbundled service packages through our key brands:

      - T-Mobile: T-Mobile is our premium B2C mobile brand, focusing on premium-seekers and
households. It offers 24-month and 12-month subscriptions and combines premium
handset sales. This brand offers limited and unlimited data, text, and talk packages on both
4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, it also offers a fixed internet package with
an option to purchase voice and TV add-ons, as well as FMC packages. We market our TMobile brand through an omni-channel approach, leveraging retail stores, online sales,
telesales and indirect sales. T-Mobile’s key competitors include KPN and VFZ.


-----

      - Tele2: Tele2 is our value brand, aimed at value-seekers and digital natives. It also offers
limited and unlimited bundles with 5G as an add-on, and it also offers handsets. We intend
Tele2 to operate within its own value segment.

      - Ben: Ben is our budget-conscious brand. It offers SIM-only subscriptions in the 4G
spectrum along with a basic portfolio of handsets. Key competitors include Simyo and
Hollandsnieuwe, which are KPN’s and VFZ’s budget brands, respectively.

      - Simpel: Simpel is our low-budget mobile brand. It offers SIM-only subscriptions on the
4G spectrum exclusively through its website. Simpel’s key competitor is Youfone, which
is an MVNO on the KPN network.

    - Fixed services: Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide fixed broadband, TV and fixed
voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. FTTH is offered via Primevest, Open
Dutch Fiber and KPN networks based on unbundled access through an ODF access as well as
VULA and WBA access with KPN. We also use KPN’s copper network based on unbundled
access through MDF, VULA and WBA. We also offer to combine T-Mobile Thuis’s fixed service
with T-Mobile or Tele2 subscriptions, as these FMC packages offer discounts and other benefits
for the customer in comparison to standalone service purchase.

_B2B segment_

Our B2B segment is dedicated to meeting the telecommunications needs of companies of all types and
sizes as we aim to offer telecommunications solutions and cloud based services to businesses to accompany
them in their growth. The B2B segment constituted 18.2% and 17.5% of our revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021, respectively.

For both our SOHO/VSE customers and our SMB customers, we offer FMC bundles that combine
fixed telephony landline, mobile phone, SMS/MMS, broadband and data services, as well as other value-added
services such as data centers, Unified Communications, security, cloud, storage, virtual PBX, email and videoconferencing. These bundled services allow clients access to broadband internet and fixed and mobile telephony
services which are invoiced jointly at competitive prices. Contracts from our LE/CE customers, by contrast, are
typically awarded by customized, separate mobile and fixed services tenders, and may also include data network
services.

We additionally offer standalone B2B mobile services, notably through our ‘@Work’ plans which
allow subscribers to adjust monthly their data limits and which include unlimited data plan choices. B2B mobile
revenues accounted for approximately 10% of our total revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020 and for
the past three years we have been the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator in the Dutch telecommunications
market as measured by net adds.

For SMB and LE/CE customers, fixed internet services are currently offered under the Tele2 brand
while SOHO/VSE customers are currently offered fixed internet services under the T-Mobile brand.

_Other_

We have also entered into several wholesale agreements for the sale of certain services, such as
Ethernet connections or access to our mobile radio networks, to other providers of mobile and fixed
telecommunications services. These services are consolidated in the Other segment, which constituted 6.9%
and 3.6% of our total company revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended
September 30, 2021, respectively.

**Our Network**

Our network is distributed throughout The Netherlands and provides both fixed line and mobile
services to customers, routing calls and data, including circuit switching services, packages switching,
authentication, data bridge with other networks, upload to the internet, value added services and interconnection


-----

to other networks. Although we own our mobile network, we do not generally own the passive infrastructure of
either our mobile or fixed networks but lease them or contract for access to them from other companies.

**_Mobile networks and spectrum_**

As of September 30, 2021, our national access network comprised 4,956 macro outdoor sites. For an
overview of the frequency bands on which these nodes are used to broadcast our network, see “—Licenses”
below. Currently, our 4G mobile network reaches approximately 99.98% of the Dutch population and our 5G
network reaches 92.31% of the Dutch population.

**_Fixed networks_**

Our fixed internet service is generally offered under the T-Mobile Thuis brand. The Magenta footprint
of our fixed internet service offers fiber internet through an ODF access as a result of several agreements and
partnerships. We have agreements with Reggefiber Operator B.V., a member of the KPN group, to provide
ODF access to their fiber network, which currently extends to 2 million homes passed as of September 30,
2021. Either party under certain conditions may terminate these agreements, including the condition that they
may be terminated by Reggefiber Operator B.V. with two years’ notice if Reggefiber Operator B.V. is no longer
required by law or regulation to provide access to its fiber grid. We also have an exclusive agreement to be the
anchor tenant of Open Dutch Fiber, a joint venture between KKR and Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners,
which aims to deploy to one million homes passed by 2025, mainly in dense urban areas with no targeted
overbuild of existing FTTH. Finally, we have an agreement with Primevest Capital Partners according to which
we will serve as an anchor tenant on a FTTH, very high speed internet network that Primevest Capital Partners
and their construction partner, VolkerWessels, will build. Following the pilot in The Hague’s Segbroek area,
this joint venture will build or has already built fiber networks in The Hague’s Loosduinen area as well as
Eindhoven and Rotterdam. This network is expected to extend to over 130,000 homes passed by mid-2022.
Under the terms of both of these agreements we are obligated to maintain certain utilization rates which we
expect to be able to maintain.

Most of the remainder of our nationwide fixed internet footprint currently relies upon KPN providing
us with WBA, MDF, ODF and VULA, whether through agreements that we have made with KPN and its
affiliates or through legacy contracts that we have inherited upon acquiring Tele2. This involves wholesale
broadband access by means of virtual unbundled local access under an open wholesale model. For more
information about our wholesale agreements with KPN, see “—Material Contracts—KPN Wholesale
_Agreements.”_

**Marketing and Sales**

_B2C segment_

We use different sales channels to market our products and services with an aim to optimize customer
reach and reduce costs. Our main sales channels are the following:

    - Exclusive retail stores: we currently operate 124 retail stores across The Netherlands, with a
slightly higher concentration in the _Randstad, the metropolitan area comprising Amsterdam,_
Rotterdam, Utrecht and The Hague. As of March 31, 2021, we operated these shops with an
average of 3.9 FTE per shop. In addition to providing for sales of traditional mobile offerings, the
stores represent an opportunity to market fixed broadband and bundled packages. We rent all shop
buildings from third parties and have incorporated our retail business in a separate legal entity, TMobile Netherlands Retail.

    - Indirect sales: we leverage relationships with key telecommunications partners to sell T-Mobile-,
Tele2- and Ben-branded products both online and through several offline resellers with presence
in more than 500 stores nationwide. Additionally, in fiber roll-out areas, we engage door-to-door
partners to sell T-Mobile Thuis-branded fixed internet.


-----

    - Online sales: we have prioritized the growth of our online sales channel, which benefits from
lower costs than brick-and-mortar storefront. We reached a high benchmark in online sales, with
approximately 46% of overall sales implemented through digital channels in 2020, excluding our
indirect online sales. Each brand has its own brand-specific website and a dedicated digital
marketing strategy supported by big data platforms to optimize media investment, traffic and
conversion rates. Simpel’s online sales channel represents its only platform for customer
interaction.

    - Telesales: we sell our products and services by telephone through our own and third-party call
centers, using both active direct to consumer telephone marketing and passive advertising in print,
online and television media. Our telesales channel not only focuses on customer retention but also
serves as important up-selling and cross-selling routes, as into fixed or FMC packages.

_B2B segment_

In our B2B segment, we take a differentiated approach to sales with a focus on maximizing growth
while optimizing cost to sell. At the SOHO/VSE level, we employ multiple distribution channels, including
telesales, our retail shops, online sales through our B2B web shop and sales through retail partners. At the SMB
level we rely mainly on dedicated retail partners, with some direct business channels. Finally, at the LE/CE
level, we employ key account management for all our clients, deploying both retention and acquisition teams.

**Information Technology**

Our Magenta business support system (“BSS”) stack forms the foundation for consolidating our brands
and customer segments into a suite of systems. The Magenta stack deploys industry-leading BSS systems, such
as Salesforce, Tibco, BSCS, Netcracker and SAP, and features a high degree of consolidation with no duplicate
systems. Services under the Ben brand are mostly based on the Magenta BSS systems but with independent
sales systems and customer relationship management provided by SugarCRM. The Simpel brand features a
fully outsourced, standalone BSS environment, while a legacy Tele2 BSS is maintained by Cognizant and
services a small number of LE/CE customers.

We rely on Atos, Wipro and Netcracker for application development and maintenance services as well
as, in the case of Atos and Wipro, infrastructure delivery and management on Microsoft Azure and Amazon
Web Services, as well as other related services. Wipro also provides our external 24x7 IT service desk.
Salesforce provides us its customer relationship management system.

Our IT infrastructure is based on a hybrid architecture deployed in private and public clouds and houses
a large number of applications for our business units and customers. We operate on a “cloud first” principle
such that new workloads are deployed to the public cloud by default, and more than 90% of the Magenta BSS
has been migrated to the cloud. However, in recognizing that not all IT workloads are cloud-ready, we migrate
our applications to the public or private cloud based on the requirements of our business technology, taking into
account our security-by-design framework, which aims to guarantee the security of our applications and our
compliance with relevant regulations. All personnel involved in software development activities are required to
follow an obligatory security awareness and security-by-design e-learning.

We have implemented polices and systems for GDPR compliance that consist of, among other things,
a data processing register, privacy statements for customers and employees, a group security policy, a data
retention policy, a data breach and notification policy and internal instructions on how to deal with data subjects’
rights and requests. Our designated, full-time Data Privacy Officer (“DPO”) is registered with AP and is
supported by (i) a Privacy and Complaints team, (ii) a Privacy and Compliance Specialist, (iii) risk officers,
who are a part of our Governance, Risk Management and Compliance Department and (iv) by the legal
department. In addition to providing our employees with our data protection policy along with instructions
regarding the secure handling of data, we require our employees to complete a GDPR e-learning that is repeated
every two years. We are closely monitoring developments regarding the European Commission’s proposal for
an ePrivacy Regulation.

Following the Acquisition, we will have to deal on a standalone basis with certain procedures that until
now had been dealt with through Deutsche Telekom AG and its affiliates, or through frameworks arranged by


-----

Deutsche Telekom AG and its affiliates, such as (i) our license to the T-Mobile brand, which automatically

to extend with Deutsche Telekom AG once the term of the license which we will acquire in connection with
the Acquisition expires, (ii) services that the Deutsche Telekom Group provided to us relating to IT, network,
marketing, personnel and procurement, (iii) cash pooling and cash management arrangements for financing and
treasury solutions, (iv) existing parent guarantees to third parties for our benefit and (v) insurance policies. In
this regard, as a condition of completing of the Acquisition, we will enter into a transitional services agreement
with Deutsche Telekom AG pursuant to which the Deutsche Telekom AG and/or its affiliates would agree to

services from Deutsche Telekom and/or its affiliates for up to five years after the Acquisition. See also “Risk

In addition to altering the terms of our license of the T-Mobile brand in connection with the Acquisition
(see “—Material Contracts—T-Mobile License Agreement”), under the transitional services agreement that will

management and messaging platforms, RAN and mobile core, and cloud services. We may incur significant

_have had during the period when we were owned by Deutsche Telekom.” Additionally, and among other_

**Legal Proceedings**

We are involved in legal, regulatory, tax and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course
of our business. The proceedings initiated against us may include, among others, the following categories of
claims: claims by or on behalf of customers on grounds such as alleged misrepresentation, breach of service or
license terms, breach of telecommunications, consumer, health, privacy and unauthorized access and safety
regulations, or intellectual property claims primarily relating to alleged copyright infringement brought by
copyright collection entities; claims by suppliers and other telecommunications providers, including
telecommunications providers who use our network pursuant to wholesale services arrangements; claims by
employees; claims by tax authorities with respect to tax matters such as VAT, transfer taxes and property tax;
and claims by other administrative bodies or agencies such as claims for breach of data protection or consumer
protection regulations.

In line with an agreement we made with Dutch tax authorities in the past, we currently do not charge
VAT over disconnection fees. The Dutch tax authorities are having an internal discussion to determine their
view in this matter. The Dutch tax authorities may challenge our view that the disconnection fees are not subject
to VAT. Any such action may have material adverse effect on our reputation, financial condition or results of
operations.

Additionally, we are currently being investigated by the AT, in joint cooperation with the AP,
regarding alleged breaches of data protection and telecommunications laws in connection with our sharing
certain aggregated and anonymized customer location data with CBS under a partnership with CBS that has
since terminated. If it finds against us, the AT could impose a fine of up to €900,000. For more information
about the AT investigation, see “Risk Factors—We face risks arising from the outcome of various criminal,
_civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.”_

Prior to changing our debt collection processes and agencies in the first quarter of 2020, we sold
customer invoice receivables to Direct Pay, who, as of September 30, 2021, continues to owe us €4.3 million
under our agreement with them, which we have currently provisioned as bad debt. However, Direct Pay has
submitted claims to us in the aggregate amount of €7.5 million, first, that we have not provided sufficient
documentation regarding customer contracts and invoices, and second, that it lost profits due to unforeseen


-----

changes in the regulatory environment that diminished its ability to collect on the debts, and that we should
share the burden of such alleged lost profits. We discussed the matter with Direct Pay in the course of the third
quarter of 2021 but have been unable to resolve the dispute amicably thus far. We or Direct Pay may initiate
legal proceedings if we are not able to resolve this matter.

Further, we have been involved in litigation involving our prior and discontinued offer of ‘free
handsets’ to consumers along with mobile subscriptions, referred to as ‘all-in subscriptions.’ In 2014 and 2016,
the Supreme Court of The Netherlands gave interlocutory decisions in which it concluded that such offerings
were not compliant with statutory provisions on installment purchases, credit transactions and credit
agreements. We had voluntarily stopped offering such all-in subscriptions on September 9, 2014 for direct sales
and January 18, 2015 for indirect sales. Tele2, which we subsequently acquired, also offered all-in subscriptions
and stopped offering them on September 1, 2014. Subsequently, multiple claims vehicles and foundations have
solicited individuals to initiate mass claims against telecommunications providers who offered all-in
subscriptions. We have been in contact with several vehicles and foundations in order to reach a settlement and
have reached a settlement with Consumentenbond and ConsumentenClaim in October 2020 in particular
regarding the period and type of mobile subscription eligible for compensation as well as the calculation method
for the amount of compensation per customer. We have finalized processing claims under this settlement.
However, this settlement does not cover claims submitted by other claims vehicles and foundations. For
instance, we are in settlement discussions with MobiClaim in particular regarding potential claims on the same
matter from claimants who are not party to any settlements thus far, and ConTel approached us in mid-2021 to
express a willingness to pursue certain claims that have been pending since 2016. Such negotiations may fail
and it is possible that MobiClaim or ConTel will initiate legal proceedings.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not aware of any other legal, administrative,
judicial, regulatory, tax or arbitral proceedings or investigations (including any pending or threatened
proceedings or investigations) that are likely to have, or have had, individually or in the aggregate, a material
adverse effect on our reputation, financial condition or results of operations. The outcome of legal proceedings
and investigations, however, can be extremely difficult to predict with certainty, and we can offer no assurances
in this regard. See also “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We face risks
_arising from the outcome of various criminal, civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.”_

**Environmental, Social and Governance Matters**

We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations relating to land use, environmental protection and
health and safety in connection with our ownership of real property and other operations. While we could incur
costs, such as clean-up costs, fines and third-party claims for property damage or personal injury as a result of
violations of or liabilities under such laws or regulations, we believe we substantially comply with the applicable

Given the scope of our activities and the property, plant and equipment we own or operate, we believe that there

provisions, relating to environmental matters.

With regards to our mobile network, we comply with regulations setting out rules governing the public
radio domain, restrictions on radio-electric emissions and health protection measures. Radiocommunications

and in accordance with Dutch recommendations, to safeguard public health.

We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several commitments in
order to improve our impact on the environment and society. For a description of some of our ESG initiatives,
see “—Our Strategy— Build on our ESG commitments” above.

**_KPN Wholesale Agreements_**

Between 1998 and 2018, we or our legal predecessors executed a series of non-exclusive framework
agreements with KPN and affiliated companies that provide us access to their copper and fiber fixed internet
networks. These agreements are generally effectively of indefinite length and provide various termination rights
to both T-Mobile Netherlands or its subsidiaries and to KPN and its affiliates. In particular, under these
framework agreements, KPN or its affiliates may terminate the agreements or services under the agreements
with between two months’ and two years’ notice. These agreements provide us with MDF access services,
WBA on the OWM and through VULA, and usage rights to fiber networks. We are largely dependent on
wholesale access to KPN’s fixed network for both bitstream access and (virtual) unbundled wholesale access
products.

Wholesale access to KPN’s fixed network was previously regulated by the ACM based on “significant
market power” (“SMP”) provisions in the Dutch Telecommunications Act. As a result of a March 2020 decision
by the CBb, no such SMP provisions apply and KPN is no longer required to provide access to its copper and
fiber networks. As we can no longer rely on the former regulatory framework, KPN and its affiliates could
potentially charge prices for access without regulatory restriction or deny us access. At the moment we are
largely protected against price increases for the wholesale access services we purchase from KPN and their
affiliates by the terms of the contracts that we have concluded with them, with the exception of our contracts
for MDF access, where we lack such price protection. At our request, the ACM is reviewing ways of restoring
regulation to KPN’s fiber network through SMP or through competent authorities’ ability to impose symmetric
regulation as provided for in the European Electronic Communications Code.

**_Cignal Infrastructure Master Services Agreement_**

As a result of the carve-out of our passive telecommunications tower infrastructure to a separate legal
entity in 2018 (see “—History of the Target Group”), in December 2018 we signed a master services agreement
with Cignal Infrastructure, then known as T-Mobile Infra B.V., which governed the relationship between us
and the demerged tower business. Our current relationship is governed by an amended and restated master lease
agreement which we signed with Cignal Infrastructure on May 27, 2021. Under the agreement, we benefit from
access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for
an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10
years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price
Index.

**_Primevest Partners Partnership_**

On April 9, 2019 we signed an agreement with PCIF NL I S.A.R.L., a subsidiary of Primevest Partners,
according to which we will serve as an anchor tenant on a FTTH, very high speed internet network that
Primevest Capital Partners and VolkerWessels will build. Following the pilot in The Hague’s Segbroek area,
this joint venture will build or has already built fiber networks in The Hague’s Loosduinen area as well as
Eindhoven and Rotterdam. This network is expected to extend to over 130,000 homes passed by mid-2022.

**_Open Dutch Fiber Partnership_**

RootsOpCo B.V. (“Open Dutch Fiber”) is a joint venture between KKR as majority shareholder
(80%) and Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners as minority shareholder (20%) which has committed to rolling


-----

out a fiber network to at least one million households in The Netherlands over a five-year period. The project
involves total investments into Open Dutch Fiber of at least €700 million.

On April 1, 2021, we signed an agreement to become Open Dutch Fiber’s anchor tenant under a 20year contract in which the base wholesale tariff we will be charged ranges from €13 to €15 per month, per line,
subject to certain adjustments, including an index to the Consumer Price Index with a cap of 3% p.a. We were
not involved in, and are not a party to, agreements that relate to the debt or equity financing of the Open Dutch
Fiber project.

**_T-Mobile License Agreement_**

We license the T-Mobile brand and various Deutsche Telekom AG trademarks and domain names
under a December 22, 2004 sublicense agreement between T-Mobile Netherlands and T-Mobile Global Holding
GmbH, then a member of the Deutsche Telekom Group who as licensor eventually merged into Deutsche
Telekom AG. This sub-license incorporates by reference the terms of a December 22, 2004 license agreement
between Deutsche Telekom AG and T-Mobile International AG & Co. KG. According to the terms of these
agreements, as amended, we license the T-Mobile brand for a fixed percentage of the revenue we derive from
the use of the T-Mobile brand. Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, upon completion of the
Acquisition we will sign a non-exclusive agreement with Deutsche Telekom AG on agreed terms under which
we will license the T-Mobile brand from them for a fixed percentage of the revenue we derive from the use of
the T-Mobile brand for an initial term of five years, extendable by mutual consent.

**_Tele2 License Agreement_**

We use the Tele2 brand under an eight-year license agreement with Tele2 Sweden dated February 11,
2019, according to which we make quarterly payments to Tele2 Sweden out of the revenues from sales under
the Tele2 brand. Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, upon completion of the Acquisition we will
sign a non-exclusive agreement with Tele2 Sweden under which we license the T-Mobile brand for them for a
certain percentage of our Tele2-branded revenue for an initial term of ten years, with such percentage varying
over that term according to a schedule.
