**REGULATION**

**General**

Our business is subject to various regulatory requirements and obligations including communications
and broadcasting laws, general antitrust law, environmental, health and safety laws, planning and construction
laws, consumer protection laws as well as technical and other regulations in each of the jurisdictions in which
we operate. Such laws and regulations are promulgated and enforced to varying degrees by supranational
regulators such as the European Commission (“Commission”) and national, state, regional and local authorities.
The regulatory environment can have a material effect on our activities. Certain key provisions of the
regulations governing our activities in The Netherlands as of the date of this Offering Memorandum are set
forth below. This description is not intended to be an exhaustive description of all regulation in this area nor a
review of specific obligations which have been imposed on us.

**Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services**

**_Summary of European regulation_**

In the last eighteen (18) years, the telecommunications market in the European Union has been
gradually deregulated.

In March 2002, the European Union approved a new regulatory framework for electronic
communications (the “RF” or “regulatory framework”), in order to adopt a harmonized regulatory framework
among the Member States.

The RF was originally composed of five directives (the “Directives”):

    - _Framework directive: a common regulatory framework for electronic communication networks_
and services that establishes the general principles of the RF, as well as the procedure that should
be followed by national regulating authorities to impose _ex ante obligations on operators with_
significant market power (“SMP”).

    - _Universal service directive: this regulates the universal service and the rights of users of_
communication networks and services.

    - _Access directive: this regulates access to electronic communication networks and their_
interconnection.

    - _Authorization directive: this regulates the authorization of communication networks and services;_
and

    - _Directive on privacy and electronic communications: this regulates the processing of personal_
data and the protection of privacy in electronic communications.

This regulatory framework also includes three key elements:

    - a recommendation from the European Commission on important markets subject to _ex ante_
regulation (the “Market Recommendation”);

    - guidelines on market analysis and the assessment of SMP (the “Guidelines”); and

    - the decision on a regulatory framework for the radio-electric spectrum.

In November 2009, the regulatory package on electronic communications was revised in a process that
took two years, with the involvement of the European Commission, Parliament and Council. The main change
consisted of the increase in the powers of the Commission to coordinate the use of the radio-electric spectrum,
and the Commission was also granted greater powers regarding the obligations that national regulatory


-----

authorities could impose on operators with significant market power, specifically when these could create
barriers to the single market or violate EU legislation.

The revised directives also contain a set of provisions relating to new generation networks, consumer
rights and (as an exceptional measure) the functional separation of vertically-integrated companies. This
measure is adopted when the regulatory authority concludes that the obligations imposed by national regulatory
authorities on operators with significant market power in accordance with applicable legislation have not
produced effective competition and there are major, persistent competition problems and/or market risks related
to the wholesale provision of certain access markets.

In 2007, a new market recommendation was adopted by the Commission, repealing and replacing the
previous 2003 Market Recommendation, by virtue of which the markets potentially subject to ex ante regulation
were reduced from eighteen to seven . This reduction included most retail markets, mobile network access
markets and the broadcast market.

In November 2009, the European Parliament and the Regulation of the European Council created the
Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (the “BEREC”), a European body of national
regulatory authorities that acts as a consultative committee of the European Commission. The BEREC began
its activities in January 2010. The regulatory framework applicable to this body was changed by European
Regulations on December 11, 2018.

Since then, the European Commission has updated its recommendation for markets in the 2014 Market
Recommendation, removing the fixed access retail markets and wholesale rented lines with the markets subject
to ex ante regulation being reduced to four. Specifically, termination markets on fixed and mobile networks
(markets 1 and 2, respectively) and the access market to broadband in its residential and business sectors
(markets 3a, 3b and 4) were retained. Subsequently in 2020 the European Commission adopted a new
Recommendation (2020/2245) on relevant markets, reducing its remaining defined markets to a market for
wholesale local access provided at a fixed location (now market 1) and wholesale dedicated capacity (now
market 2). The recommendation became effective on December 21, 2020. It has also adopted measures aimed
at promoting the development of broadband, through the adoption of: (i) recommendations in 2010 and 2013
promoting greater harmonization and effectiveness of corrective measures for NRAs (national regulatory
authorities) concerning operators with significant market power with access to NGNs (new generation
networks); (ii) a European Directive to facilitate the roll-out of networks, and (iii) a new commission decision
on the spectrum of the following frequencies: 790-862 MHz, 880-915 MHz, 925-960 MHz, 1,710-1,785 MHz,
1,805-1,880 MHz, 1,900 -1,980 MHz, 2,010 – 2,025 MHz, 2,110– 2,170 MHz, 2.5 -2.69 GHz, and 3.4-3.8 GHz.

On July 1, 2012 Regulation (EU) No. 531/2012 on public communications networks in the EU entered
into force, with the ultimate aim of removing the differences between international roaming tariffs (the
“Regulation 531/2012”) by establishing an internal market for communication services.

This regulation makes it possible for:

    - mobile operators to use the networks of other operators in Member States at regulated wholesale
prices; and

    - clients to use voice, SMS and data services from an alternative service provider without changing
their telephone, telephone number or SIM card.

The application of regulation 531/2012 started on July 1, 2014. On June 30, 2015, the Commission
announced that it had reached a commitment with the European Parliament and the Council to eliminate excess
costs for users starting on June 15, 2017 (“RLAH”—roam like at home) and establish the principle of net
neutrality on April 30, 2016.

In November 2015, Regulation 2015/2120 entered into force, which establishes the measures to
safeguard open internet access and among other regulations, modifies Regulation 531/2012 regarding roaming.
The principle of net neutrality must ensure that all traffic that circulates through networks receives the same
treatment, irrespective of its content, source or destination. Therefore, it prohibits commercial practices that


-----

consist of blocking traffic, slowing down speed and discriminating against services. The BEREC guidelines
were published on August 30, 2016, detailing the terms of the European Regulation in order to ensure universal
internet access with a minimum quality, known as the “best effort.”

The 2015/2120 European Regulation foresaw the removal of roaming surcharges from June 2017 and
established a maximum price calendar applicable until April 2016 and for the period from April 2016 to June
2017. It also introduced specific restrictions to ensure fair use of the roaming service by users to prevent abuses
of such permanent roaming. On December 15, 2016, the European Commission approved the Regulation that
details the fair use policy and the methodology to ensure the sustainability of the removal of the roaming
surcharge for roaming providers. The BEREC Guidelines concerning the retail roaming market were published
on March 27, 2017, updating the 2016 guidelines to include and specify all the provisions introduced by the
2015 Regulations and the European Commission’s 2016 Implementing Regulations. In May 2017, Regulations
were approved changing the 2012 roaming Regulations regarding wholesale roaming markets. In February
2021, the European Commission proposed a new Regulation governing roaming, which seeks to extend the
RLAH rules and inter alia improve service levels when roaming. The new Regulation is still subject to the
European Union legislative process and may therefore be modified before entering into force. For example, a
European Parliament Committee has voted to reduce wholesale roaming fees charged between operators. Until
a final Regulation enters into force, the exact implications will remain uncertain.

In 2013, the EU announced its cyber security strategy, which included a series of measures, among
them a newly proposed Directive on network and information systems security. This regulatory proposal would
guarantee a reliable information society throughout the EU, where internet providers are also subject to security
requirements. This Directive ((EU) no. – 2016/1148)) was definitively adopted in August 2016.

In January 2012, the European Commission announced the proposed replacement for Data Protection
Directive 95/46/CE with the new General Data Protection Regulation, which is applicable to providers that
process personal data in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not. The
Regulation was published on May 4, 2016 and became application from May 25, 2018.

One of the ten strategic priorities of the European Commission for coming years is the strategy of a
digital single market adopted on May 6, 2015 and which approved several initiatives organized into three pillars
were approved: (i) better access for consumers and businesses to digital goods and services across Europe; (ii)
maximizing the growth potential of the digital economy, and (iii) creating the right conditions and a level
playing field for digital networks and innovative services to flourish. This pillar provided for the review of the
new telecommunications regulatory framework. Said review led to Directive (EU) No. 2018/1972 of the
European Parliament and the Council of December 11, 2018 that established the European Electronic
Communications Code. This is a harmonized framework to regulate electronic communication networks,
electronic communication services, associated resources and services and some aspects of terminal equipment.
The objective of the aforementioned code is to promote competition, encourage investment and strengthen the
internal market and consumer rights.

In 2016, the Commission also presented an action plan for the roll-out of 5G which provided a common
calendar in the EU for its coordinated commercial commissioning in 2020, as well as cooperation between
Member States and interested parties in the sector to determine and allocate spectrum bands to 5G, organize 5G
pan-European trials starting in 2018, promote worldwide common 5G regulations and encourage the adoption
of national plans for the roll-out of 5G in all Member States.

**_Competition Regulation_**

EU competition legislation applies to all its Member States.

In particular, Article 101 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (the “TFEU”)
prohibits all agreements between companies, decisions by associations of undertakings and concerted practices,
which may affect trade between Member States and which have as their object or effect the prevention,
restriction or distortion of competition within the European Union. Article 102 of the TFEU prohibits the abuse
by one or more companies of a dominant position within the internal market or a substantial part of it. Article
107 of the TFEU prohibits all aid provided by a Member State or through state resources that falsifies or


-----

threatens to falsify competition, by favoring specific companies or the production of specific products that affect
trade between Member States. Finally, EU Regulations on merger control demand that all mergers and
acquisitions that exceed specific turnover thresholds are notified to the European Commission for their review,
and not to the national competition authorities. The regulations prohibit mergers if they affect real competition
within the internal market or a substantial part of it, particularly as a consequence of the creation of
strengthening of a dominant position in the market. Both the European Commission and the national
competition authorities and courts have to apply European legislation on competition (although only the
European Commission has the authority to apply the law relating to state aid). In addition, there are similar
competition regulations in the national legislation of each state, and national and regional competition
authorities and courts have the authority to oversee compliance with these regulations.

**_National regulatory authorities in The Netherlands_**

_Overview_

The video distribution, broadband internet, fixed-line telephony and mobile businesses are regulated
at the EU level. In The Netherlands, these regulations are implemented through the Telecommunicatiewet (the
Dutch Telecommunications Act, “DTA”), the Mediawet (the Dutch Media Act, “DMA”), the Wet beveiliging
_network en informatiesystemen (the Network and Information Systems Security Act, “NNIS”) and related_
legislation and regulations. The ACM in which the former Independent Post and Telecommunications Authority
(“OPTA,” _Onafhankelijke Post en Telecommunicatie Autoriteit) as well as the former Dutch Competition_
Authority (“NMa,” _Nederlandse Mededingings autoriteit) have been integrated, and the Dutch_
Radiocommunications Agency (“AT,” _Agentschap Telecom) supervise and enforce compliance with certain_
parts of the DTA. Pursuant to the DTA, the ACM is designated as a National Regulatory Authority (NRA). The
Dutch Media Authority (“CvdM,” Commissariaat voor de Media) is authorized to enforce compliance with the
DMA. The AT is authorized to enforce the NISS with regard to network and information system providers and
any mandatory notifications of cybersecurity incidents have to be made to The Netherlands National Cyber
Security Center (“NCSC,” _Nationaal Cyber Security Centrum). The Privacy Authority (“AP”) (Autoriteit_
_Persoonsgegevens) supervises and enforces compliance with privacy legislation._

In addition to complying with industry specific regimes, we must comply with both specific and
general legislation concerning, among other areas, competition, data protection, data retention, cyber security,
internet service provider liability, consumer protection, and e-commerce. The DTA comprises a wide variety
of rights and obligations relevant to the provision of public electronic communications networks and services.
Certain key provisions included in the DTA are described below, but this description is not intended to be a
comprehensive description of all regulations in this area.

_Licensing_

The DTA contains a system of general authorizations and provides a possibility to charge supervision
costs, generally based on a percentage of the generated revenues or in case of certain specific activities a fixed
fee applied for the activity conducted by ACM. A provider of a public electronic communications network or
service needs to notify the ACM of its network or service, who will register the notification. The purpose of the
notification is to increase transparency and to ensure effective regulation and does not constitute a formal
condition for market entry.

With regard to scarce resources such as telephone numbers and frequencies, a system of (individual)
licensing or allocation by the ACM applies. The ACM, on request, administers telephone number allocation in
line with the national phone number plan. The Ministry of Economic Affairs, including through AT, administers
the frequency spectrum (including auction processes and supervision) and grants licenses with regard to the use
of frequencies. Licenses for frequencies are issued upon application, either on a first-come-first-serve basis,
beauty contest or auction. A frequency license confers the right to use a specific set of frequencies in a specific
band for a specific period of time and under specific conditions, such as coverage obligations. Frequency
licenses are transferable with permission from the Minister of Economic Affairs. In addition to one-off license
fees, holders of licenses have to pay annual supervision costs, based on the amount of spectrum held. We hold
licenses in the 700, 800, 900, 1,400, 1,800, 2,100, and 2,600 MHz bands to provide 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G
communications in The Netherlands. In 2020, we acquired new licenses in the 700 MHz, 1,400 MHz band and


-----

were able to re-acquire licenses in the 2,100 MHz bands, all for a period of 20 years. The other licenses will
expire in 2030. The Dutch Government is planning to auction 300 MHz in the 3.5 GHz band, which due to
delays is presently expected to occur in the second half of 2022, but could be delayed even further. As of
December 31, 2020, we hold approximately 38% of the total mobile spectrum licenses in The Netherlands,
which are used to deliver mobile services.

_Access, Interoperability and Interconnection_

All providers of public electronic communications networks or services who control access to endusers are obliged to enter into good-faith negotiations upon the request of a competitor to conclude an
interoperability agreement. Interoperability refers to all measures, including network interconnection, which
should be implemented to ensure end-to-end connections. Although there is no obligation to reach any specific
outcome, if a provider does not comply with its obligation to enter into good-faith negotiations, the ACM, at
the other party’s request, can impose proportionate obligations on the provider in order to ensure end-to-end
connectivity.

**_Financial Services Regulation_**

We provide consumer credit to customers for payment installments for mobile devices when obtaining
a post-paid subscription. Our entity providing these services, T-Mobile Netherlands Finance B.V. is subject to
the Dutch Financial Supervision Act (Wet op het financieel toezicht).

**_Significant Market Power_**

To ensure that the telecommunications markets become genuinely competitive, the ACM can, in the
event of a possibility of consumer harm at retail level, impose ex ante regulation at wholesale level by means
of market analysis decisions on operators or service providers that have significant market power in a relevant
market. Ex ante regulation means that the ACM sets behavioral rules beforehand with which providers who the
ACM determines have significant market power must comply. A company will be deemed to have significant
market power if, either individually or jointly with others, it enjoys a market position equivalent to dominance,
_i.e., a position of economic strength affording it the power to behave to an appreciable extent independently of_
competitors, customers, and ultimately consumers.

Before it can be established whether an operator or service provider has significant market power, the
ACM needs to determine, in accordance with the principles of general European competition law, in which
relevant electronic communications market(s) the operator or service provider competes. The ACM must do
this while taking into account the European Commission’s “Recommendation on relevant product and service
markets within the electronic communications sector,” the latest version of which was published by the
European Commission on December 21, 2020. The ACM may also define additional relevant markets provided
that any such market meets the cumulative criteria defined by the European Commission in its so called threecriteria test for determining whether a market is susceptible to ex ante regulation.

If the ACM determines that a company has significant market power, the ACM must, subject to
appropriateness and proportionality principles, impose one or more obligations. These obligations relate to,
among other things, access and use of specific network facilities, non-discrimination, transparency, and price
regulation at both the wholesale and retail level, though the framework seeks for obligations to be imposed as
much as possible at an upstream (wholesale) level. To ensure a proper functioning of the market, these
obligations may not be disproportionate. The investigation of a relevant market, the designation of parties with
significant market power and the imposition of _ex ante obligations culminate in so-called market analysis_
decisions of the ACM. These decisions normally apply for a period of three years, after which the market
concerned needs to be re-investigated. Under the EECC this term is extended to five years.

The ACM has completed various rounds of market analyses. The Company was designated as a party
with significant market power for both the fixed terminating and mobile terminating access markets.

The analysis in respect of these markets are discussed below.


-----

**_ACM Call Termination Market Analysis Decisions_**

In respect of the call termination market, the ACM has taken the view that all providers of call
termination on fixed-line and mobile networks in The Netherlands have significant market power because all
such providers exclusively control access to end-users connected to their respective public telephone networks.
As a result, Former Ziggo (in relation to fixed call termination services) and Vodafone NL (in relation to both
fixed and mobile call termination services), have been subject to specific _ex ante obligations, including in_
particular tariff regulation (maximum termination charges), since the ACM’s third market analysis decision of
July 7, 2010. On August 5, 2013, the ACM published its fourth market analysis decision on call termination,
which combined both the fixed termination market and the mobile termination market. The new tariffs became
effective September 1, 2013, and applied for a three-year period that ended September 1, 2016. The decision
was appealed by various operators, including us, and on August 27, 2013, the Dutch Supreme Administrative
Court decided in a preliminary decision that the price cap on mobile termination charges should be higher than
the ACM had initially determined. The court ruled that the ACM should apply a so-called Bottom-up Long Run
Incremental Cost (“BULRIC”) plus cost calculation method (taking into account common overhead costs
relating also to other services than mobile call termination, (“BULRIC plus”)) rather than a pure BULRIC
method (in which such common overhead costs are to be disregarded, “pure BULRIC”). These revised tariffs
applied until the Dutch Supreme Administrative Court arrived at a final decision in the appeal proceedings on
the merits (see below). Because the pure BULRIC method used by the ACM is in fact a method recommended
by the European Commission in its 2009 Recommendation on the Regulatory Treatment of Termination Rates,
the Supreme Administrative Court posed prejudicial questions to the European Court of Justice.

After an Advocate General opinion, the European Court of Justice ruled on September 15, 2016, that
deviation from the European Commission’s 2009 Recommendation on Termination Rates is only possible if
justified by national circumstances. The ACM started a new (the fifth) market analysis and published a draft
decision on November 18, 2016, in which they again regulate using a pure BULRIC calculation. The hearing
at the Dutch Supreme Administrative Court was held on January 11, 2017, and ruling given on July 10, 2017,
upheld the ACM’s use of pure BULRIC, though not requesting retroactive adjustment.

In April 2017, the ACM provided their plan to impose tariff ceilings of €0.00139 per minute for fixed
and €0.005819 per minute for mobile calls from July 1, 2017, to the European Commission. The European
Commission approved these in May, 2017. The new tariff implementation was delayed by the court decision,
until July 12, 2017. VFZ appealed ACM’s market decision. In September 2018, the appeal court delivered its
decision on VFZ’s appeal against the ACM’s Mobile Termination/Fixed-line Termination Rate (“MTR” and
“FTR”) regulations market decision. The verdict provides the relevant guidance sought by VFZ about the
interpretation and setting of interconnection tariffs among operators.

Further to the entry into force of the EECC, the European Commission has adopted a delegated act on
December 18, 2020, that will set maximum, EU-wide voice termination rates, both fixed and mobile. These
rates will be applicable to any operator providing voice call termination services in the EU. Approval of the
delegated act by the European Council and the European Parliament is expected in the course of 2021 and then,
after two months, the new rates will apply. The delegated act includes a transition period for the fixed rate that
ends on December 31, 2021, and a glide path for the mobile rates that ends on December 31, 2023. On July 21,
2020, ACM has extended the applicability of the rates that the delegated act did not regulate until the new
European rates apply.

**_ACM Wholesale Fixed Access Decision_**

On February 27, 2018, the ACM published a draft decision of its analysis of the LLU market,
concluding that there is a single market for local and central access. ACM referred to this market as the
Wholesale Fixed Access (WFA) market and concluded for the first time that KPN and VFZ had joint Significant
Market Power. As a result, ACM imposed an obligation on VFZ to offer wholesale cable access and continued
wholesale access regulation of KPN. Following a market consultation, ACM submitted the draft decision to the
European Commission. After comments by the European Commission, ACM published the final decision on
September 28, 2018, which became effective on October 1, 2018. VFZ published a draft Reference Offer on
December 31, 2018, and published tariffs on March 31, 2019. In parallel, KPN and VFZ appealed ACM’s
decision before the national court seeking annulment, while T-Mobile and Tele2 appealed with the intent to


-----

secure more stringent regulation. VFZ also initiated an action before the European General Court related to the
European Commission’s response to the consultation. The national appeal turned out successful: on March 17,
2020, the Court annulled ACM’s decision. With Court’s verdict being final, VFZ is no longer obligated to offer
cable access and has since withdrawn its reference offer. Also, KPN is no longer obligated to offer regulated
access. On July 9, 2021, the ACM indicated in a press release that it is again investigating fixed access, because
KPN’s access conditions may make it more difficult for competitors to compete, which may in the future lead
to higher prices for consumers and companies, and lower uptake of high-speed internet. In its press release the
ACM indicated that it intends to publish a new draft market analysis decision in the fall of 2021, which has not
yet been done.

**_Symmetrical access_**

The DTA is undergoing revision to fully implement the European Electronic Communications Code
and has already been revised to contain provisions enabling the ACM to impose obligations inter alia to grant
access to infrastructure within buildings or up to the first concentration or distribution point of the network. For
this to occur it is necessary that replication is economically inefficient or physically impracticable. Moreover,
should this kind of access be insufficient to overcome high and non-transitory barriers to replication within the
context of a market situation significantly limiting competitive outcomes for end users, the ACM will be able
to impose obligations beyond the first concentration or distribution point of the network. The ACM has not yet
made use of these new powers, and it remains to be seen if and how exactly they will be applied, however it is
likely that the ACM in doing so will take into account BEREC’s December 2020 Guidelines on the Criteria for
a Consistent Application of Article 61 (3) EECC. Nevertheless, they could become an alternative or addition to
its powers under the significant market power regime described below. A key difference is that for these
symmetrical access provisions to be applied, the ACM will not need to demonstrate the existence of such
significant market power (but rather replicability issues and, for access beyond the first concentration or
distribution point, a market situation significantly limiting competition outcomes for consumers). We have
requested the ACM to make use of its new powers and impose symmetrical access ACM is currently prioritizing
its market analysis decision process to impose access regulation on the basis of market dominance. The timing
of a decision based on the new powers granted to ACM under the symmetric access regulation is therefore
unclear.

**_Network and services security and continuity_**

As a provider of public electronic communication networks and services, we are subject to specific
obligations to safeguard the security and integrity of our networks and services, and to ensure the continuity of
electronic communications services in the event of disturbances or outages of the electricity grid. We are
required to notify the AT in case of disturbances, which materially threaten the continuity of our networks and
services, and the National Cyber Security Center (“NCSC”) in case of security and integrity breaches caused
by cyberattacks, which could lead to disturbance of the continuity. To mitigate the risks to continuity of mobile
services, T-Mobile, Vodafone NL, and KPN voluntarily entered into national roaming arrangements in 2014,
allowing for their respective subscribers to roam (voice and SMS) on the other parties’ networks in the event
of local outages of mobile networks where the outage is foreseen to last for more than three days and affect
over 500,000 customers. Acquisitions of control in telecommunications companies (such as ourselves, or
companies we may wish to acquire) may be subject to a notification requirement and investigation from the
perspective whether the acquisition poses a threat to the public interest, with the worst possible outcome being
a prohibition of the acquisition.

In October 2021, additional rules (Regeling veiligheid en integriteit telecommunicatie) were published
aiming to protect critical network elements, adjacent elements, security elements and control environments. The
rules include specifications for implementation, and are categorized as follows: (i) safe configuration of
technical equipment, (ii) safe configuration of networks, (iii) guarding of technical infrastructure, (iv) security
assurance for software and control services, and (v) human resource security. We will have to comply with
these rules ultimately by October 1, 2022.


-----

**_End-user Protection_**

As a provider of public electronic communication networks and services, we are subject to specific
regulations aiming to protect end-users, including regulations concerning information obligations toward
consumers, the enactment of amendments to end-user contracts, the term of end user contracts, termination
rights of consumers, quality reporting, access to emergency numbers and subscriber information, and
compensation of subscriber fees in the event of outages. Access to emergency numbers has to be provided
without limitation and free of charge. Access to subscriber information includes the provision of access to the
names, addresses and telephone numbers of our subscribers who have consented to be included in directory
enquiry services.

**_Data Protection_**

For providers of public electronic communications networks or services and further to the GDPR and
the ePrivacy Directive, a strict data protection regime applies in The Netherlands. On May 25, 2018, the EU
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which replaced the European Data Protection Directive, came
into force. The GDPR has direct effect in The Netherlands with additional data protection obligations relevant
to our operations that include: (i) clear explanation and transparency of personal data usage to customers and
employees, and maintaining an internal data processing register, (ii) affirmative consent from users for profiling
by automated means, (iii) stronger privacy rights for users and (iv) application of privacy by design/default to
data processes. In addition to the general data protection framework of the GDPR, the DTA sets out specific
regulations for providers of public electronic communications networks and services. These regulations include
an obligation to offer certain technical facilities, such as specification of invoices, telephone number
identification and transfer of calls, rules regarding the use and processing of location data and traffic data (i.e.,
call detail records), an obligation to provide access to subscriber lists for directory services, obligations to
implement security measures to protect personal data and rules regarding unsolicited commercial
communications (“spam”). The DTA also obliges providers of public electronic communications networks to
notify the AT in case of a security breach or major outage. If this includes the leakage of personal data processed
by the provider, the AP needs to be informed as well.

On January 10, 2017, a draft ePrivacy Regulation (“ePR”) was proposed by the European Commission
to replace the ePrivacy Directive. On February 10, 2021, the Council reached an agreement on their position on
the ePR and negotiations are ongoing. It is unclear when the ePR will be agreed on by all Member States and
enter into force.

**_Lawful Interception_**

Providers of public telecommunication networks and services can only make their networks and
services available to the public if they have arranged their networks and services in such a manner that they can
be lawfully intercepted promptly. Providers of public telecommunication networks and services are obligated
to cooperate fully in the execution of a lawfully given special tapping order or permission, in accordance with
the technical and procedural requirements set forth on the basis of the DTA, and to provide relevant Dutch law
enforcement agencies information on subscribers and telecommunications traffic.

**_Net Neutrality_**

On January 1, 2013, certain provisions in the DTA with respect to net neutrality entered into force.
These provisions regulate net neutrality by, among other things, prohibiting operators of public
telecommunication networks through which internet access is provided as well as internet service providers
from blocking or restricting services or applications which are accessed via the internet other than in
circumstances set forth in the DTA. In October 2015, the European Parliament adopted a new Regulation
including the first EU-wide net neutrality regime. Following a lengthy legislative procedure, the regulation
(directly applicable in all Member States from April 30, 2016) reflects a light-handed approach to net neutrality
permitting the provision of specialized services optimized for specific content and approving reasonable traffic
management. In October 2016, a bill to change the DTA pursuant to the EU net neutrality Regulation was
adopted by the Dutch Senate. In the law, a specific obligation prohibiting tariff differentiation for data was
maintained, which however did not follow from the Regulation. The Court in Rotterdam ruled on April 20,


-----

2017, that the Dutch ban on zero rating for data is not valid as the EU net neutrality Regulation does not allow
further national regulation on this issue. Also the net neutrality regulation did not contain a prohibition of any
form of zero-rating. Therefore, the Dutch law was conflicting with the EU net neutrality regulation and had to
be set aside. As a result, the DTA was amended to properly reflect the EU regulation. The special interest group
Bits of Freedom has brought a series of legal challenges aimed at prohibiting zero rating, all of which were
unsuccessful. BEREC is currently reviewing zero rating as a result of a decision of the European Court of
Justice from September 2, 2021.

**_Radio and Television Transmission_**

The distribution of must-carry television services to the public is regulated by the DMA, entailing
obligations regarding the transmission of specified radio and television broadcast channels. On January 1, 2014,
the revised must-carry obligations became effective. The revised must carry obligations do not only apply to
cable operators, as was previously the case, but also apply to all providers of analogue and digital program
packages based on the principle of technology neutrality. Providers of digital program packages with 100,000
or more subscribers are subject to the obligation to provide at least 30 television channels, including six public
television broadcasting channels as a must carry obligation, a limited amount of regional and local television
broadcasting channels and a number of digital radio broadcasting channels. In addition, all providers of
analogue program packages with 100,000 or more subscribers must include at least 15 television channels,
including five public broadcasting channels as a must carry obligation, a limited amount of regional and local
television broadcasting channels and some analogue radio broadcasting channels. The DMA can grant a
(conditional) exemption from the obligation if the must carry obligations listed above give rise to
disproportionate costs for the network operator, an impediment to innovation or other unreasonable outcomes.

There is no regulated financing mechanism in place between network operators and broadcasters.
Commercial and public program providers must negotiate with network operators regarding transmission fees.

**_Property Rules regarding the Network_**

In accordance with the Dutch Civil Code, all public fixed-line electronic communication networks are
the legal property of the rightful constructer of the network or its legal successor, and not (by accession) of the
owner of the ground in which the network resides. Registration at the Land Registry (het Kadaster) is required
for the transfer of legal ownership and/or to encumber public networks, for example by a right of mortgage.
Registration is also required to enjoy statutory protection against title claims of third parties. We have currently
registered a substantial majority of our network at the Land Registry.

**_Roaming_**

As a result of the European Roaming Regulation, which has direct effect in The Netherlands, as of
June 15, 2017, roaming retail surcharges are no longer permitted, subject to a fair use policy. On June 15, 2017,
revised maximum wholesale roaming rates (exclusive of VAT) became effective as follows (i) outgoing calls
at €0.032 per minute, (ii) incoming calls at €0.0114 per minute, (iii) €0.01 per SMS sent, and (iv) rates for data
at €7.7 per GB decreasing annually ultimately to €2.5 per GB effective January 1, 2022.

**_International calls_**

New rules regarding intra EU communications impose regulated maximum retail prices charged to
consumers of €0.19 per minute for calls and €0.06 per SMS messages (exclusive of VAT). The rates apply to
fixed and mobile communications, effective from May 15, 2019 for a period of five years.

**_Consumer Credit_**

In June 2014, and February 2016, the Dutch (Civil) Supreme Court ruled that certain combined
propositions of mobile services and a mobile handset could, under circumstances, be qualified as, inter alia,
consumer credit and installment sales, which qualification could have consequences on the validity of certain
customer contracts and the applicability of financial laws including the supervision of the Autoriteit Financiële
_Markten (the Dutch financial market supervisory body, “AFM”). The Company was not party to the above-_


-----

mentioned proceedings. Since January 1, 2017 mobile operators are subject to the Financial Supervision Act
(“WFT” Wet Financieel Toezicht) and are required to have a license for the AFM to provide consumer credit
services when allowing customers purchasing a mobile device to pay in installments for such device. TMNL
was granted a consumer credit license by the end of 2016 and is subject to the supervision of the AFM.

In February 2021, the Dutch Minister of Finance sent a letter to the Dutch Parliament reflecting an
intention to revise consumer credit regulation in The Netherlands by lowering the threshold for document
verification required to obtain a loan for a mobile device. The proposal is to lower the threshold from €1,000 to
€250. So far, no legislative proposal has been submitted to the Dutch Parliament to execute this intention and
also no decision is taken if such proposal will be submitted.

**Corporate Governance**

The Group has a number of bodies, control mechanisms and internal rules that conform its corporate
governance system with the objective, inter alia, of managing and regulating the Group’s organization in a
transparent and efficient manner and promoting its common interest and that of its stakeholders, as reflected in
its Corporate Governance Policy. In addition to its Corporate Governance Policy, the Group operates under a
Code of Ethics, as well as its internal rules of conduct, certain rules applicable to its governing bodies, various
corporate policies and protocols and a compliance model, in addition to numerous policies and procedures in
various areas of its operations aimed at improving management of the business.

The composition, operation and activity of the Group’s principal governing bodies and their main
responsibilities are as follows:

    - _The Management Board, at the level of the Target, is the body responsible for administering_
and representing the Group notwithstanding the powers granted to the general meeting. In
connection with these functions, among others, the articles of association set forth specific
duties assigned to the Board.

    - _The Supervisory Board, at the level of the Target, is the body responsible by law for_
supervising the policy pursued by the management board and the general course of affairs in
the company and its business. Its members are appointed by the general meeting.

    - _The Executive Committee, at the level of the Target, manages the day-to-day business of the_
Target Group. The Executive Committee’s current members are Søren Abildgaard, Gero
Niemeyer, Tisha van Lammeren, Léon Toet, Kim Larsen, Pieter de Klein, Margreet Hoekstra
and Saskia Bekkers.

**CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS**

We have entered into various agreements or transactions with certain related parties from time to time.
These agreements and transactions are carried out on arm’s length terms and we believe that the terms of these
agreements are no more favorable to the related parties and our affiliates than what they would have been with
disinterested third-parties.

The following summary describes our material related party transactions.

**_Demerger of T-Infra (now Cignal Infrastructure)_**

On September 1, 2018, the Target Group’s passive network infrastructure elements, notably its mobile
network towers, were demerged into T-Infra, a 100% subsidiary of T-Mobile Netherlands. On December 17,
2018, T-Mobile Netherlands and T-Infra entered into a master services agreement for TMNL’s use of towers
for a fee. Subsequently, on January 1, 2019, T-Infra was distributed out of the Target Group to Deutsche
Telekom. The agreement governing the relationship between the Target Group and T-Infra (since June 2021
named Cignal Infrastructure) was amended and restated as a master lease agreement on May 27, 2021. For more
information on the T-Infra demerger, see “Business—History of the Group.” From January 1, 2019 onwards,
pursuant to the transfer of T-Infra out of the Target Group, T-Infra’s financial information is not included in
TMNL’s consolidated financial information.

**_Existing Target Group Facilities_**

We have entered into the Existing Target Group Facilities with Deutsche Telekom and/or its affiliates,
consisting of the Existing Target Group 2018 Facilities and Existing Target Group 2020 Facility. On or about
the Completion Date, we expect to prepay all amounts outstanding under the Existing Target Group Facilities
and to cancel these facilities. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.”

**_Separation from Deutsche Telekom_**

Following the Acquisition, our business operations will be separated from Deutsche Telekom and run
as a stand-alone business. In this regard, and at the time of completion of the Acquisition, we expect to enter
into certain transitional services agreements with Deutsche Telekom and/or its affiliates. See “Business—
_Separation from Deutsche Telekom.”_

conditions customary for companies owned by private equity funds with the objective of aligning the long-term
incentives of Target Group’s senior management employees with those of Target Group’s shareholders.

**Senior Facilities Agreement**

**_Overview_**

On September 16, 2021, WP/AP Telecom Holdings III B.V. (the “Parent”) entered into a €3.10 billion
senior secured term and revolving facilities agreement between, among others, ABN Amro Bank N.V., Banco
Santander, S.A., Banque Nomura France, Barclays Bank PLC, Barclays Bank Ireland PLC, BNP Paribas,
Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A., Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch, Credit
Suisse (Deutschland) Aktiengesellschaft, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, ING Bank N.V., Jefferies Finance
Europe, S.L.P., Jefferies Finance LLC, KKR Capital Markets (Ireland) Limited, Mizuho Bank, Ltd., Morgan
Stanley Bank AG, MUFG Bank, Ltd., National Westminster Bank Plc, Natwest Markets N.V., Royal Bank Of
Canada, SMBC Bank International Plc, Société Générale, London Branch, Standard Chartered Bank and
UniCredit Bank AG as arrangers and, together with Bank of China Limited, Luxembourg Branch and KB
Securities Co., Ltd and KB Securities Hong Kong Limited (as sole Korean mandated lead arranger), as
mandated lead arrangers, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Europe) S.A. Amsterdam Branch as lead
arranger and Lucid Agency Services Limited as agent (the “Agent”) and Lucid Trustee Services Limited as
security agent (the “Security Agent”) (as amended and restated on October 18, 2021 and November 25, 2021
and as amended and/or amended and restated from time to time, the “Senior Facilities Agreement”).

The Senior Facilities Agreement provided a term loan facility of €2.40 billion (the “TLB”) to WP/AP
Telecom Holdings IV B.V. as original borrower (the “Borrower”) and revolving facilities of €500 million
(“RCF 1”) and €200 million (“RCF 2,” and together with RCF 1, the “RCF,” and the RCF together with the
TLB, the “Credit Facilities”) to the Borrower.

**_Purpose_**

Borrowings funded under the TLB have been applied towards:

(a) amounts payable in connection with the acquisition (the “Acquisition”) of the shares in TMobile Netherlands Holding B.V. (the “Target”);

(b) refinancing certain existing indebtedness of the Group;

(c) transaction costs in connection with the Acquisition; and

(d) working capital requirements and/or general corporate purposes of the Group.

Borrowings under the RCF may be applied towards working capital requirements and/or general
corporate purposes of the Group (for the avoidance of doubt, including without limitation the financing or
refinancing of any acquisition or capital expenditure). The RCF may be drawn in cash or letter of credit and can
be made available by lenders thereunder way of bilateral ancillary facility and fronted ancillary facilities. The
RCF is currently available until 77 months following the first utilization of the TLB (the “SFA Closing Date”).

**_Repayments and prepayments_**

Repayment of the TLB is due 84 months after the SFA Closing Date.

Repayment of loans drawn under the RCF and related interest payments will be due and payable on
the last day of the interest period for each loan. The applicable interest period is selected in the relevant


-----

utilization request or selection notice and will either be two weeks (an option in respect of the RCF only) or
one, two, three or six months subject to certain exceptions.

If it becomes unlawful in any applicable jurisdiction for a lender to perform its obligations under the
Senior Facilities Agreement, such lender under the Senior Facilities Agreement will have the right to cancel its
commitments. Each Borrower shall repay the relevant lender’s participation in any loans made to that Borrower
on the date specified by the relevant lender in the notice delivered to the Parent (being no earlier than the last
Business Day of any applicable grace period permitted by law).

On a change of control or sale of all or substantially all of the assets of the Group (subject to a leveragebased portability exception applicable to the TLB only (set at a pro forma Senior Secured Leverage Ratio (as
defined below) of not more than 4.75:1)), a lender may, by notice to the Parent and on the first Business Day
falling at least 60 days after the date of receipt by the Parent of the notice, cancel all of its undrawn commitments
and declare all outstanding amounts owed to it due and payable provided that such request is made within 30
days of the date of the Agent’s receipt of the notification from the Parent that such change of control or sale has
occurred.

In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement requires that, in respect of each financial year of the
Parent, a mandatory prepayment of loans under the TLB is made in an amount equal to a percentage of excess
cashflow (net of a minimum threshold amount and the amount of any voluntary prepayments made during such
financial year and amounts reinvested in the business of the Group within certain time limits and certain other
permitted uses of such amounts) which percentage decreases as the Group’s Senior Secured Leverage Ratio (as
defined below) decreases.

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains a prepayment fee provision whereby lenders in respect of
the TLB will, subject to customary carve-outs and exceptions, benefit from a prepayment fee of 1% of their
participation in the relevant amount of any facility under the TLB if all or part of that facility is voluntarily
prepaid in connection with a refinancing or repricing, or the Senior Facilities Agreement is amended pursuant
to a refinancing or repricing transaction, in each case, within six months of the earlier of the SFA Closing Date
and the date on which any commitment fee in respect of available commitments under the TLB is payable at a
rate equal to 100% of the then applicable margin on the TLB, the primary purpose of which (as determined by
the Parent in good faith) is to reduce the effective yield on the TLB.

**_Interest and fees_**

Borrowings under the TLB initially bear interest at a rate equal to the aggregate of EURIBOR and a
margin of 4.00% per annum.

Loans under the RCF initially bear interest at a rate equal to the aggregate of LIBOR (in respect of
loans drawn in any currency other than Euro and Sterling), compounding overnight SONIA (in respect of loans
drawn in Sterling) and EURIBOR (in respect of loans drawn in Euro) and a margin of 3.25% per annum.

All base rates have a zero floor under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

After the date falling six (6) months after the SFA Closing Date, the margin for each loan under each
of the Credit Facilities will be subject to adjustment by reference to the Senior Secured Leverage Ratio (as
defined below) as shown in the quarterly financial statements or, as the case may be, the annual financial
statements for that relevant period and the related compliance certificate delivered to the Facility Agent, to
equal the rate per annum set out in the following table:

Default interest on each of the Credit Facilities will be calculated as an additional 1.00% per annum
on the overdue amount.

In respect of the RCF 1 and RCF 2 a “commitment fee” is payable on the available commitments under
each of RCF 1 and RCF 2, until the end of the availability period applicable to RCF 1 and RCF 2 (as the case
may be), at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for RCF 1 and RCF 2 (as the case may be). Such commitment
fee is payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period applicable to the RCF and, if
cancelled, on the cancelled amount of the relevant lender’s commitment under the relevant RCF at the time the
cancellation becomes effective.

The Parent is required to pay customary agency fees to each of the Agent and the Security Agent in
connection with the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**_Additional Facilities_**

The Parent may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility and/or as an increase in or
as additional tranches of the Senior Facilities Agreement (the “Additional Facilities”). The Parent and the
lenders in respect of the Additional Facilities may agree to certain terms in relation to the Additional Facilities,
including the margin, the termination date (each subject to parameters as set out in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) and the availability period thereof. Subject to the parameters set out in the Senior Facilities
Agreement, unless the indebtedness incurred is otherwise permitted under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the
maximum aggregate principal amount of the indebtedness outstanding under all Additional Facilities (after
taking into account the application of proceeds of any relevant indebtedness) may not at any time result in a
breach of the limitation of indebtedness covenant in the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**_Guarantees_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement is guaranteed by the Parent and the Guarantors. The Senior Facilities
Agreement requires that (subject to agreed security principles as set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement (the
“Agreed Security Principles”)) each member of the Group which:

(a) is incorporated in The Netherlands (the “Security Jurisdiction”); and

(b) is a “Material Company” (which is generally defined under the Senior Facilities Agreement
to include, among other things, any wholly owned Restricted Subsidiary of the Parent
incorporated in a Security Jurisdiction that has earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and
amortization representing 5% or more of consolidated EBITDA of the Group), each holding
company that is a member of the Group of a company which is a Material Company, and any
Restricted Subsidiary of the Parent to which it has been transferred the whole or substantially
the whole of the assets of a Restricted Subsidiary that was a Material Company prior to such
transfer,

will be required to become a guarantor under the Senior Facilities Agreement within 60 days of the
delivery of the Group’s annual audited consolidated financial statements for the relevant year showing that such
subsidiary is a Material Company such that the guarantors represent at least 80% of the consolidated EBITDA
of the Group (subject to certain exceptions and excluding the EBITDA of any non-obligor and the EBITDA of
any member of the Group not required to become a Guarantor in accordance with the Agreed Security
Principles).

In addition, any member of the Target Group which is incorporated in a Security Jurisdiction and is a
Material Company (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) is required to become a guarantor under the
Senior Facilities Agreement within 120 days of the SFA Closing Date, such that the guarantors represent at
least 80% of the consolidated EBITDA of the Group (subject to certain exceptions and excluding the EBITDA
of any non-obligor and the EBITDA of any member of the Group not required to become a Guarantor in
accordance with the Agreed Security Principles).


-----

**_Security_**

Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Guarantors have granted or will grant security interests
on a first priority basis (to the extent legally possible) in favor of the Security Agent over certain assets as
described below:

(a) in the case of each borrower and/or guarantor incorporated in The Netherlands (the day one
“Security Jurisdiction” for purposes of the Senior Facilities Agreement):

(i) security over any shares held by it in another borrower and/or guarantor;

(ii) any material operating bank accounts held by it; and

(iii) any material structural intercompany loans made by it to another borrower and/or
guarantor; and

(b) in the case of each other borrower and/or guarantor incorporated in a security jurisdiction that
is not The Netherlands, security over any shares held by it in a borrower and/or guarantor.

**_Representations and warranties_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties (subject to
certain exceptions and qualifications and with certain representations and warranties being repeated), including
status and incorporation, power and authority, binding obligations, non-conflict with constitutional documents,
applicable laws and certain other obligations, authorizations, no default, accuracy of information and acquisition
documents.

**_Affirmative covenants_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement requires certain members of the Group to observe certain affirmative
covenants, including:

(a) maintenance of relevant authorizations;

(b) compliance with laws;

(c) payment of taxes;

(d) maintenance of pari passu ranking of the TLB;

(e) compliance with obligations relating to pensions;

(f) provision of financial and other information and (in certain circumstances) granting access to
books and records to the facility agent and the security agent;

(g) maintenance of intellectual property;

(h) maintenance of insurance;

(i) maintenance of guarantor and security coverage and further assurances; and

(j) maintenance of ratings in respect of the TLB and/or a corporate family credit rating.

The Senior Facilities Agreement also contains an “information covenant” under which, among other
things and in the first instance, the Parent is required to deliver to the Agent annual financial statements,
quarterly financial statements and compliance certificates. Note, however, that the delivery of
accounts/financial statements as set out under the caption “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain
_Covenants—Reports” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Reports” of this Offering_
Memorandum will satisfy the information covenant.


-----

**_Negative covenants_**

The Credit Facilities Agreement contains certain customary operating and financial covenants (see “—
_Financial covenant” below), subject to certain exceptions and qualifications, including covenants restricting_
the ability of certain members of the Group to do the following:

(a) merge with other companies;

(b) incur additional indebtedness;

(c) enter into transactions other than on arm’s length basis;

(d) make restricted payments;

(e) create security over its assets;

(f) sell its assets and stock (subject to any related re-investment rights or prepayment
requirements in relation to such sales); and

(g) to repay or redeem certain junior ranking indebtedness.

**_Financial covenant_**

With respect to the RCF only, the Senior Facilities Agreement provides that if the sum of certain
outstanding senior secured net indebtedness of the Group to the consolidated EBITDA of the Group in respect
of each relevant period ending on or after the date falling 12 Months after the SFA Closing Date (the “Senior
**Secured Leverage Ratio”) shall not exceed 8.50:1.00, the financial ratio test for that period will be satisfied,**

_provided that:_

(a) the financial covenant is only to be tested if at 5.00 pm London time on the last day of the
applicable relevant period, the amount drawn by way of loan under the RCF (including any
additional revolving facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement) (less cash and cash
equivalents and any proceeds of any RCF loan used to fund any original issue discount) is
greater than 40% of the aggregate of the commitments under the RCF (including any
additional revolving facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement) at that time; and

(b) with respect to the TLB, failure to satisfy the financial covenant ratio shall not (or be deemed
to) constitute or result in a breach of any representation, warranty, undertaking or an event of
default.

The Parent is permitted to prevent or cure breaches of the net leverage covenant by applying a “cure”
amount (generally, amounts received by the Parent in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted subordinated
debt) as if consolidated EBITDA had been increased by such amount or the consolidated leverage had been
decreased by such amount. There is no requirement to apply any cure amount in prepayment of the Credit
Facilities. In each period of four consecutive financial quarters there shall be at least one financial quarter where
a different cure amount is not first taken into account and no more than five different cure amounts may be
taken into account prior to the original termination date of the TLB.

**_Events of default_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain events of default, the occurrence of which would
allow the requisite majority of lenders to, amongst other actions, accelerate all outstanding loans and terminate
their commitments, including, among other events (subject in certain cases to agreed grace periods, financial
thresholds and other qualifications):

(a) failure to pay off any amounts when due under the finance documents entered into in
connection with the Credit Facilities;


-----

(b) (with respect to the RCF only) breach of the financial covenant or (with respect to all Credit
Facilities) failure to comply with other obligations under the Credit Facilities finance
documents;

(c) inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made (subject to materiality qualifications);

(d) cross defaults in relation to certain indebtedness;

(e) (subject to certain thresholds) insolvency, insolvency proceedings and commencement of
certain creditors’ processes, such as expropriation, attachment, sequestration, distress or
execution;

(f) unlawfulness, invalidity rescission and repudiation, or unenforceability of the finance
documents entered into in connection with the Credit Facilities; and

(g) breach of material obligations under the Intercreditor Agreement by any holding company of
the Parent that is party thereto.

**_Governing law and jurisdiction_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection
with it are governed by English law and the courts of England have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any disputes
arising out of or in connection with the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**Bridge Facility Agreements**

On September 16, 2021, the Parent entered into a senior secured bridge facility agreement between,
amongst others, ABN Amro Bank N.V., Banco Santander, S.A., Banque Nomura France, Barclays Bank PLC,
BNP Paribas, Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A., Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, Credit Suisse AG, London
Branch, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, ING Bank N.V., Jefferies Finance LLC, KKR Capital Markets
(Ireland) Limited, Mizuho Bank, Ltd., Morgan Stanley Bank AG, MUFG Bank, Ltd., Natwest Markets N.V.,
Royal Bank Of Canada, SMBC Bank International Plc, Société Générale, London Branch, Standard Chartered
Bank and UniCredit Bank AG as lead arrangers, the Agent and the Security Agent (as amended and restated on
October 18, 2021, the “Senior Secured Bridge Facility Agreement”). The Senior Secured Bridge Facility
Agreement provided a term loan facility of €800 million to the Borrower (the “Senior Secured Bridge
**Facility”).**

On September 16, 2021, the Parent entered into a senior bridge facility agreement between, amongst
others, ABN Amro Bank N.V., Banco Santander, S.A., Banque Nomura France, Barclays Bank PLC, BNP
Paribas, Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A., Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch,
Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, ING Bank N.V., Jefferies Finance LLC, KKR Capital Markets (Ireland)
Limited, Mizuho Bank, Ltd., Morgan Stanley Bank AG, MUFG Bank, Ltd., Natwest Markets N.V., Royal Bank
Of Canada, SMBC Bank International Plc, Société Générale, London Branch, Standard Chartered Bank and
UniCredit Bank AG as lead arrangers, the Agent and the Security Agent (as amended and restated on October
18, 2021, the “Senior Bridge Facility Agreement” and together with the Senior Secured Bridge Facility
Agreement, the “Bridge Facility Agreements”). The Senior Bridge Facility Agreement provided a term loan
facility of €550 million to the Borrower (the “Senior Bridge Facility” and together with the Senior Secured
Bridge Facility, the “Bridge Facilities”).

It is anticipated that the commitments under the Bridge Facilities will be cancelled on or prior to the
Issue Date and be replaced by the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes (respectively).

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_General_**

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, WP/AP
Telecom Holdings III B.V. (the “Parent”), WP/AP Telecom Holdings IV B.V. (together with any other entity


-----

which accedes or otherwise becomes a party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a debtor, the “Debtors”) entered
into an intercreditor agreement (the “Intercreditor Agreement”) dated September 16, 2021 (as amended and
restated by an amendment and restatement agreement dated October 18, 2021 and as amended and/or amended
and restated from time to time), with, among others, Lucid Agency Services Limited as facility agent and Lucid
Trustee Services Limited as security agent. The Senior Secured Notes Trustee and the Senior Notes Trustee
will accede to the Intercreditor Agreement on the Issue Date.

The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out, among other things, the relative
ranking of certain indebtedness of the Debtors, the relative ranking of certain security granted by the collateral
providers, when payments can be made in respect of certain debt of the Debtors, when enforcement action can
be taken in respect of that indebtedness, the terms pursuant to which certain of that indebtedness will be
subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions.

The Intercreditor Agreement additionally provides for Hedge Counterparties and Operating Facility
Lenders (each as defined below) to receive guarantees and indemnities from the Debtors on substantially the
same terms (including the relevant limitations) as such guarantees and indemnities are provided by the obligors
to the finance parties under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement; provided that, in the case of the Operating
Facility Lenders, this applies only to the extent permitted by the Debt Financing Agreements (and all references
in this section titled “Intercreditor Agreement” to Operating Facilities, Operating Facility Documents,
Operating Facility Lenders and Operating Facility Liabilities should be construed accordingly).

Capitalized terms set forth and used in this section entitled “—Intercreditor Agreement” have the same
meanings as set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement, which may have different meanings from the meanings
given to such terms and used elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In particular, in this summary the term
“Senior Parent Notes” includes the indebtedness to be incurred under the indenture in respect of the Senior
Notes as defined elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
